Sub-Output: 1.2.1 Access to services, including justice for women and men, increased (Improving justice service delivery  in Kosovo + Empowering communities, youth and women for an effective rule of law and access to justice in Kosovo)
Contributing partners: United Nations Development Programme, United Nations Interim Administration Mission in Kosovo
Implementation partners: Direct implementation

Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
UNDP: "UNDP’s contribution in upholding the rule of law focused on strengthening the capacities of legal practitioners on key areas of competence: communication, integrity (ethics), case management, court translation and interpretation. 133 legal practitioners (assistant court administrators, clerks, chiefs of offices for case management, legal officers, court secretaries, public information officers, court translators and interpreters) of which 50% women, benefited from capacity development.
As part of UNDP’s dedication to gender equality and gender mainstreaming, all implemented project activities had gender-specific considerations. 
UNDP created the space for youth from Albanian, Serbian, and Roma communities, to come together and share their community challenges and propose solutions to social issues, access to justice, human rights, hate speech, and language rights. The intervention mobilized 117 multi-community youth members (aged 16 to 24 years old) who gained knowledge and skills on the above-mentioned topics and allowed the youth to build networks and constructive narratives."

Output: Capacities are enhanced to develop the mechanisms of engagement (including through volunteering), monitoring, and support of all stakeholders, including adolescents, young men and women, men and women aged 65 and older, and other vulnerable groups, in decision-making in the sphere of sustainable socio-economic development in all sectors, including through improvement of the electronic system for public discussion of draft normative legal acts
Sub-Output: 1.4.1 Empowering youth as agents of change in the fight against human trafficking ("Learn.Act.Share" summer camp series and a networking platform)
Contributing partners: United States Agency for International Development
Implementation partners: Belarus Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Belarus Ministry of Internal Affairs
SDG Targets: 8.7 Take immediate and effective measures to eradicate forced labour, end modern slavery and human trafficking and secure the prohibition and elimination of the worst forms of child labour, including recruitment and use of child soldiers, and by 2025 end child labour in all its forms.,8.8 Protect labour rights and promote safe and secure working environments for all workers, including migrant workers, in particular women migrants, and those in precarious employment.,10.2 By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.,10.7 Facilitate orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility of people, including through the implementation of planned and well-managed migration policies.
SDG Goals: 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth, 10 Reduced Inequalities
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: The activities were moved to 2024.
2024 Narrative: In July 2024, on the eve of the World Day against Trafficking In Persons celebrated on the 30th of July annually and in order to expand its awareness-raising efforts and reach out to different segments of population, IOM conducted a Summer School on Combatting Trafficking In Persons and Safe Migration bringing together 18 dynamic young leaders (nine females, nine males) —students and recent graduates—to deepen their understanding of migration issues and human trafficking, and to inspire them to take meaningful action against this global plight. Over the course of five engaging days filled with workshops, meetings, and team-building activities, the participants delved into the complexities of human trafficking. Assisted by expert practitioners from international organisations and government agencies, the young people explored connections between trafficking in persons and broader issues such as migration, gender equality, sustainable development, and HIV/AIDS, gaining a holistic perspective on the phenomenon. The Summer School on Combatting Trafficking in Persons and Safe Migration agenda also equipped participants with practical skills in youth leadership through the session on Summit of the Future and youth impact on sustainable development; as well as social media engagement, particularly in creating impactful social video reels. By fostering these hands-on experiences, IOM aimed to empower young people to disseminate critical information on combatting human trafficking through various channels, especially digital platforms. IOM made efforts to utilize a creative approach and new technologies to bring up a new generation of students, migration advocates and counter-trafficking leaders. Following the educational sessions, the participants produced two social video reels to educate a broad audience about human trafficking and provide tools to prevent it.

Output: Women, youth and marginalized groups benefit from supportive environment through tailored employment, income generating measures including green jobs and a more dynamic and inclusive skilling system that responds to labour market and post COVID-19 needs
Sub-Output: 3.2.1 Skills, decent jobs and livelihoods for youth and women increased
Description: ALMP2
Contributing partners: Government of Kosovo
Implementation partners: Direct implementation
SDG Targets: 8.3 Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
UNDP:In 2021, UNDP continued implementing the four institutionally approved active labor measures, including: On the job training, wage subsidy, self-employment programme, internship programme. From all the implemented measures, 510 registered jobseekers benefited, of which 58% were women, 13% of the beneficiaries were from non-majority communities, and 72% were registered regular jobseekers.
A proven strength of the project is the hands-on support to 33 employment offices with a wide geographical reach. The strategic coverage of the entire territory has resulted in 46% of the beneficiaries reached by the project being from rural areas- inherently known as areas with lower employment opportunities.
The internship scheme focused on young jobseekers and had a significant participation of women (256 out of 366). This can indicate shifting attitudes towards work, where young women are more likely to apply for internships, jobs and other employment opportunities.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Inclusive human capital development leading to health, well-being and resilient prosperity
Outcome: Outcome 4. By 2025, the most vulnerable benefit from enhanced access to gender-sensitive quality health, education and social services.
Output: Output 4.3. By 2025, the national social protection system is strengthened to deliver progressively universal inclusive and gender-responsive social security, social protection benefits and social services to address all forms of poverty, violence, social exclusion and other vulnerabilities
Sub-Output: Social Service Delivery for people with disabilities is transformed through implementation of Human Rights-Based Approach for Children, Youth and Women with Disabilities in Uzbekistan
Description: The programme will consolidate the multi-stakeholder commitment to the achievement of CRPD-compliant SDGs through a robust legislative and policy framework, sound coordination structures and meaningful participation of organizations of persons with disabilities. It will address the essential building blocks to the CRPD implementation that are legislative reform, strengthening the representativity and capacity of OPDs, and availability of inclusive services (UNPRPD Outcome 1). The programme specifically focuses on accessible person-centered and age-appropriate services in the community, aimed at supporting the autonomy and inclusion of children, women and men with disabilities and prevention of institutionalization, violence and abuse. Development of early identification and early intervention services for children with disabilities will be one of the focus areas of the programme, as will the inclusion of women and girls with disabilities in programmes addressing gender-based violence (UNPRPD Outcome 2). The programme also intends to strengthen disability mainstreaming within the implementing country-level UN agencies’ activities to ensure that national development assessments, plans, budgets, programs and monitoring mechanisms supported under the SDG processes advance disability-inclusive development in Uzbekistan (UNPRPD Outcome 3).
Contributing partners: The United Nations Partnership on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities
Implementation partners: Uzbekistan Agency on the Development of Medical and Social Services under the Cabinet of Ministers
SDG Targets: 1.3 Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable.,3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.,5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.,16.2 End abuse, exploitations, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children.
SDG Goals: 1 No Poverty, 3 Good Health and Well-being, 4 Quality Education, 5 Gender Equality, 16 Peace and Justice - Strong Institutions
Geography: Tashkent city, Uzbekistan, Fergana, Republic of Karakalpakstan, Samarkand, Namangan
QCPR function: Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Data Collection and Analysis, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 1.4 Output 1.4. Population groups at risk of being left behind are empowered to effectively participate in decision making, social cohesion, rule of law and peace-building processes at all levels
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2022 Narrative: Since the ratification of the CRPD, the Government of Uzbekistan (GoU) launched step by step process of transformation of social service delivery to people with disabilities. In 2022, the GoU has introduced substantial measures to simplify access to disability determination procedure, and disability allowances. UNICEF jointly with UNFPA, UNDP, OHCHR, the GoU and OPDs launched the UN Joint Programme funded by the UNPRPD. UNICEF supported 60 Organizations of People with Disabilities (OPDs) to enhance their capacities on implementing the CRPD.  UN Joint SitAn identified lack of OPD participation in government policy making; weak organizational capacity of OPDs, lack of OPDs led by underrepresented groups, such as women with disabilities and no OPDs representing families of children with disabilities. As leading agency under UNJP, UNICEF supported the establishment of the Steering Committee led by the Chairperson of the state Inter-Agency Group on CRPD and Advisory Group of OPDs. For the first time grassroots OPDs and SIG were included in the policy making platforms. The Advisory Group of OPDs and members of Steering Committee include OPDs based on cross-disability approach and members of self-initiative parents’ groups (SIG).  Uzbekistan’s UN Disability Inclusion Strategy (UNDIS) is UNCT’s vision for one UN approach for CRPD implementation. UNICEF initiated the process as part of the recent findings from the UN Joint Situational (SitAn) Analysis on rights of people with disabilities. 25 UNCT members endorsed UNDIS under the leadership of the UN Resident Coordinator. UNDIS prioritizes the key pre-conditions for CRPD implementation in Uzbekistan in order to promote human rights-based approach to disability inclusion. At the same time, UNJP funded by UNPRPD and implemented jointly with the GoU and OPDs, provides coordinated approach in transforming social service delivery for women and children with disabilities.  UNDP supported the GoU efforts to incorporate international standards and best practices of disability inclusion. Together with governmental and nongovernmental partners, including OPDs it is providing technical assistance to nurture national expertise in disability assessment, social services, disability inclusive programming and budgeting. UNDP has capacitated the national partners and organizations of persons with disabilities (OPD) to provide more effective contributions towards disability inclusive policies, systems and the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) in Uzbekistan, including on disability costing and budgeting in compliance with CRPD and the data collection, analysis and use to identify gaps and improve the budget allocation and usage, as well as on designing and building social services delivery for persons with disabilities. OPDs were systematically engaged in the national development strategy design through their involvement in the national development coordination mechanism and accountability frameworks.   To complement the SoP/MSR efforts a needs assessment on the availability, quality, accessibility and relevance of community-based services for GBV victims who are women and girls with disabilities was conducted on the example of Tashkent, Fergana and Samarkand regions of Uzbekistan. The study showed that further improvement of the legal and regulatory framework is required to protect the rights of people with disabilities, especially women and girls, as a special group at greater risk of violence and discrimination. A study also revealed that women and girls with disabilities experience isolation from society, which is a serious barrier to socialization and awareness.Training module on provision of inclusive services to GBV survivors was developed by the working group established from the representatives of NGOs, healthcare service provider, psychologists as well as members of the project Advisory group/organizations of people with disabilities. The training module and materials are based on the international experience, developed SOPs on MSR to GBV, governmental legislative documents, Central-Asian experience on the work with disabilities and international standards and provisions. 64 service-providers including the members of OPDs from Samarkand and Tashkent region were capacitated during pilot trainings conducted in coordination with the Senate Committee on gender equality and women as well as other national partners for Samarkand and Tashkent regions.
2023 Narrative: UNICEF: UNICEF's coordination in implementing the UN Joint Programme funded by UNPRPD resulted in provision of age-appropriate services for children, youth and women with functional difficulties. The UNJP facilitated multi-stakeholder commitment to achieving CRPD-compliant SDGs, established a robust legislative and policy framework, and ensured accessible person-centred services. Notably, UNICEF strengthened the capacity of 50,000 patronage nurses on early identification and intervention and 500 teachers on Universal Design for Education. Two inclusive schools with accessible infrastructure were modelled, generating evidence to advocate for a more integrated approach for inclusive service provision. UNFPA:For the first time disability inclusion was integrated into SOPs on MSR based on the practical guide for service providers developed with the support of UNFPA and the Committee of Family and Women. To increase the availability of services to marginalized women and girls, and within the nationwide ‘implementation and scale-up of SoP on MSR to GBV’, 239 representatives of law enforcement, healthcare, social, and psychological services providers and OPDs were trained to better understand the needs and respond to GBV with a focus on women and girls with disabilities. This result was achieved within the interagency collaboration of UNFPA, UNICEF, OHCHR and UNDP as part of the Joint Programme.

Human rights marker narrative: Project focuses on providing access to services and rights to all young people.
2023 Narrative: The project has supported development of national Youth Strategy 2023-2027 with Action plan 2023-2024. The Strategy was developed through inclusive process led by working group and consulting multiple stakeholders.  Following this, support was provided to local self-governments to create local youth action plans based on the national strategy, enabling a  comprehensive development of national and local youth policy. The project has further facilitated the provision of youth programs in local youth clubs and centers.
2024 Narrative: The project supported development and promotion of 3 and evaluation and reporting on 2 strategic documents.Youth Strategy, developed in 2023, was translated in English and Albanian, and promoted though the various formats and content, such as dedicated website and youth friendly content (www.strategijazamlade.me), social media campaign, printed materials.  The project enabled preparation of the report on the implementation of the Youth Strategy Action plan 2023-2024 and preparation of the Action plan 2025-2026. The project has ensured evaluation of the European Youth Card Development Program (EYCA) for the period from 2022-2024. year, and supported development of the program for 2025-2028.Through the project, 3 NGOs empowered 1400 young people through more than 200 activities with 11 youth clubs and centres (youth services) in 11 towns.  They have also strengthened the capacities of youth administrators to implement activities with young people and run youth services, enabled the networking of the youth administrators and youth services with other local actors.

UNICEF cooperated with the Ministry of Interior to provide its specialists training opportunities and dialogue platforms to enhance prevention work including through dedicated training via Interpol.

2023 Narrative: IOM in cooperation with  MoL and Atameken conducted the Integration Self-Assessment Survey for Migrants and Refugees in Urban Settings. The main objective of the rapid study was to identify specific obstacles to the integration of ethnic repatriates (kandas) within the urban districts where they reside. The self-assessment, which is based on the Integration Self-Assessment Survey for Migrants and Refugees in Urban Settings, gives an opportunity to use migrants’ own observations and experiences of integration in the regions of destination to identify obstacles to economic, cultural, and educational integration and inclusion. This self-assessment tool, based on the grid of polling interview questions, was used to interview kandas residents in pilot regions by IOM national expert in coordination with the Ministry of Labour and Social Protection of Population and local executive bodies (akimats). The survey complements the results of the Assessment of South-North Relocation Programme by focusing on the institutional, infrastructure and economic barriers experienced by kandas. Based on the survey’s findings, a report is being developed  with recommendations to monitor impact of existing assistance and develop targeted interventions that can ease the identified barriers to integration for kandas.  [NNC1]Do you have an estimate of when the report will be completed, validated, published? Also, if the report was not developed during the project timeframe, progress for this activity 1.6.3 should be less than 100

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Inclusive human capital development leading to health, well-being and resilient prosperity
Outcome: Outcome 4. By 2025, the most vulnerable benefit from enhanced access to gender-sensitive quality health, education and social services.
Output: Output 4.3. By 2025, the national social protection system is strengthened to deliver progressively universal inclusive and gender-responsive social security, social protection benefits and social services to address all forms of poverty, violence, social exclusion and other vulnerabilities
Sub-Output: Social Service Delivery for people with disabilities is transformed through implementation of Human Rights-Based Approach for Children, Youth and Women with Disabilities in Uzbekistan
Description: The programme will consolidate the multi-stakeholder commitment to the achievement of CRPD-compliant SDGs through a robust legislative and policy framework, sound coordination structures and meaningful participation of organizations of persons with disabilities. It will address the essential building blocks to the CRPD implementation that are legislative reform, strengthening the representativity and capacity of OPDs, and availability of inclusive services (UNPRPD Outcome 1). The programme specifically focuses on accessible person-centered and age-appropriate services in the community, aimed at supporting the autonomy and inclusion of children, women and men with disabilities and prevention of institutionalization, violence and abuse. Development of early identification and early intervention services for children with disabilities will be one of the focus areas of the programme, as will the inclusion of women and girls with disabilities in programmes addressing gender-based violence (UNPRPD Outcome 2). The programme also intends to strengthen disability mainstreaming within the implementing country-level UN agencies’ activities to ensure that national development assessments, plans, budgets, programs and monitoring mechanisms supported under the SDG processes advance disability-inclusive development in Uzbekistan (UNPRPD Outcome 3).
Contributing partners: The United Nations Partnership on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities
Implementation partners: Uzbekistan Agency on the Development of Medical and Social Services under the Cabinet of Ministers
SDG Targets: 1.3 Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable.,3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.,5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.,16.2 End abuse, exploitations, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children.
SDG Goals: 1 No Poverty, 3 Good Health and Well-being, 4 Quality Education, 5 Gender Equality, 16 Peace and Justice - Strong Institutions
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance

2023 Narrative: In 2023, the project empowered youth in the Aral Sea region by providing green skills training, entrepreneurship support, and innovation-driven opportunities to promote sustainable development. Young people were engaged in climate-smart agriculture, eco-tourism, and renewable energy initiatives, fostering economic resilience and environmental awareness.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, the project expanded its impact by scaling up vocational training programs, strengthening youth-led green enterprises, and enhancing digital innovation hubs. These efforts enabled youth to become active contributors to the region’s sustainable transformation, driving inclusive economic growth and climate resilience in one of Uzbekistan’s most vulnerable areas.

2021 Narrative:
[UNDP]: The Youth Resource Centre – iCan a newly established training service provider and innovation hub offers support to young people in Polog region in finding employment through job seeking, business creation, career, innovation and skills development, startup incubation and others. In 2021, with the revised National Employment Operational Plan 2021, iCAN was officially recognized as an implementor of the measure “Internship program”, which significantly improves sustainability prospects of the center. 
These activities are significant since they are directly contributing for strengthened with Polog region Triple helix system of cooperation among local community, MLSP, South East University of Tetovo, Gostivar municipality, SCO’s, and private sector. The Center has a specific focus on supporting women entrepreneurs. Some of the workshops that raised particular interest are “How women use digital marketing to thrive, Digital Marketing, Behavior Management”, “Career orientation, Investments for startups and Marketing Strategies for startups” and “Women entrepreneurship”. 55% of our total number of participants in the events organized by the iCan are female. More than 500 women participated in the events, and more than 300 women and girls attended courses. 70% of them were aged 29 and younger. 
This will contribute to further strengthen capacities of the center to serve as an intermediary between youth and the private sector, and act in partnership with ESA in direct implementation of active employment programs and measures for youth employment.

Strategic priority: Support national efforts to respond to people’s needs by ensuring equitable access to quality social services including education, health, social protection and decent work through effective policies and appropriate financing mechanisms with the participation of all parties (QUALITY SOCIAL SERVICES)
Outcome: By 2027, the people of the Kyrgyz Republic, particularly vulnerable groups, have enhanced resilience, strengthened capabilities, and access to decent work, resulting in full enjoyment of their rights contributing to the socio-economic and gender-transformative development of the country
Output: National and local policies, plans, budgets, and financing mechanisms are evidence-based and aligned to respond equitably to people’s needs in an inclusive, gender responsive and accountable manner.
Sub-Output: Duty bearers have capacities to create an enabling environment and safe spaces for inclusive and equal engagement of women, youth, and other rights holders’ groups affected by HIV, to advance EVAWG and women leadership
Description: Duty bearers have capacities to create an enabling environment and safe spaces for inclusive and equal engagement of women, youth, and other rights holders’ groups affected by HIV, to advance EVAWG and women leadership
Contributing partners: Core Funding, UNAIDS Unified Budget, Results and Accountability Framework
Implementation partners: Kyrgyz Civil Society Organizations, Kyrgyzstan Ministry of Health
SDG Targets: 5.c Adopt and strengthen sound policies and enforceable legislation for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls at all levels.
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Gender marker narrative: The sub-output’s focus on enhancing the capacity of local and national governmental agencies to understand gender aspects and addressing HIV challenges through collaborative activities. In addition, UNW will support the Country Coordinating Mechanism (CCM) in providing gender analysis for the country proposal to the Global Fund
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
LNOB groups targeted: Persons affected by chronic/long-term health conditions (e.g., HIV/AIDS, leprosy, diabetes, autoimmune disease, etc.)
2023 Narrative: During 2023, all provincial-level AIDS coordinating agencies (Osh, Jalalabad, Batken, Issyk-Kul, Talas, Naryn, Chui provinces and Bishkek) were capacitated in the area of gender in HIV. They strengthened their capacity to engage multiple stakeholders and define strategies for disseminating information using Participatory Design practices among peers. In addition, during the 16 days campaign against gender-based violence, jointly with the key population groups, these coordinating agencies initiated and implemented several advocacy activities to promote GEWE and tackle stigma and discrimination among a wider audience, reaching out to more than 1000 people, with the focus on youth, local authorities and women.
2024 Narrative: UN Women actively engaged with state HIV/AIDS Centers across the country enhancing their capacities to work with key population groups, including women living with HIV through organizing two staged GALS (Gender Action Learning System) trainings where 11 employees of state HIV/AIDS along with 24 non-state actors and civil activists underwent extensive learning program. These trainings heightened gender sensitivity of participants, strengthened commitment to gender justice, particularly for individuals living with HIV. Following the trainings AIDS Centers came up with various initiatives within the frame of the annual global 16 days of activism against GBV and World AIDS Day campaigns. Specifically, a Women Leaders Forum have been organized in Osh by AIDS Center which gathered above 80 participants, including youth and women living with HIV. Women leaders having expertise in different fields, including in law and legal practice, health and gynecology, mental health, yoga practice, entrepreneurship shared the most valuable information that empowered women living with HIV to pursue their professional goals, build self-confidence, reduce internalized stigma, and learn on how to protect themselves in cases of GBV. A quiz game was organized by Bishkek AIDS Center among public school teachers to enhance their awareness and knowledge on HIV disease and enable them to share this knowledge further among school students. The Head of the ME Unit of the National AIDS Center took part and shared valuable information, including latest statistics and major issues that the country faces with HIV prevention and response during the round table with religious leaders, where the role of religious leadership in HIV prevention and reduction of stigma and discrimination was discussed.

2021 Narrative:
Detailed Assessments on Budgetary Mechanisms for Allocating Funds to NGOs for 15 local self-governments prepared.

Research on Local Youth Policies for 15 local self-governments in Montenegro is in progress.

13 trainings for 56 staff from 15 LSG in Montenegro organized and participants trained on:
-	Project cycle management,
-	LOD Methodology for transparent allocation local public funds to NGOs,
-	Cooperation with NGOs,
-	Public relations and communicating project results.

ReLOaD 2 Public Calls for NGOs for two Clusters of municipalities (Tara: Pljevlja, Kolasin and Mojkovac, and Together for North: Berane and Andrijevica) prepared.


Detaljne analize o budžetskim mehanizmima za dodjelu sredstava NVO za 15 lokalnih samouprava pripremljene.
Istraživanje o lokalnim omladinskim politikama u 15 lokalnih samouprava u Crnoj Gori u toku.

Organizovano 13 obuka  za 56 lokalnih službenika iz 15 crnogorskih lokalnih samoupravu na teme:
-	Upravljanje projektnim ciklusom,
-	LOD Metodologija za transparentnu raspodjelu lokalnih javnih sredstava NVO,
-	Saradnja sa NVO,
-	Saradnja sa javnosti I predstavljanje rezultata projekta.
Pripremljena 2 ReLOaD2 Konkursa za klastere opština: Tara – Pljevlja, Kolašin I Mojkovac, I Zajedno za sjever: Berane I Andrijevica.
2022 Narrative: Assessments on exiting budgetary mechanisms for funding NGOs are prepared for 10 new municipalities, presented and comments introduced, while Royal Capital Cetinje adopted new municipal Decision on criteria for allocating fund to NGOs in line with recommendations. Five Public Calls and two re-launched Public Calls for NGOs were published by 5 clusters of municipalities (15 municipalities) and 42 NGOs contracted for implementation of their local Projects, One project is finalized. Around 1,118 (532 m and 586 f) Project beneficiaries were reached out in 14 municipalities, participating in various events, trainings, other project activities.Research on Local Youth perceptions and policies in 15 municipalities was finalized, presented to institutions at the central level and local institutions and organizations in 15 municipalities. Following findings and recommendations training and mentoring for youth on entrepreneurship and starting business was designed and implementation started (in 12 municipalities). Grant schemes for the first ReLOaD Public Call for recently established NGOs and NGOs working with youth, were designed, published and 13 Projects are under implementation.  Analiza postojećih budžetskih mehanizama za finansiranje NVO je finalizovana za 10 novih opština, prezentovana i komentari opština uvršteni, dok je Prijestonica Cetinje usvojila novu opštinsku Odluku o kriterijumima za raspodjelu sredstava NVO u skladu sa preporukama. Objavljeno je 5 Konkursa i dva ponovljena Konkursa od strane 5 klastera opština (15 opština) i ugovoreno 42 NVOa  za realzaciju lokalnih projekata. Jedan projekat je završen. Oko 1,118 (532 m i 586 ž) korisnika iz 15 opština je učestvovalo u projektnim aktivnostima kao što su: događaji. obuke, stale aktivnosti.Istraživanje o percepcijama i politikama za mlade u 15 lokalnih samouprava  je završeno, predstavljeno institucijama na nacionalnom nivou,i lokalnim institucijama i organizacijama u 15 opština.  Na osnovu nalaza i preporuka pripremljena je obuka i mentorska podrška mladima na temu preduzetništva i započinjanja biznisa i počelo se sa realizacijom u 12 opština.Grant šeme za NVO koje su tek osnovane ili se bave pitanjima mladih su kreirane, objavljene i 13 odabranih projekata se realizuje.

2021 Narrative: Model UNCAC conference for Masters degree students conducted on 24 Dec. 2021. The round table on civil AC initiatives held on Nov. 17, 2021. Business integrity forum held on Nov. 30, 2021.

Training on UNCAC IRM was delivered to CSO representatives in Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan.
2023 Narrative: In partnership with the Regional Dialogue, Anti-Corruption Agency, and Academy of Law Enforcement of Uzbekistan the 5th Model Conference of States Parties to the United Nations Convention Against Corruption Conference for students of Master of Law of Uzbek Universities organized on December 11, 2023. Over 60 students from 7 universities and academies gathered to practice their skills in reviewing and analyzing the implementation progress of Article 13 of the UNCAC based on the case of 7 countries.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, the UNODC youth-led initiative at the Law Enforcement Academy in Uzbekistan significantly expanded, transforming into a national Model CoSP platform.During this year's event, more than 80 students assumed the roles of UN delegates, engaging in substantive discussions related to the UNCAC’s Second Review Cycle. The focus was on Article 12, which addresses corruption prevention in the private sector. The debates provided a platform for participants to explore and propose strategies to enhance public-private partnerships, strengthen anti-corruption measures, and develop legislative reforms promoting transparency and justice.Looking ahead, UNODC aims to extend this initiative to a regional scale, enhancing youth participation in anti-corruption efforts across Central Asia.

SDG Targets: 17.18 By 2020, enhance capacity-building support to developing countries, including for least developed countries and small island developing States, to increase significantly the availability of high-quality, timely and reliable data disaggregated by income, gender, age, race, ethnicity, migratory status, disability, geographic location and other characteristics relevant in national contexts.,17.19 By 2030, build on existing initiatives to develop measurements of progress on sustainable development that complement gross domestic product, and support statistical capacity-building in developing countries.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: To advance gender equality, UNFPA applies gender disaggregation in all its research papers, data analysis and statistical publications related to the Census results, youth, older persons, persons with disabilities as well as on reproductive health and family planning. To ensure and advocate for gender mainstreaming in policy development, it is vital that gender disaggregation in data collection complimented with disaggregation on age, geography, level of education, access to health services, labor market etc.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
LNOB groups targeted: Older Persons, Youth, Persons With Disabilities
2023 Narrative: UNFPA supported the National Statistics Committee (NSC) to organize capacity building activities for all involved NSC staff in preparation for MICS 2023, supported presentations of first Census results to key stakeholders, and Census results dissemination activities.
2024 Narrative: As part of the initiative to enhance disability-related data systems in Kyrgyzstan, an Inter-agency working group (IWG), comprised of representatives from key government ministries and organizations, was established to develop a methodological note on disability data collection. The IWG’s primary objective is to design a framework for incorporating disability-related questions into administrative registers across various government ministries and agencies. The first step of the IWG was a preparation of the analysis to review existing data sources, identify gaps, and develop recommendations to improving the quality, consistency, and comprehensiveness of disability data collection. This analysis underscored the critical need for a unified methodology encompassing standardized definitions, harmonized indicators, and enhanced interagency collaboration to improve the quality and reliability of disability data. In addition, UNFPA jointly with the National Statistical Committee developed an Analytical Overview of Disability Issues that provides an in-depth analysis of disability data in the country derived from the 2022 Population and Housing Census of the Kyrgyz Republic and available official disability statistics. It offers a detailed analysis of disability prevalence, socio-economic characteristics, and trends, serving as a critical resource for policymakers, advocacy groups, and researchers.UNFPA jointly with the Resource center on elderly developed the first Active ageing index (AAI) that will serve as a key tool for monitoring and evaluation of the effectiveness of policies on ageing, as well as measuring the realization of potential of older persons in Kyrgyzstan.

SDG Targets: 3.1 By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.,4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,6.1 By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all.

2021 Narrative: During the 5 days Summer school in Almaty 35 medical universities' faculty and national experts were trained on organizing and providing quality youth-friendly health services.
2022 Narrative: The UNFPA CO played a pro-acitve role in providing technical expertise to the Ministry of Healthcare in developing national policies and standards to deliver quality youth friendly services.Two 60-hours training courses for postgraduate medical education on “Organizing and provision of YFSs” and “Providing social care services in YFCs” developed in 2021 were approved by the National Academic Council under the MoH on 27 May 2022.To start the roll-out of the approved curricula, the CO supported the strengthening capacity of 25 faculty staff members from national medical universities and 11 regional YFCs' coordinators during the Summer school on organizing and providing YFSs (22-26 August, Almaty).  Moreover, upon the request of the Department of healthcare of Abay region (the newly established region of Kazakhstan, earlier it used be a part of Eastern Kazakhstan Oblast), the UNFPA CO provided recommendations on establishing the regional network of YFCs and strengthened capacity of 51 health professionals on organizing and providing YFSs (24-25 November 2022).In addition, Kazakhstan's experience in the integration of youth-friendly health services into the UHC was promoted by the following global, regional, and sub-regional events:- the “Policy and legislative steps to advance adolescent health in Kazakhstan” implementation story was launched globally within WHO, and UNFPA organized a webinar (19 July) and published at the Learning by sharing portal (http://www.srhr.org/learn-uhc). - during the “Youth for Health” Health and Well-being Forum for Youth (25-27 October, Tirana, Albania) co-organized by EECARO and WHO Euro;- during “Positive pathways to change: Building stronger legal guarantees for sexual and reproductive health and rights’ a webinar organized by UNFPA EECARO and the Center for Reproductive Rights (29 November);- finally, the CO co-organized jointly with WHO Kazakhstan at the Central Asian Sub-regional conference “COVID-19 pandemic realities to brighten the spotlight on children’s and adolescents’ health” (12-13 December, Astana). Kazakhstan's experience in providing various YFSs was shared with 60 health professionals from the country’s YFCs, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, and Turkmenistan.
2023 Narrative: UNFPA contributed to the development of a new Standard on Youth Friendly Health Centres (YFCs) operation (a subsidiary legislative act, approved by the MoH in 2023). After the entry into force of this act, the State financing of the National Network for YFCs through the Social Health Insurance Fund amounted to 2.7 billion Kazakh Tenge (US$5.8 mln) in 2023 and contracted around 190 clinics that provide youth-friendly health services.In 2023, UNFPA supported four workshops, covering over 130 health professionals nationwide. Moreover, the CO had the chance to share Kazakhstan’s experience in organizing YFS, as an example of the “shifting from funding to financing” to Executive Director of UNFPA during the Global Leadership Meeting in Almaty (17 May 2023), and to Global Results Based Management Community (10 May 2023, online).
2024 Narrative: The CO made significant strides in advancing youth-friendly health services (YFHS) through a three-pronged approach: (i) supporting the development of regulations, (ii) capacity building, and (iii) advocacy and promotion.The CO contributed to developing a Standard for accrediting Youth-Friendly Health Centers and a Package of statistical reports to monitor these centers, laying the groundwork for standardized, quality YFHS.UNFPA continued to build the capacity of clinics to provide YFHS that meet international standards. This included a workshop for over 40 health professionals from the northern region and participation of national experts in the European Summer School on YFHS in Lisbon, Portugal.The "Shyn.kz" TikTok account saw remarkable growth, amassing over 211,800 followers and 2.6 million likes, with some videos exceeding 76 million views. This success earned the CO recognition from UNFPA HQ with the Digital Spotlight Award.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Support national efforts to respond to people’s needs by ensuring equitable access to quality social services including education, health, social protection and decent work through effective policies and appropriate financing mechanisms with the participation of all parties (QUALITY SOCIAL SERVICES)
Outcome: By 2027, the people of the Kyrgyz Republic, particularly vulnerable groups, have enhanced resilience, strengthened capabilities, and access to decent work, resulting in full enjoyment of their rights contributing to the socio-economic and gender-transformative development of the country
Output: National and local policies, plans, budgets, and financing mechanisms are evidence-based and aligned to respond equitably to people’s needs in an inclusive, gender responsive and accountable manner.
Sub-Output: Youth policy implementation contributing to youth empowerment and  participation at all levels and ensuring healthy environment supported
Contributing partners: Core Funding
Implementation partners: 100%LIFE - Kharkiv, Kyrgyz Ministry of Culture, Information, Sports and Youth Policy
SDG Targets: 8.6 By 2020, substantially reduce the proportion of youth not in employment, education or training.,16.7 Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
SDG Goals: 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth, 16 Peace and Justice - Strong Institutions
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: To advance gender equality, youth policy implementation empowers girls and young women to actively participate in decision-making, implementation, and engagement, ensuring their voices are heard and valued. The results will be captured through the programme’s M&E framework.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: Youth Advisory Board (YAB) was established consisting of 12 young people, representing diverse backgrounds, including from various ethnic groups, geographical locations, and individuals with disabilities. The YAB serves as a platform to amplify the voices of young people within UN programming. UNFPA with support of other UN agencies organized capacity-building sessions for the YAB members, focusing on key principles such as social cohesion, leaving no one behind, do no harm, effective communication, and child safeguarding.UNFPA provided support to the Ministry of Culture, Information, Sports, and Youth Policy (MCISYP) to enhance coordination efforts with development agencies, including UN Agencies, to promote youth policies. By facilitating collaboration among stakeholders, UNFPA aims to strengthen initiatives that foster inclusivity, respect for diversity, and the promotion of peaceful coexistence among young people. As a result 3 Advisory Committee meetings were organized; priority areas and responsible development partners identified. More than 500 young people participated in Youth events organized by MCISYP.
2024 Narrative: UNFPA within the UN Youth Thematic Group, in collaboration with the Ministry of Culture, Information, Sports, and Youth Policy (MCISYP) achieved significant progress in empowering youth and advancing their engagement in national and global initiatives such as creation of a Youth movement of Kyrgyzstan, development of the National Action Plan 2024-2027 for implementing UN Resolution 2250 on Youth, Peace, and Security, development of the legislative frameworks under the Law on volunteerism and many other. In addition, UNFPA supported the work of the UN Youth Advisory Board that provided inputs into the UN Common Country Analysis document on youth mainstreaming and participated in different national UN events.

Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1 - Pillar 1 Sustainable economic growth, environment and employment.
Outcome: Outcome 1.1 - By 2022, all women and men, especially young people, equally benefit from an enabling environment that includes labour market, access to decent jobs and economic opportunities
Output: Output 1.1.3 - Government and other stakeholder are equipped with knowledge and skills for gender responsive policies on investment, trade and employment.
Sub-Output: 1.1.3.5 - Enhance tripartite social dialogue and collective bargaining as means to create more and better jobs, especially for youth
Description: The social dialogue outcome will be pursued through a combination of well tested approaches and tools in relation to strengthening of the capacity employers’ and workers’ organizations to become overall more efficient and effective, to better represent and service their members, to engage in collective bargaining and to contribute constructively to national and local economic and labour policy making; and to the improved functioning and effectiveness of tripartite social dialogue bodies at both national and local level.
Contributing partners: Government of Denmark
Implementation partners: Confederation of Free Trade Unions of Ukraine, Federation of Trade Unions of Ukraine, Federation of Ukrainian Employers, Ministry of Social Policy of Ukraine, National Tripartite Social and Economic Council
SDG Targets: 8.3 Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.
2021 Narrative:
ILO is continuously providing support at all levels of social dialogue to promote collective bargaining and improve the concluded collective agreements. In particularly this encompasses including the specific provisions, related to occupational safety and health at work, salary increase, incentive schemes, annual and other types of leave etc. While quality of existing workplaces is regulated by national legislative framework and collective agreements, creation of new jobs is also covered by sectorial and general agreements, as well as by other forms of cooperation and social dialogue. ILO is continuously providing its support to strengthen tripartite cooperation within the National Tripartite Social and Economic Council (e.g. capacity development, contribution to the working groups, policy advice etc). 
National Tripartite Socio-Economic Council provided with a self-assessment method for social dialogue institutions (SAM-SDI). This is a tool, developed by ILO, to enable members of social dialogue institutions to undertake an in-depth self-assessment and devise an action plan to enhance its inclusiveness and effectiveness
Ad-hoc verbal comments provided to the Draft Law of Ukraine “On Collective Contracts and Agreements” with ref to C 98, 154 during the Working Group under NTSEC working group. 
67 trade unionist and employers` representatives from 5 pilot sectors (maritime transport; agriculture; services; construction and metallurgy) were trained on effective skills for collective bargaining (54% women); 
Training curriculum "Mediation in the settlement of collective labor disputes" for the 3-day training course of mediators, involved into amicable solution of collective labour disputes developed, based on the ILO ITC methodology; 5 active trainers from the National Service of Mediation and Conciliation (NSMC) rolled out 4 regional mediation trainings for 87 mediators from NSMC (49 women and 38 men); 
The workgroup prepared the draft law On Collective Labour Disputes following recommendations of the ILO Study “Assessment of the system of extra-judicial resolution of individual and collective labour disputes” facilitated.
ILO provided technical comments to the draft law On Collective Bargaining presented.

2023 Narrative: OHCHR established a Network of CSOs and conducted four workshops enhancing the networking between 42+ CSOs, human rights activists and independent journalists from both banks of Nistru/Dniester river with the goal to enhance future cooperation between them on advancing human rights. Advocacy activities were preliminary discussed and will be rolled out in 2024. Additionally, the knowledge of civil society on interaction with UN Treaty Bodies was increased with a focus on alternative reporting. Joint reporting by CSOs from the left bank and the right bank of Nistru/Dniester River was encouraged.Three regional advocacy groups established by OHCHR through five practical workshops were empowered in developing three regional advocacy plans for promoting HRBA to disability in their respective regions. The advocacy plans will be implemented in 2024.

2022 Narrative: ILO: North Macedonia endorsed, in July 2021, the Western Balkans Declaration on ensuring sustainable labour market integration of young people (15-29) and committed to taking steps to further enhance the implementation of the national Youth Guarantee and align its delivery to the principles set forth in the Council Recommendation on A Bridge to Jobs - Reinforcing the Youth Guarantee (2020). The commitment to promote youth employment and reduce labour market detachment reflects the policy priorities that have been pursued by North Macedonia since 2018, when the Youth Guarantee – modelled on the European Union one - was piloted in the country and then rolled out nation-wide the following year. 20185 (10316 women) persons registered with the Youth Guarantee in 2022, out of which 7419 (3595 women) got employed within 4 months of registration. Rate of the successful exit from the YG (Percentage of participants who successfully completed the Youth Guarantee) in 2022 was 43%.ILO/ EU supported Youth Guarantee Implementation Plan (YGIP)of North Macedonia for the period 2022-2026 builds on the lessons learnt since 2018 and the principles set forth in the Council Recommendation on A Bridge to Jobs – Reinforcing the Youth Guarantee (October 2020). Compared to the previous YG implementation plans, in the period 2022-2026 more emphasis will be placed on: (i) reaching out to detached young people where they mostly live, (ii) improving the quality of offers provided to young people registering in the YG service delivery system; (iii) establishing wider and better partnerships with other governmental and non-governmental actors, and (iv) building a stronger service delivery system.The YG delivery mechanism is expected to improve through: (i) the revision of organizational structure, staffing levels and funding envelope of the Employment Service Agency at the central, regional and local level; (ii) the expansion of preparation services (to include the validation non-formal and informal learning and outsourced employability courses) and subsidized offers of employment, continued education and training and traineeship; (iii) the strengthening of the Education Management of Information System (EMIS) and the increase of offer of adult education courses; (iv) the expansion of outreach activities and the progressive shift of tasks to municipal Youth Centres; and (v) data pooling mechanisms to allow the sharing of information across public institutions about young people (ESA, education, social security, tax authority, youth organizations, etc.).UNESCO: During 2022 UNESCO, as lead partner, together with the British Council and the Italian agency for Development Cooperation, launched the implementation of the EU-funded project Culture and Creativity for the Western Balkans, which includes North Macedonia among its beneficiaries. The project aims at promoting inclusive, fair and sustainable socio-economic development in WBs IPA Beneficiaries, and to improve reconciliation and good neighbourly relations in the region. Main thematic areas of intervention will be cultural heritage, intercultural dialogue, and creativity. The project will offer a systemic, effective and viable approach to enable progress across governance, policy and operational frameworks, by combining advice for policy improvement with data for informed decision-making, capacity-building, support to public-private partnerships, networking and funding opportunities for cultural and creative actors.﻿One of the core activities during the Regional Project’s inception phase was the launch of a comprehensive desk research aimed at mapping cultural and creative sectors in the Western Balkans IPA Beneficiaries, covering existing data and statistics, national and international legal frameworks as well as key strategic documents, cultural governance structures and relevant competences, main cultural heritage sites and elements, along with prominent cultural projects, events and activities. Collected information is being organised and presented in “Beneficiary files“.The members of the Advisory Committee were officially appointed and the Committee’s Terms of Reference approved, together with the updated Project’s Workplan, Logical Framework, Visual Identity, and Inception Report. UNDP:During 2022, through different UN initiatives and support services, 5,351 unemployed where activated in the labour market out of which 3,717 (69.5%) where young unemployed with 2.400 NEET. 339 young people received various trainings in future skills in key industries or got required skills as per employer’s needs. UN supported the Employment Service Agency in implementation of the Youth Guarantee. Through two youth umbrella NGOs (engaged over 60 young field workers) to support ESA’s Employment Centers in identifying and registering young NEET. With the support, over 5,000 young unemployed and over 1.140 private companies were informed about Youth Guarantee scheme in ESA. Out of 5,000 informed young, 2,400 NEET were registered in ESA’s data base (1,553 women; 6 persons with disabilities; and 193 Roma). With UN support, in 2022 total 404 jobs were created for young unemployed (282 full-time and 122 part-time).
2023 Narrative: ILO: Following the Declaration on ensuring sustainable labour market integration of young people, signed on 8 July 2021 at the second EU-Western Balkans Ministerial Meeting on Employment and Social Affairs, in April 2023, at its 142nd session the Government of North Macedonia adopted a new Youth Guarantee Implementation Plan (Act 41-1199/10, of 5 April 2023), which is now in line with the principles enshrined in the EU Council Recommendation of 30 October 2020 on A Bridge to Jobs – Reinforcing the Youth Guarantee. Among the innovations introduced is the application by the Employment Service Agency (ESA) of a youth-specific statistical profile model for client segmentation. In North Macedonia, institutions and organizations involved in the implementation of the youth guarantee have relied significantly on the ILO's facilitation of peer-learning and triangular cooperation with other public employment services from the region and from the EU.UNESCO: See sub-output 1.1.4.1.
2024 Narrative: UNDP:In 2024, the UN implemented targeted interventions to support youth employment, skills development, and labour market activation, with a particular focus on NEET youth. Through the Youth Guarantee initiative, 2,203 NEET youth benefitted from activation services, with 59% (1,299) being women. Dedicated youth coordinators played a key role in engaging young people, facilitating their transition into employment, education, or training.In parallel, tailored skills development programmes strengthened youth employability, equipping them with the necessary competencies to navigate the evolving labour market. A total of 2,300 unemployed individuals, including a significant number of young people, participated in business skills development and entrepreneurship training, leading to successful business creation and economic independence for many participants. Additionally, 385 individuals received specialized training to enhance their competitiveness in the job market.Employment outcomes for youth were further reinforced through active labour market measures (ALMMs), which contributed to the creation of 285 jobs for young people under 29 (159 full-time, 126 part-time). The integration of youth into the workforce was supported by youth (field) coordinators, who facilitated the activation of 505 NEET Roma youth, contributing to inclusive labour market participation.By leveraging targeted activation services, skills development programs, and inclusive employment measures, the UN continued to drive youth labour market participation, ensuring that young people, particularly those from vulnerable backgrounds, have access to meaningful economic opportunities.ILO:Phase II and Phase III of the EU-ILO Youth Guarantee Technical Assistance Facility continued to facilitate the labour market integration of unemployed and disengaged young women and men in N. Macedonia, in a systemic manner, through the implementation of the Youth Guarantee. The ILO supported the enhancement of the framework conditions and institutional capacities requisite for the implementation of the Youth Guarantee, through tailor-made technical guidance, recommendations, and capacity support. In this light, in 2024, the ILO focused on systematic support to the Employment Service Agency to enhance its functional organization; initiate a reform of the guiding legislation, which will enable modernization and digitalization of its services; reduce the deadweight through enhanced profiling of the unemployed persons and focusing the human and financial resources on the persons at greater risk of becoming long-term unemployed; improve the classification of employment services and ALMPs in line with the EU standards; adapt the ALMPs in the following years based on the cost-effectiveness. Additionally, the ILO facilitated 4 peer-learning events and exchanges of good practices among institutions involved in the design and implementation of the YG from the Western Balkans and EU Member States. It also facilitated the functioning of the regional Network of YG Coordinators, through organization of networking activities, aimed at strengthening institutional capacity via exchange of knowledge, information, and good practices. Main interventions:﻿Development and validation of the National Employment Action Plan 2024-2027 -Training of all ESA councillors on the use and interpretation of the statistical profiling modelThematic Youth Guarantee website with a Knowledge Repository -Thematic peer-learning events and training workshops for the representatives of the Ministry of Economy and Labour and of the Employment Service Agency involved in the Youth Guarantee implementation (Minimum standards and good practices for outreach to inactive NEETs; Quality standards for employment services and programmes; Performance monitoring of the Youth Guarantee; Collecting data and information to monitor Youth Guarantee Implementation Plans; Classification of services and ALMPs) In 2024, 14,394 young people (15-29) were employed through the Youth Guarantee scheme in 2024. 7,323 of them were women

2021 Narrative:
"Among all UNDP interventions, youth projects have a bigger dividend in strengthening social cohesion than those projects where the age group of beneficiaries are higher. Innovative schemes such as boot-camps, SDG hackathons that UNDP utilizes frequently to bring SuTP and Host community (HC) youth together can contribute to changing perceptions of young people at an early age when prejudices are easier to destroy. In this vein, in 2021 alone, UNDP brought together 1490 members of SuTP and HC youth in activities as diverse as ICT trainings, Hackathons, Mentorship, Social Cohesion and volunteering of which 645 are Syrians and 897 are women (both Turkish and Syrian) (EV ).
Additionally, in order to improve public sector capacities to promote social cohesion, UNDP trained 98 Youth Center Staff and Youth Volunteers of Ministry of Youth and Sports. The staff and volunteers organized Social Cohesion Festivals in Ankara, Bursa, Kocaeli, İstanbul and Şanlıurfa. 62% of the trained youth and youth center staff was women. Hardware improvements were made for computer classrooms in 30 Youth Centers in nine provinces (Ankara, Kayseri, Şanlıurfa, Hatay, Adana, Mersin, Kocaeli, Bursa and İstanbul) so that the Ministry is better able to reach Syrian and Turkish youth to improve their ICT skills. The project procured and delivered equipment worth a total of US $680.000 to establish state-of-the-art computer classrooms in 30 Youth Centers. A technology Hackathon was organized with the participation of  72 SuTPs and HCs in 5 provinces to give a chance to create tech-based solutions to social cohesion problems. Four solutions that were prized included an online platform for increasing access of Syrian and Turkish Youth to employment, a mobile application that will make it easier for Turkish and Syrian youth living in close neighbourhoods to get to know each other and organize sports events, a software that displays trainings and cartoons with VR technology to children and an online application where Syrian and Turkish youth can play games together and match with each other in e-sports activities."

2023 Narrative: UNICEF continued to promote engagement of children and adolescents in issues related to climate change. UNICEF continued its cooperation with the Republican Centre of Ecology and supported advocacy roundtables (ART) for projects developed during the 2022 Eco-Marathon. 89 adolescents and specialists participated in the ART, presenting results of their projects and proposing sustainability plans with local authorities, experts and companies. The climate change agenda also gained momentum through partnership with the online retailer, 21vek.by, that led to a social media initiative with volunteers promoting eco-friendly habits, reaching approximately 500,000 people (77.6% female; 11% children and young people) and demonstrating the power of collaborative efforts in environmental advocacy.UNICEF supported participation of an SDG Youth Ambassador Alternate as an official Belarus delegate member in the COP28, sharing her experiences and ideas in social media posts and live broadcasting from the event. The COP28 adolescent delegate drafted suggestions for amendments addressing climate issues for children to Belarus’ National Law on Child Rights which were presented at the National Child and Adolescent-Friendly Cities Forum in November 2023 attended by more than 150 participants from Adolescent Parliaments, Executive Committees, and representatives of the Ministry of Education.

resources.

In 2021 WFP implemented a project that offers smallholder farmers in the rural farming community of Tegh (Syunik) to increase agricultural production through an approach that is economically self-sustaining, climate sensitive, and community led.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2023 – 2027
