Output: OU 2.3_People of Moldova, in particular most vulnerable and marginalized, are empowered to claim and exercise their human rights and meaningfully participate in public and civic life, governance and decision-making processes
Sub-Output: (UN WOMEN) Provide support to advance gender equality and women’s leadership for women aspirants and candidates in political life and diplomacy and diverse networks of women activists at national and local levels (including youth and under-represented groups
Description:
2023
At least 300 women aspirants and candidates for 2023 local elections (including young and under-represented) increased their capacities as result of their participation in a comprehensive pre-electoral training program
At least 25 national experts are able to deliver trainings on women’s political leadership as a result of tot training of trainers on political leadership & candidate training in Moldova based on UN WOMEN’s curriculum
Up to 25 MFAEI leadership representatives and women diplomats have increased leadership skills and capacities to contribute at building a gender sensitive, equitable and inclusive institutional culture. 
1 (one) analytical research on election monitoring from gender perspective in partnership with civil society organizations and women's leadership platforms developed and launched
Support Gender Equality Platform to continue advance a common gender equality agenda and represent women’s leadership voice.

2024
At least 50 women aspirants and candidates for 2025 parliamentarian elections (including young and under-represented) increased their capacities as result of their participation in a comprehensive pre-electoral training program
Support for more than 150 elected women during 2023 Local Elections with post electoral support and networks to became effective local leaders in their communities
Support Gender Equality Platform to continue advance a common gender equality agenda and represent women’s leadership voice.
Support for Women Roma Networks to advocate for their rights and advance Gender Equality 
At least 50 youth leaders and activists with increased awareness and involvement are able to advocate for Gender Equality as a result of their gathering at the Generation Equality: Youth in Action event dedicated to International Youth day.
At least 25 women from Middle-Senior Management from non-traditional sectors will increase their knowledge, leadership and management in their institution as a result of a comprehensive Leadership Development, Mentorship, and Coaching Program
12 members of AYAP have increased knowledge about Gender Equality as a result of series of session of basic and advance notions of Gender Equality, leadership and Harassment 

2025
At least 200 women aspirants and candidates for 2025 parliamentarian elections (including young and under-represented), including 50 women aspirants for elections in ATU Gagauzia increased their capacities as result of their participation in a comprehensive pre-electoral training program
Support Gender Equality Platform to continue advance a common gender equality agenda and represent women’s leadership voice.
Support for Women Roma Networks to advocate for their rights and advance Gender Equality 
At least 10 youth leaders and activists with increased awareness and involvement are able to advocate for Gender Equality as a result of their gathering at various event dedicated to International Youth day.
At least 12  local Civil Society Organizations, citizens and women’s groups are more engaged in the design, implementation and monitoring of gender sensitive local projects along with Local Public Authorities.
More than 100 women leaders are more empowerment to be civically active as a result of leadership and mentorship program dedicated for women civil society local leaders, including in Gagauzia, to enable women’s socio-economic agency and challenging of social norms.
Support small women-led initiatives, including in Gagauzia region to promote dialogue and socio- and economic empowerment of women.
Contributing partners: Danish International Development Agency, Government of Sweden, Swedish International Development Agency, Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation
Implementation partners: Centre "Partnership for Development", Gender Equality Platform, Institutum Virtutes Civilis, Moldova Ministry of External Affairs and European Integration, Roma Women’s Platform “ROMNI” Moldova, UN Women
SDG Targets: 5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.,17.18 By 2020, enhance capacity-building support to developing countries, including for least developed countries and small island developing States, to increase significantly the availability of high-quality, timely and reliable data disaggregated by income, gender, age, race, ethnicity, migratory status, disability, geographic location and other characteristics relevant in national contexts.
SDG Goals: 5 Gender Equality, 17 Partnerships for the Goals
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Gender marker narrative: GEWE as the principal objective of the current sub-output having targeted beneficiaries, such as women and under representative groups
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: The sub-output seeking to realize human rights via empowering most vulnerable groups
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: UN Women entered a comprehensive 3- year Partnership with Institutum Virtutes Civilis to advance leadership for women aspirants and candidates in political life and diplomacy. The Partnership “Women in Leadership and Good Governance” will last from June 13, 2023 - till November 30, 2025, aiming to enhance capacities of 650 candidates for next electoral cycles based on standardized and accredited UN Women’s Political Leadership and Candidate Training Curriculum. 25 local women experts (10 youth, 1 woman with disability, and 1 Roma woman) improved their abilities, skills, and knowledge as trainers of trainers to deliver capacity building sessions for women aspirants and candidates in political life on standardized and accredited UN Women’s Political Leadership and Candidate Training Curriculum. This was a result of TOT (28 June - 2 July 2023) organized by UN Women partners and funded by the Women in Politics Fund (Sweden Fund). The topics included gender equality, leadership, political participation, elections, voter campaigns, fundraising, civic engagement, etcPre-electoral support within 2023 Local Elections301 women aspirants and candidates for 2023 Local Elections (11 with disabilities, 5 women, 55 youth) have increased their knowledge and enhanced their confidence to run for election as a result of participation in 10 four-days trainings organized by UN Women’s partner IVC, based on UN Women's Curriculum and funded by Sweden and Women in Politics Fund. As per post evaluation, the percentage of women who wanted to run for local elections reached 80% (248) at the end of the training’s comparative with 60,4% identified at the beginning of the training sessions. Out of a total of 301 women trained, 146 ran for office and 81 were elected (i.e. 55% of the trained women candidates who stood for elections, and 27% of the total women trained).Post-electoral support within 2023 Local Elections47 elected women after 2023 local election (39 rural, 8 urban, 1 disabilities, 8 youth) have enhanced capacities (23.94%) to exercise leadership and apply gender mainstreaming at local level, as a result of first 2 days session out of 4. The participants were 18 mayors, 1 vice-mayor, 23 local councilors, 2 district councilors and 3 municipal councilors.2023 Local Election monitored from gender perspective. 3 reports related to 2023 local elections monitoring process from a gender perspective have been released, by UN Women Partner and Sweden funding, namely:(a) Report -population's perceptions of gender roles in the decision-making process (press release);(b) Report - representation of women and men in elective positions at the level of town halls (online press conference).(c) Report - representation of women and men in the position of councilor (online press conference).Support for Women's Diplomat Network to advance Gender Equality Agenda:37 MFAEI representatives (33 women and 4 men) enhanced their knowledge on gender sensitive foreign policies, understand better their leadership and role as women diplomats in advancing Gender Equality and their work life balance as a result of 2 networking events for MFAEI representatives conducted on 27 October (12 women) and 08 November 2023 (25 women). This activity has been organized under UN Women partnership with Institutum Virtutes Civilis under Goverment Offices of Sweden, represented by the Ministry for Foreign Affairs.6 MFAEI representatives (4 women, 2 men) enhanced their knowledge and experience in the field of gender integration in the foreign policy as a result to a Study visit to French authorities during reporting period. This activity has been organized under UN Women partnership with Institutum Virtutes Civilis under Goverment Offices of Sweden, represented by the Ministry for Foreign Affairs.Support to Roma WomenThe public at large, as well as parliament representatives, the government, the international community, and CSOs have gained increased awareness on inclusiveness towards the Roma community as promoters of change after a March called "Roma Woman here and now. Know Me and accept Me" and a Dialogue event organized on April 3, 2023, by the Roma Women Platform "Romni" in partnership with UN Women and financial support from Swiss Development Cooperation on the occasion of International Roma day. The Women CAUCUS and Gender Equality Platform strengthened their partnership to advance the gender equality Agenda following discussions on October 3, 2023, where were identified the best practices, policies, and initiatives for enhancing the normative framework. This initiative is part of the UN Women - UN Joint Project funded by Sweden.
2024 Narrative: Pre-electoral support within 2023 Local Elections 58 women, including 8 youth, have developed essential skills to participate confidently in the 2025 Parliamentary Elections, fostering leadership and understanding governance processes as a result of attendance at first edition of an intensive pre-electoral training course, organized during 12-13 December 2024 by UN Women’s partner with Sweden funding.Post-electoral support within 2023 Local Elections 157 elected women mayors and councillors after 2023 local elections (29 youth, 5 disabilities, 38 urban, 119 rural), received post-electoral support and enhanced their knowledge about the gender sensitive governance, budget and strategic planning, public policies, and decisional process as a result of last 3 2-day sessions. The event was organized under UN Women partnership and funded by Sweden. FB Posts: [0] [1] [2] [3] [4]70 mayors and councillors elected after 2023 local elections (18 youth, 2 with disabilities, 17 urban and 53 rural) have been equipped with essential knowledge to ensure fair access to quality public services for the citizens in their localities as a result of the first networking event held on March 28, 2024. The event organized under Partnership with IVC and Sweden funding.75 locally elected women and those in leadership or executive positions in local public administration improved their knowledge in public procurement after second networking event, held on September 24, 2024 organized by partners with Sweden funding. 95.32% of attendees reported an increase in knowledge.78 central and local officials (71 women, 7 men, 21 youth) from diverse sectors (government, local councils, police, healthcare, social assistance, psychology, media and civil society) strengthened their cooperation and problem-solving capacities to prevent gender-based violence as a result of the 3rd networking event “Consolidating Solidarity and Social Cooperation Against Gender-Based Violence”. Organized on November 8, 2024 by a UN Women partner as part of the 16 Days, the event focused on overcoming barriers, supporting victims and fostering local cooperation. Over 92% of participants found it highly relevant.Women aspirants, leaders, candidates and elected have access to a highly qualitative translated version into Romanian of the UN Women Political Leadership and Candidate Training Manual and Handbook with support of UN Women partnership under Sweden funds.The public at large is now more aware of women’s rights, gender equality and sexual exploitation as a result of various awareness and advocacy activities organized by the Gender Equality Platform within the 10th Edition of the Feminist Festival supported by UN Women and funded by Sweden.International community was driven by motivational speech of a local woman councilor with a disability from Moldova following her speech at an international EDF conference on March 1, 2024, which gathered 73 leaders and activists. Her participation was possible with support of Sweden. A manifesto that promotes the empowerment of women with disabilities in elections has been approved.20 women mayors exchanged experiences with other local communities and were inspired to better connect their communities through cultural events in the IProsop Festival organized by Selemet Village, which is led by a woman.During the "Generation Equality: Youth in Action" event marking International Youth Day, more than 50 young men and women, including roma and people with disabilities, joined discussions of positive examples of youth leadership, activism and entrepreneurship, as well as best practices for youth-led non-governmental organizations. The event aimed to empower young women and men through an integrated approach, focusing on changing social norms, supporting public policy changes, promoting girls' leadership and amplifying the voices of youth in society. The event was organized by UN Women funded by Sweden.Public at large are aware about youth activism in difference fields due to 3 videos launched after the "Generation Equality: Youth in Action" event marking International Youth Day funded Sweden support. [1] [2] [3]Over 300 youth increased their awareness of gender equality through UN Women's thematic corner at the Youth Festival in Chisinau. The event emphasized the importance of engaging young people in breaking gender stereotypes to build an inclusive society. Organized by the National Youth Council of Moldova, the festival was supported by UN Women with funding from Sweden and Japan.More than 200 women leaders from across the country were inspired and deepened their understanding of women's influence in politics, local development and peacebuilding because of a dedicated panel discussion during the Moldovan Women's Forum, held on November 30, 2024. The panel had as members active women leaders from the Romanian Parliament, UN Women, UNESCO, and civil society and charity organizations.Roma women and girls, including refugees, have become more confident to be agents of change to combat deeply rooted stereotypes in society and encourage others from Roma community to be more vocal as a result of the March Event organized by UN Women partners under NatComs and Sweden Funds. The event was followed by a workshop organized for kids within the Roma Music Evening.﻿19 women in leadership positions from the Government of the Republic of Moldova (including ministers and state secretaries) and the diplomatic community exchanged their experience-sharing as a result of their participation in a safe and informal networking event organized on December 11, 2024 aiming to develop a partnership-building among both communities by addressing common challenges exploring common challenges and opportunities to advance gender equality and women's leadership in public and diplomatic spheres. The event was organized by UN Women with Danish and Sweden Funds.

Description: Supporting  advocacy for strengthening advancing gender equality and  youth agenda, strenghthen GBV response  against women,  girls and target group at high risk of HIV/AIDS(UNJP4GE)
Contributing partners: United Nations Population Fund
Implementation partners: Gender Equality Council of the Parliament, Georgia National Center for Disease Control, Inter-Agency Commission on Gender Equality, Violence against Women and Domestic Violence Issues , Ministry of Internally Displaced Persons from the Occupied Territories, Labour, Health and Social Affairs of Georgia, Public Defender of Georgia, The Youth Agency of Georgia

LNOB groups targeted: Women & Girls, Youth, LGBTI persons (sexual orientation and gender identity)
2021 Narrative:
UNFPA as the chair of the UN Thematic Group on Youth coordinated the youth development agenda at the national level and provided TA to the Youth Agency in development of the National Youth Action Plan 2022-2023 with its costing and M&E tools in line with the National Youth Strategy 2025.
UNFPA has prepared amendments to the SOP on the healthcare system response to VAW/GBV to reflect specific needs of the LGBTQI community and women with disabilities while identifying, reporting, and referring cases of GBV/VAW. The document encompasses special provisions to ensure rights-based approach throughout the process. The document was submitted to the Ministry of Health for its consideration. UNFPA will further continue cooperation with the MoH to approve the SOP and make it mandatory nationwide
2022 Narrative: 1. UNFPA, as the chair of the UN TG on Youth (UNDP, UNICEF, UNHCR, ILO) continued to provide technical support for establishing a strong policy framework on Youth development. In 2022 the National Youth Strategy 2023-2026 and the annual Action Plan have been finalized and adopted by the Government of Georgia (Decree N 606). UNFPA supported Sports and Youth Issues Committee of the Parliament of Georgia to develop a package and framework for legislative reforms for the youth agenda related to priorities and legal obligations stipulated in the National Youth Policy, National SDG agenda, EU Youth Strategy and commitments under the EU Association Agreement to ensure that youth ecosystem of Georgia is fully aligned with the EU standards and best practices.2. In consultations with the relevant civil society organizations working on the rights of the LGBTQI community and women with disabilities, UNFPA revised the Standard Operational Procedures on Healthcare System Response to GBV/VAW. The exercise aimed to ensure the compliance with the principle of LNOB and reflect specific needs of the LGBTQ+ people and WwDs in it. The SOP was discussed with the representatives of the Ministry of Health and officially submitted to the Ministry for approval. Moreover, the online training module on Healthcare System Response to GBV/VAW has been amended following the requirements of the new SOP. Experts added relevant information and tests in the module to ensure alignment of the training module with the SOP. 60 medical professionals have trained on the issues considered in the SOP regarding detection, prevention and response to GBV/VAW among KPs at high risk of HIV, also considering the SOGI issues.
2023 Narrative: 1. UNFPA, as the chair of the UN TG on Youth (UNDP, UNICEF, UNHCR, ) continued to provide technical support for establishing a strong policy framework on Youth development. In 2023 the National Youth Strategy 2023-2026 and the annual Action Plan 2023 have been finalized and adopted by the Government of Georgia (Decree N 606). UNFPA supported Sports and Youth Issues Committee of the Parliament of Georgia to develop a package and framework for legislative reforms for the youth agenda related to priorities and legal obligations stipulated in the National Youth Policy, National SDG agenda, EU Youth Strategy and commitments under the EU Association Agreement to ensure that youth ecosystem of Georgia is fully aligned with the EU standards and best practices.2. In consultations with the relevant civil society organizations working on the rights of the LGBTQI community and women with disabilities, UNFPA revised the Standard Operational Procedures on Healthcare System Response to GBV/VAW and as per request of the MOH it has been converted as protocol.  The SOP was discussed with the representatives of the Ministry of Health and officially submitted to the Ministry for approval. Moreover, the online training module on Healthcare System Response to GBV/VAW has been amended following the requirements of the new SOP. Experts added relevant information and tests in the module to ensure alignment of the training module with the SOP. 160 medical professionals have trained on the issues considered in the SOP regarding detection, prevention and response to GBV/VAW among KPs at high risk of HIV, also considering the SOGI issues and on Stigma and discriminations as per the updated online accredited course at TSMU on HIV/SRHR and SD.
2024 Narrative: UNFPA in its capacity as the chair of Youth TG and HIV/AIDs group played a crucial role in shaping the youth empowerment agenda in the country and well as providing TA in HIV prevention and developing the GFATM country response n response to the National HIV Strategic Plan 2023-2026 and State Youth Strategy 2023-206. TA was provided to the Youth Agency to conduct a National Forum, an event that brought together members of youth advisory councils and municipal youth councils’ coordinators (200 participants) from 30 municipalities across Georgia with the primary aim to enhance the leadership capabilities of young people in the regions and foster collaboration among different governmental stakeholders. The forum also focused on equipping coordinators with the necessary skills and knowledge to effectively manage the councils, ensuring that youth participation in decision-making is systematic, inclusive, and impactful.

This resulted in empowered Youth to address youth challenges and develop youth-driven solutions for a drug-free future

Civil society, media and public oversight institutions have strengthened their awareness, knowledge and skills on human rights, access to justice and legal aid, and are empowered to use them and prevent any human rights violations, violence, and all forms of discriminatory practices
2021 Narrative: Throughout 2021, UNODC was involved in arranging and organizing of several campaigns, which include Model UN among universities and schools, World Drug Day, Anticorruption day, AIDS day, Anti-human Trafficking day, 16 days of activism on GBV and others. All these campaigns were broadcasted by existing and new media partners. In addition to previously partnered, 10 additional media partners were engaged in 2021, including printed media: Narodnoe Slovo, Mahalla, Yoshlar Ovozi, Uchitel Uzbekistana, Xalq So'zi, Ma'rifat, Jamiyat, Biznes Novosti, Pravda Vostoka, and Sevimli TV channel, and several internet-based platforms.
2022 Narrative: UNODC either conducted or was involved in the organization of several awareness-raising campaigns in 2022 devoted to different international days. Specifically, a series of events were conducted on International Women's Day, World Drug Day, Antihuman Trafficking Day, Nelson Mandella Day, Anticorruption Day, World AIDS day, 16 days of activism, and others with involvement of media and civil society, youth, and vulnerable groups of the population. Such campaigns contributed to the increase of awareness and enhancement of access to justice, human rights, crime prevention and prevention of violence, TIP, GBV, corruption, counternarcotics, and other relevant topics.UNAIDS supported civil society organizations and communities of people living with HIV in implementation of activities within the World AIDS day. Several information sessions for young people were organized. After the information session with UN Youth Advisory Board, the YAB members used UNAIDS developed materials to do the same session in the regions. During 2022 successful partnership was build with Subyektiv media. Several videos were created and broadcasted through different channels. Main theme of the videos is creation and promotion of stigma and discrimination free environment. The heroes of these videos are young people living with HIV.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, UNODC was involved in marking of several international days, including World Drug Day, Anticorruption Day, World Day Against Trafficking in Persons, International Women's Day with involvement of media, civil society organizations, youth, and vulnerable groups. Moreover, UNODC in collaboration with other agencies supported several Model UN conferences to promote human rights, crime prevention, gender equality, etc.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Inclusive and Equitable Social Development
Outcome: Outcome 1.3 By 2025, Persons under the Law on Foreigners and International Protection are supported towards self-reliance.

Description: This activity aims to foster positive social/behavioural chage amongs refugee and migrant as well as host communities by organising social cohesion events aiming at promoting inclusion between refugee and migrant children and youth and with their peers in host community. In additon, it refers to Technical support on establishment of platforms with the target of promoting inclusion and bridging the local divides with a focus mainly on adolescents participating in or leading civic engagement initiatives (including in humanitarian settings)
Contributing partners: United States Fund for UNICEF
Implementation partners: Ministry of Internal Affairs
SDG Targets: 4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.,16.7 Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.

QCPR function: Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Direct Support/ Service Delivery
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
"UNICEF strengthened the inclusivity of formal education through programmes aiming to ensure that all adolescents, including refugees, have equitable access to education, knowledge and skill development opportunities, including critical support for the continuation of learning during the pandemic. Furthermore, UNICEF implemented youth empowerment, skills development and peer-to-peer mentoring activities with Government and NGO partners, reaching in total of 28,895 (16,735 female 12,160 male) vulnerable Syrian and Turkish children, engaging them in blended programmes on leadership, volunteerism, skills development, and social cohesion to develop their life skills. Provincial ‘Kick-off ‘meetings in preparation for the launch of ‘Genc-UPSHIFT’ (a national youth social innovation skills initiative) were conducted by MoYS and partners (International Youth Solidarity Association and Junior Achievement Turkey) across 4 provinces for sensitisation and engagement of key stakeholders. 
Furthermore, in 2021 UNICEF launched the Generation Unlimited Initiative in Turkey through the establishment of the first UNICEF Business Advisory Board in Turkey, including 14 private companies and business associations as members, as well as the Turkish National Committee for UNICEF and  Youth Representatives. The Board works closely with the private sector to forge innovative collaborations to address the challenges faced by young people in the country, bridging education and training to employment and entrepreneurship at-scale. 
As part of the adolescent engagement programmes, UNICEF worked with NGO and government partners, reaching 244,861 (123,544 female, 121,317 male) adolescents and young people through child rights committees, social entrepreneurship, leadership programmes, girls ambassadors, and empowerment through sport activities"

2023 Narrative: Over 324,200 youth reached via social media with communication about HIV, sexual  reproductive health, and relationships through AI-based chatbot “ASPAN”. In 2023, the chatbot was moved to a new platform, enabling the use of artificial intelligence to generate answers to queries, and presented in media, related events and trainings held in co-operation with Y-PEER Kazakhstan volunteer trainers in Astana, Turkestan, Almaty and Semey cities.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Effective governance and justice for all
Outcome: Outcome 1. By 2025 all people and groups in Uzbekistan, especially the most vulnerable, demand and benefit from enhanced accountable, transparent, inclusive and gender responsive governance systems and rule of law institutions for a life free from discrimination and violence

Description: Effective participation of young people in decision-making processes, especially on matters affecting their life, is encouraged through scaling-up and enhancement of the digital platform U-Report
Contributing partners: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation, UNICEF Catalytic Fund, UNICEF GenU, UNICEF Other Resources
Implementation partners: Agency on Youth Affairs (Youth Union of Uzbekistan), Yuksalish

Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 1.4 Output 1.4. Population groups at risk of being left behind are empowered to effectively participate in decision making, social cohesion, rule of law and peace-building processes at all levels
2021 Narrative: The number of U-Reporters across all regions continues to grow and has reached over 225,000 young people, making Uzbekistan the leading U-Report country in ECA region. Two additional regional Youth Committees were established in Andijan and Bukhara regions, so that now Youth Committees supporting governance of the platform and advocacy for youth participation at the local level are established in all regions of Uzbekistan. Regional face-to-face dialogues Youth-U-Report-Khokim (local governor) were conducted in Navoi and Andijan to promote youth participation in decision-making at the local level. U-Report poll results impacted several decisions made, e.g. introduction of the "Volunteer of the Year" contest to appraise young volunteers across the country, as well as planning on the youth-related programming among UN agencies.
2022 Narrative: The number of U-Reporters across all regions continues to grow and has reached over 320,000 young people. Uzbekistan remains to be the top U-Report country on the ECA region. The number of national partners regularly using U-Report is growing. Anticorruption Agency is among the new partners frequently using U-Report for assessing the changes happening in the perceptions of the populiton.
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNICEF achieved outstanding results in expanding the opportunity for over 13.5 million adolescents in Central Asia to actively engage in climate actions. Specifically, UNICEF supported the Government and Zamin Foundation in provision of the platform for adolescents and youth from five Central Asian (CA) countries to participate in the development of the Regional Strategy on Promoting Sustainable Development Culture and Engagement of Children and Youth in Climate Agenda. The Governments of the five CA states endorsed and signed the strategy, which incorporates the voices of young people, as a basis for further youth climate actions. Two young people as a part of the National Delegation presented the Strategy at COP 28 in Dubai.

Implementation partners: Uzbekistan Agency for Youth Affairs, Yuksalish
SDG Targets: 10.2 By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.

Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 1.4 Output 1.4. Population groups at risk of being left behind are empowered to effectively participate in decision making, social cohesion, rule of law and peace-building processes at all levels
2021 Narrative: Youth and Children Friendly Local Governance Initiative has been endorsed at the level of the President's Administration. Roadmap of the initiative implementation was developed. Project team consisting of UNICEF consultant, Youth Affairs Agency and Yuksalish specialists, was established. At the moment, Institute for Studying Youth Problems is undertaking the review of the national legislation and practices to base the initiative on. Swiss funds in the amount of almost $400,000 were secured for modelling the initiative in 6 pilot cities of Uzbekistan.
2022 Narrative: Through the Youth and Child-Friendly Local Governance Initiative, UNICEF succeeded in increasing the comprehension of meaningful youth participation in decision-making of the local government of 6 pilot cities (Asaka (Andijan region), Kokand (Fergana region), Termez (Surkhandarya region), Zarafshan (Navoyi region), Yangibozar (Khorezm region) and Buston (Elikkala district, Karakalpakstan). 203 young people, including the most marginalized, took active part in the initial situation assessment. Youth Advisory Boards were established and facilitated consultations of the local government with children and youth on Action Plans of the cities for 2023. Action Plans of the cities address issues raised by children and youth during the consultations.
2023 Narrative: Jointly with the nationwide movement Yuksalish, UNICEF continued modeling Youth and Child-Friendly Local Governance in 5 pilot cities (Kokand, Termez, Zarafshan, Buton and Yangibozar) supporting the cities in implementation of the Action Plans and creating a platform for cooperation between the local government and young people for improving the well-being in their communities. By the end of 2023, all cities implemented the activities planned in the Action Plans benefitting over 100,000 children and youth in their cities through improving road safety, creating inclusive development and leisure spaces for children and youth.

2021 Narrative: Capacities of the Ministry of Sport and Youth Policy, Youth organization at the central level as well as their local councils and hakimlics at the velayat level working in the area of youth policy increased on results-based management (RBM) and understanding of the youth related SDGs and respective targets and indicators.
2022 Narrative: The country initiated some reforming of the Youth policy, made changes in the Law on Youth policy and transferred the responsibility for the Youth programme from the Ministry of Sport and Youth Policy to the Ministry of Education. The Ministry of Sport and Youth Policy was renamed to the State Committee of Physical Culture and Sports and was entrusted to lead the work on healthy lifestyles and promotion of sports and physical culture in accordance with the Law on Physical Culture and Sports. Along with these changes within the Youth participation focus of the UNFPA CO Youth programme, youth participation capacities were assessed and methodologies developed to promote and support initiatives to strengthen youth participation in country. Volunteer programme, Youth educational programme, Women and girls safe space methodology and Engagement of men programmes were developed to support the establishment of youth participation mechanism. 3-day training was held for 25 representatives of the Ministry of Education, State Committee of Physical Culture and Sports, and Youth organization from 5 velayats and Ashgabat city on youth participation application of RBM methodology to the monitoring of implementation of youth policy.

2022 Narrative: To support the initiatives of young people 2-day Youth consultations were initiated, planned and held with the UNFPA CO support that gathered around 200 young people from all over the country. This event was a great opportunity for young people to share their knowledge, experience, advise on Youth policy, ask questions and express their interests and needs in conversation with decision making authorities as well as network across the country on various issues related to young people and their communities.

2021 Narrative: 1. UNTFHS funded JP on “Empowering and engaging the youth to mitigate the multi-dimensional threats of the health pandemic” signed and launched. 2. Capacities of the Ministry of Sport and Youth Policy, Youth organization at the central level as well as their local councils and hakimlics at the velayat level working in the area of youth policy increased on the application of Human Security approach in work with vulnerable population within the UNTFHS funded JP on “Empowering and engaging the youth to mitigate the multi-dimensional threats of the health pandemic”. 3. UNODC established Youth Network with engagement of local non-public organizations and Magtymguly Youth Union, which will work closely with regional network of Youth on public awareness of the harms of drug use and will make its contribution in advocating the healthy way of life among Young people.
2022 Narrative: UNFPA CO continued the Turkmenistan – UN Joint Programme on Empowering and Engaging the Youth to Mitigate the Multi-Dimensional Threats of the Health Pandemic funded by UNTFHS. Within this programme capacity building activities on human security approach were conducted, and community initiatives started by a Youth Reference group consisting of 84 young people in Dashoguz and Lebap velayats. Within these initiatives UNFPA CO focused on building intergenerational dialogue between young people and the vulnerable groups of older people to ensure the principles of human security on freedom of dignity, freedom of fear and freedom of need. Intergenerational Dialogue was conducted to celebrate the International Day of Elders and brought visibility to the human security approach in establishing communication between young poeple and the vulnerable older people.The programme implementation was extended for another three months and will be completed by April 31, 2023.
2023 Narrative: UNFPA CO completed the Turkmenistan – UN Joint Programme on Empowering and Engaging the Youth to Mitigate the Multi-Dimensional Threats of the Health Pandemic funded by UNTFHS. The JP was implemented jointly with UNICEF, UNODC and IOM. Within this programme capacity building activities on human security approach were conducted, a Youth Reference group consisting of 84 young people were formed in Dashoguz and Lebap regions and community development initiatives conducted by these youth reference group.

2021 Narrative: Turkmenistan component of STRIVE Asia has 90K for grants to support PVE initiatives of communities and CSOs. However, there was a delay in receiving all 2021 budget, therefore, this will be done in 2022. In addition, project staff agreed with the UNDP Project Coordinator of STRIVE Asia at HQ in using 45K of grant budget for procurement of IT equipment for establishing information-resource centeres for youth, as it was suggested by advisory groups. The rest, 45K, will be used for PVE community initiatives implemented by CSOs, such as information campaigns to raise awareness about inclusive society, tolerance, peacebuilding, and PVE issues. We plan to distribute 2-3 subgrants in first quarter of 2022.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Effective governance and justice for all
Outcome: Outcome 1. By 2025 all people and groups in Uzbekistan, especially the most vulnerable, demand and benefit from enhanced accountable, transparent, inclusive and gender responsive governance systems and rule of law institutions for a life free from discrimination and violence
Output: Output 1.4. Population groups at risk of being left behind are empowered to effectively participate in decision making, social cohesion, rule of law and peace-building processes at all levels
Sub-Output: HIV positive youth are empowered and know their rights
Description: Capacity of adolescents and young people living with HIV is strengthen. Young people are empowered to know their rights and ensure  proper access to available services on HIV treatment, care and support
Agencies: United Nations Joint Programme on HIV and AIDS Secretariat
Contributing partners: United Nations Joint Programme on HIV and AIDS Secretariat
Implementation partners: United Nations Joint Programme on HIV and AIDS Secretariat
SDG Targets: 3.3 By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.,4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,13.3 Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 4 Quality Education, 17 Partnerships for the Goals
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2021 Narrative:
	In July 2021, UNAIDS organized a 3 days training for 33 adolescents / young people living with HIV and their parents from Bukhara, Navoi, Kashkadarya and Surkhandarya. The training is part of programme on psychosocial support to people living with HIV and their families. During the training, young people were provided with basic knowledge on health and HIV, adherence to treatment and quality life with HIV. 
	Ensured participation of young person living with HIV in the World Youth Rights Conference on 12-13 August. Otabek Abdujalalov opened his HIV status for the first time and spoke publicly on behalf of a group of HIV positive young people, raising issues they face on daily basis. UNAIDS inputs were included into Declaration of the Conference. 
	In October - December 2021 UNAIDS organized workshop for 10 young people living with HIV on public speaking skills development. The main purpose was to train young people on public speech to draw attention to the problems of social inequality, stigma and discrimination against young representatives of key groups and PLHIV. As a result, participants of the training prepared and did their presentation on internal meeting. Final speeches will be presented on 26 February 2022.
2022 Narrative: Three new representatives of young people living with HIV (2 girls and 1 young man) were selected as UN Youth Advisory Board members. The provided technical support and consultations and daily constant mentoring empowered them to be part of the Board. These young people are also peer educators in the communities and support regional AIDS centers work.Unfortunately, very small funds were available and it was not possible to mobilize additional resources to scale up / strengthen the work with HIV+ youth although necessary efforts were done.
2023 Narrative: Results and achievements:During July-August 2023, UNAIDS and UNICEF organized three training sessions for 76 adolescents and their parents from 9 regions in Uzbekistan. During the training participants were equipped with necessary knowledge on essential life skills for managing HIV, emphasizing the importance of HIV treatment, and fostering positive relationships with peers, parents, and healthcare professionals. The trainings were facilitated by four HIV+ young trainers, who are peer educators and UNAIDS volunteers. Two of them recently disclosed their HIV status, enabling them to share valuable information during the training and serve as role models for the participants. (Fergana 14,166 USD, Tashkent 22,053 USD)   On 26 October 2023, the Government of Uzbekistan initiated an international forum dedicated to the 75th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights on the topic: "Youth rights: opportunities and protection mechanisms". Gareth Jones, a UNAIDS consultant, highlighted diverse youth needs, UNAIDS' role in youth leadership, and challenges in HIV prevention. He praised Uzbekistan's Youth Parliament, emphasizing an enabling legal environment. The international consultant stressed the impact of punitive laws on key populations and shared insights from drafting the Agenda for Action for Adolescents. Gareth Jones urged leveraging the agenda for advocacy and making commitments to improve adolescent well-being.  Partnership: UNAIDS collaborated with UNICEF and NHRC to advocate for adolescent well-being and equip adolescents living with HIV and their parents with knowledge on essential life skills for managing HIV.  Lessons learnt:  The disclosure of HIV status by two young trainers serves as a powerful method for reducing stigma. By openly sharing their experiences, they become role models, challenging stereotypes, and contributing to a more supportive environment for individuals living with HIV.   Education, capacity building and awareness raising have become a powerful tool in empowering individuals to take control of their health and well-being.
2024 Narrative: In August, UNAIDS supported in launching the #UzYouthMentor Project, a transformative mentoring initiative for young UNAIDS volunteers in Uzbekistan, in collaboration with Chevening alumni. Over the six-month mentoring journey, mentors and mentees will meet to focus on empowering transformation of young people living with HIV. As described by one of the mentors, mentoring is a powerful educational approach that challenges, inspires, and empowers both mentees and mentors to create meaningful personal and professional growth.  In November, UNAIDS, in collaboration with the Republican AIDS Center, conducted an information session for World AIDS Day at the private Sehriyo school for students in grades 8-11. Around 140 students attended, gaining accurate insights into HIV transmission, debunking myths, and learning about the stigma and discrimination faced by people living with HIV. In December, to amplify the voices of young people living with HIV, UNAIDS organized a meeting between members of YPLHIV and the UN Resident Coordinator. Several YPLHIV members shared their personal experiences, highlighting challenges such as discrimination in healthcare settings, barriers to education, and mental health issues.  In December, UNAIDS led an information session on HIV for students at Westminster International University in Tashkent to provide students with essential knowledge about HIV, fostering awareness and understanding among the university community. About 30 students and staff members of the university were engaged in the event. Three young people living with HIV shared their experiences of life with HIV and challenges they face because of the misinformation. UNAIDS implemented a photo project featuring young people living with HIV, promoting creativity and self-expression. A photo story of Azima, a young woman living with HIV, was published on the UNAIDS global website: Azima’s Story. In September, UNAIDS organized a specialized photography walk, led by a professional photographer, aimed at enhancing the photography skills of young people living with HIV. The event provided participants with practical, hands-on experience in photography techniques, fostering creativity, self-expression, and confidence. Throughout the walk, participants learned about the technical aspects of photography, such as composition, lighting, and camera settings, while also exploring storytelling through images.

Plan name: Turkmenistan UNSDCF 2021 - 2025
Strategic priority: Priority A: People centred governance and rule of law
Outcome: Outcome 1 By 2025, people have access to more effective, innovative, and transparent public administration based upon the rule of law, human rights, gender equality, labour rights, and quality data
Output: Output 1.4. Government, including law enforcement agencies and other state institutions develop, and equipped with tools and skills to effectively implement programmes and mechanisms in the field of human rights, gender equality and labour rights  on the basis of recommendations from UN treaties and mechanisms and ILO supervisory bodies and feedback from civil society, including workers’ and employers’ organizations and relevant population groups
Sub-Output: Support to the implementation of the 2021–2025 Programme for the Support and Development of Physical Culture and Sports in Turkmenistan as well as strengthening mechanisms for youth participation by advancement of physical culture, sports, peace and gender equality
Description:
In 2023-2025 UNFPA will continue its technical support to the State Committee of Turkmenistan on Physical Culture and Sports as well as other national partners in the implementation of the “2021–2025 Programme for the Support and Development of Physical Culture and Sports in Turkmenistan” as well as strengthening mechanisms for youth participation by advancement of physical culture, sports, peace and gender equality. 
In 2023 the focus will be on completing the UNTFHS JP; launching of piloting of the programme of volunteerism and men angagement to increase awareness and advance gender equality, educate on life skills, reproductive health, managing emotions and promote physical culture and sports to empower young people; studying international best practices on the work of youth organizations in promoting physical culture and sports, peace and gender equality; conducting a survey among adolescents and youth to assess their interests, rights, opportunities and participation in advancement of gender equality, healthy lifestyles, engagements in physical culture and sports as well as decision-making processes related to their lives. 
In 2024-2025 the focus will be on completing the piloting, evaluating the results, reviewing institutional mechanisms for further implementation and developing a draft volunteerism program aimed at promoting healthy lifestyles, gender equality, and youth participation in decision-making related to the lives of  young people; (2) creating a network of youth groups and youth work organizations and holding annual coordination meetings; (3) the formation of a Youth Reference Group for the purpose of advising on the implementation of the UNFPA Youth Program; (4) training a group of young activists in the field of promoting healthy lifestyles, physical education and sports, gender equality, youth participation in decision-making; (5) developing materials and conducting campaigns to spotlight issues of gender equality, healthy lifestyles, physical education and sports to promote the UNFPA Global Youth Program and “State Program in the field of state youth policy of Turkmenistan for 2021-2025”.
Contributing partners: Conflict, Stability and Security Fund, Spotlight Initiative Fund, United Nations Population Fund
Implementation partners: Civil society organizations of Turkmenistan, State Committee of Turkmenistan on Physical Culture and Sports, United Nations Population Fund
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.,5.4 Recognize and value unpaid care and domestic work through the provision of public services, infrastructure and social protection policies and the promotion of shared responsibility within the household and the family as nationally appropriate.,5.5 Ensure women's full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life,5.6 Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.
Geography: Balkan Province, Ahal Province, Mary Province, Lebap Province, Ashgabat, Turkmenistan, Daşoguz Province
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Direct Support/ Service Delivery
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
LNOB groups targeted: Youth, Women & Girls, Persons With Disabilities
2023 Narrative: Within this sub output UNFPA coordinated UN support throughout the UN Agencies in the area of advancing gender equality, healthy lifestyles, physical culture and sports. In 2023 UNFPA will continue its technical support to the State Committee of Turkmenistan on Physical Culture and Sports as well as other national partners in the implementation of the “2021–2025 Programme for the Support and Development of Physical Culture and Sports in Turkmenistan” as well as strengthening mechanisms for youth participation by advancement of physical culture, sports, peace and gender equality. The Committee and UNFPA jointly carried out activities focusing on (1) cooperation in holding meetings with young men and women from urban and rural areas with the involvement of young athletes (men and women) to advance the concepts of peace, gender equality, physical culture and sports; (2) piloted of the programme of volunteerism among young people to increase awareness and advance gender equality, educate on life skills, reproductive health, managing emotions and promote physical culture and sports to empower young people; (3) studied international best practices on the work of youth organizations in promoting physical culture and sports, peace and gender equality; (4) conducted a survey among adolescents and youth to assess their interests, rights, opportunities and participation in advancement of gender equality, healthy lifestyles, engagements in physical culture and sports as well as decision-making processes related to their lives; (5) cooperated in conducting national informational activities within international initiatives to promote gender equality and positive gender norms through the engagement of men and boys as well as (6) developed a new project proposal for youth empowerment and advancement of youth participation, gender equality, physical culture, sports and peace among adolescents and youth.
2024 Narrative: The year of 2024 was successful for the GEN/YTH programme. Here's a snapshot of the successes:Strategic Focus: By aligning with CEDAW and the Beijing Declaration, the program effectively addressed key priorities like tackling traditional gender norms, strengthening policies, and improving service access.Government Collaboration: Strong partnerships with the government and national partners led to concrete achievements, including the development of a CEDAW Road Map to improve legal protections for women and girls, signing of a Memorandum of Understanding for the scale up of essential GBV services, gaining support and commitment from key stakeholders to establish a lasting program of gender-focused volunteerism within sports schools and introduction of GBV related topics in the education of young soldiers in the army.Essential GBV Services: Collaboration with the National Red Crescent Society resulted in the launch of six Family Support Services in 5 regional capitals and Ashgabat city providing vital support to GBV survivors through hotlines, psychosocial counselling and case management Engaging Men and Boys: The program piloted successful initiatives to engage men and boys in championing gender equality and preventing GBV, addressing root causes and shifting harmful norms by introducing gender focused volunteerism programme in sports schools and capacity building of psychologists in military. Being a small-scale intervention, it helped create buy-in at the central and community levels for the gender equality concept among young men and boys, in particular. Partnerships with international counterparts: Collaboration with international organizations like the UK Embassy, OSCE, EU Delegation, UNODC, UNRCCA and UNDP amplified efforts through shared expertise, increased advocacy, and enhanced coordination.This focused approach, combining strategic alignment, strong partnerships, and targeted initiatives, has laid a solid foundation for continued progress towards gender equality and GBV prevention in Turkmenistan.Among lessons learned it's worth mentioning the below:Building trust with the national partners and showcasing the real results is a basis for the fruitful cooperation: men engagement piloting was monitored jointly with the national partners; launching of GBV services was undertaken as a joint decision with the national partners applying international and regional UNFPA expertise.Connecting Turkmenistan's development goals with UNFPA's expertise was a successful strategy in helping the country fulfill its international commitments related to gender equality, as outlined in the CEDAW agreement and the Beijing Platform for Action.Promoting gender equality and opening conversations on GBV prevention from bottom up, developing a bank of communication resources to showcase and promote gender equality in social media, engagement of young men and boys and working with stereotypes provoked lots of comments and responses making the online and offline conversations interesting and real. This approach proved to be working well and gathered many supporters for promoting GE and GBV prevention. More and more young men and boys exress their interest to join the men engagement initiative.

2023 Narrative: Since April, OHCHR conducted “School on human rights and advocacy on the rights of persons with disabilities.”as part public awareness campaign commemorating the 75th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR). 18 young people with various forms of disability for a period of six months enhanced their knowledge and skills on human rights, the UN Strategy on Youth, international approaches to equality and non-discrimination, the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and advocacy on the rights of persons with disabilities. 8 women and 10 young men participated in the initiative.

Description: Support to development of the third National Action Plan on combating trafficking in persons and strengthening the legal framework on trafficking in persons to better address the needs of youth and women through a victim-centered approach.
Contributing partners: International Organization for Migration Development Fund
Implementation partners: Government of Turkmenistan

2023 Narrative: IOM supported the development of the draft woman and youth-sensitive CTIP National Action Plan for 2024-2026 which was shared with the relevant national stakeholders, UN agencies for review and feedback. The new draft NAP on CTIP prioritizes a number of important issues, including, among others, the establishment and operationalization of a National Referral Mechanism and Compensation Mechanism for survivors of human trafficking, possible establishment of human trafficking victims support fund and shelters with a specific focus on youth and women.The new draft NAP also provides for a series of capacity building interventions for a broad range of stakeholders to ensure sustainability and national ownership of CTIP NAP.IOM supported the development of the analyses of the national CTIP legal framework through a gender- and age-sensitive perspectives, particularly focusing on women and youth issues with the recommendations for changes and amendments in the relevant national laws and normative acts, which was submitted to the members of Interdepartmental Working Group on development and implementation of National Action Plan (NAP) on combating trafficking in persons (CTIP) for review.IOM also built capacities of relevant national stakeholders on mainstreaming gender-sensitive approaches in relevant national plans in Turkmenistan.

In addition, UNODC's sport-based social movies included in the secondary education curricula (5th and 7th grades) covered about 400 000 school students in 2021.
2022 Narrative: Completed Line Up Live Up (LULU) life skills sport-based programme in Kokand city of Fergana Valley among 20 schools and more than 2,000 school students. In addition, in 2022, the LULU program was conducted in several schools of Uzbekistan (Tashkent and Fergana Valley) without any financial support from UNODC, more than 200 students took part in the programme. Since 2020, LULU social movies have been included into the secondary curricula “Education” (Vospitanie) 5th, 6th abd 7th academic grades.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Effective governance and justice for all
Outcome: Outcome 1. By 2025 all people and groups in Uzbekistan, especially the most vulnerable, demand and benefit from enhanced accountable, transparent, inclusive and gender responsive governance systems and rule of law institutions for a life free from discrimination and violence
Output: Output 1.4. Population groups at risk of being left behind are empowered to effectively participate in decision making, social cohesion, rule of law and peace-building processes at all levels
Sub-Output: Assessing the Media and Information Literacy of the youth in Ferghana valley
Description:
A large-scale MIL Assessment on 3 regions of Fergana Valley (Andijan, Ferghana and Namangan) has been conducted between May and November of 2021. The assessment has collected very valuable data on MIL capacity of the youth and the members of the organizations that work with youth in the region. The analytical report from collected data is being used for organizing and developing other MIL based activities and guidelines, media policies.
In addition, Capacity Building Workshops in partnership with local media information organization has given fruitful results. Members of 9 local youth led organization have been trained for MIL capacity and they are currently using the acquired knowledge in their respective jobs. Part of the trainings were in capital city – Tashkent. Therefore, participants have valuable experience on networking with their colleagues from Tashkent as well.

All activities had criteria of at least 50% participants/respondents involved must be women.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Contributing partners: The UN Secretary-General’s Peacebuilding Fund (UN Peace Fund)
Implementation partners: Uzbekistan Ministry of Higher Education, Science and Innovation , Uzbekistan State Inspectorate for the Supervision of Education Quality

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Competitive Production, Productivity and Decent Work for All
Outcome: 2.1 By 2025, public institutions and private sector contribute to a more inclusive, sustainable and innovative industrial and agricultural development, and equal and decent work opportunities for all, in cooperation with the social partners.
Output: Output 2.1.4 Technical and institutional capacities of public institutions, social partners and the private sector on elimination of worst forms of child labour are strengthened
Sub-Output: 2.1.4.15 Business practices upholding children's rights are promoted and number of business organizations undertaking activities for children/youth are increased.
Description: (i) Children's rights and business principles (CRBPs) are introduced and  business organizations are supported to adopt business practices upholding children's rights; (ii) Standart operational procedures of labour inspection are made child sensitive and child-labour sensitive, and all labour inspectors received trainings to apply these tools in their  work; (iii) SMEs providing workplace training for vocational training center students are supported to increase their capacity to adopt Occupational Health & Safety measures tailored to Covid-19.
Contributing partners: UNICEF National Committees
Implementation partners: Turkish Ministry of Family and Social Services, Turkish Ministry of National Education, Türkiye Odalar ve Borsalar Birliği (TOBB)
SDG Targets: 8.7 Take immediate and effective measures to eradicate forced labour, end modern slavery and human trafficking and secure the prohibition and elimination of the worst forms of child labour, including recruitment and use of child soldiers, and by 2025 end child labour in all its forms.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: The project seeks to address some root causes of gender inequalities by using the Children’s Rights and Business Principles, which guide businesses to respect and support children’s rights with a focus on gender dimensions. These principles recognize that girls are more likely to be involved in child labour activities such as domestic work and sexual exploitation, and that boys and girls face different risks. By applying these principles, the project addresses gender inequalities by acknowledging that women and girls often face greater challenges in accessing decent work due to social and gender norms. Additionally, the project ensures that security arrangements consider the different vulnerabilities of both girls and boys, particularly in emergency or high-risk situations.This project is in line with the UNICEF’ Country Programme Document which emphasizes on creating social change to address harmful practices affecting adolescents, such as child labor, child marriage, and other forms of violence, as well as to increase the parents' and communities' knowledge of protective behaviours and practices. In addition, gender integration is guided by UNICEF Gender Action Plan (2022-2025).
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights

2021 Narrative: Turkmenistan took part at the Ministerial Conference on “Shaping Europe’s Demographic Future”, organized by the Government of Bulgaria and UNFPA on 1-2 December 2021 and supported the joint initiative to announce a Decade of Demographic Resilience and establish the Sofia Alliance. The Decade is to provide impetus for countries in the region including Turkmenistan to partner, anticipate and understand the way populations are changing, and develop responses that mitigate potentially negative effects and fully harness the opportunities that also always come with demographic change. It also to contribute to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals in Europe and Central Asia. The Alliance is to contribute to achieving the goals of the Decade of Demographic Resilience by offering a platform to receive support, and share experiences, in addressing challenges and harnessing opportunities related to demographic change in areas such as population ageing, migration, rural revitalization, empowering young people, gender equality, financing of social policies, and enabling people to have the number of children they want. Turkmenistan was represented by a delegation led by a Deputy Chair of the SSC that demonstrates the country’s buy-in and strong promises for future partnersips, support and follow up regarding the Conference agreements.

2021 Narrative: UNFPA initiated extensive consultations with the Academy of State Service, SSC and the Ministry of Education to discuss the importance and avenues for establishment of Demographic Education in Turkmenistan. The dialogue helped to identify the associated needs and gaps as well as opportunities for effective solutions. It shall be noted that the initiative for Demographic Education was suggested by the Academy of State Service and supported by UNFPA. Considering the fact that the national educational system does not offer the demographic education as a full-fledged program. Some universities offer this education in a fragmented manner under other disciplines in small sections. The SSC recognizes serious difficulties when it comes to analysis of population data and demographic forecasts. With the support of an international expert, a Concept Note for Demographic Education was drafted with information on global and regional education programs in demography and opportunities for partnerships, exchange programs for students and faculty members, overview of the Turkmenistan situation and how the initiative could be rolled over in the country. The Concept Note is being considered by the national partners for actualization in 2022 with specific and targeted actions.

Sub-Output: 3.4.18 Strengthening youth friendly health centers by further enhancing on-line counselling, promoting gender equality in service provision, improving outreach to the most vulnerable groups of adolescents, and providing necessary supplies
Contributing partners: European Union, UNAIDS Unified Budget, Results and Accountability Framework, UNICEF Education Thematic Fund, UNICEF Emergency Program Fund
Implementation partners: Belarus Ministry of Health
SDG Targets: 3.3 By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.,3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,3.8 Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.

Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
LNOB groups targeted: Persons With Disabilities, Refugees & Asylum Seekers, Women & Girls, Youth, Children , Migrants, Other, Persons affected by chronic/long-term health conditions (e.g., HIV/AIDS, leprosy, diabetes, autoimmune disease, etc.)
2023 Narrative: UNICEF conducted a nationwide assessment of 58 Youth Friendly Health Centers. The assessment identified that YFHCs provided quality health care services tailored to adolescents needs and contributed to decrease in adolescents’ abortions (by 19%), pregnancies (by 28%) and sexually transmitted infections (by 35%) rates. The conclusions and recommendations of the YFHCs assessment contributed to the review of the Order of the Ministry of Health #343 on YFHCs functioning to cover outreach work and online services and update the centers’ coordination at the oblast level, staff structure, reporting forms, and classification of services. The Order is currently pending approval. Regarding the role of social media in adolescents accessing information, communications and services, a guide on the use of social media was developed and placed online for YFHCs specialistsSpecial focus was on the YFHCs outreach services scaling up and piloting rehabilitation among vulnerable groups of adolescents, including adolescents living with HIV. 180 pediatricians, GPs, psychologists, specialists on infection diseases were trained to apply the engaging outreach practices. In two YFHCs in Minsk trained specialists reached out 1,995 adolescents and boosted targeted assistance to adolescents practicing risky behaviors by 24%.

Description:
General theme: Increasing women's and youth's capacities for leadership positions (national and local government, legislature, etc.)
Outcome 8: Gender Equality 
Output 8.2: Participation of women in decision making at all levels of the executive, legislative, and judicial sectors of governance systems
8.2.1 Increased women's and youth's capacities for leadership positions (national and local government, legislature, etc.)
Existing programme: Women and Youth for Innovative Local Development (WYILD). Respective component from UKGGF-funded Women in Politics (WiP2.0) Project. UNDP Armenia Engagement Facility for Gender Equality Portfolio; Resilience For All
Contributing partners: Good Governance Fund of the UK, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Norway, Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation, United Nations Development Programme
Implementation partners: Armenia Ministry of Territorial Administration and Infrastructure, Local Governments
SDG Targets: 5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.,5.5 Ensure women's full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life,16.6 Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.,16.7 Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.

QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 8.2  8.2 Participation of women in decision making at all levels of the executive, legislative, and judicial sectors of governance systems
2021 Narrative: In 2021 local elections, UNDP reached 1311 women from142 communities across Armenia.Leadership potential and capacity of 62 women elected or working in local self-government (Ararat, Armavir and Aragatsotn regions) advanced on leadership, participatory local governance, gender equality and women empowerment via 4 leadership schools and post-school self-driven community projects (25) on local democratization. 37 women (Arts  Culture, STEM, lawyers) advanced on political empowerment via 3 leadership schools. “Women2Women” leadership advancement scheme linked 39 local women leaders (mentees) and 20 national-level women leaders (mentors). The participants valued the inspirational and network-building effect of the initiative. “Integrity Islands” piloted in 2 new municipalities of Shirak and Lori regions to enhance accountability and transparency, including corruption risk assessment, integrity management planning and monitoring.  Women and Youth Advisory Councils (WYACs) adjunct to Mayor are formed in 7 municipalities, as bodies for strengthening women’s voice and local participatory processes. 63 (44 women, 19 men) WYAC members developed their leadership, negotiation and communication skills via four capacity building training sessions.  6 municipalities engendered AWPs to ensure a more balanced allocation of municipal resources in community annual workplans.
2022 Narrative: Overall, Gender Equality portfolio’s major interventions at the country level in 2022, included:Pre-electoral and post-electoral support to women leaders (resulted into 30% women representation in local councils, and increase in women representation as head of communities from 2% to 5.5%)Co-designed formal and non-formal platforms establishment to engage women and youth in policy making and community development as well as local democratization efforts (21% of all recommendations submitted were adopted by stakeholders, 15 more Women and Youth Advisory Councils adjunct to the head of communities were established and capacitated)Engendered local and national policies, planning and budgeting practices (7 communities engenders the Annual Work Plans and 2 action plans based on Gender Seal process were developed for public institutions)
2023 Narrative: 44 women local councilors, administrative heads of communities and secretaries of staff skills on leadership, participatory research, municipal planning and budgeting, gender equality main concepts advanced within two leadership schools;36 women connected as mentors (women leaders and the national level) and mentees (women leaders at the local level) through the Mentorship scheme;31 members of political parties/ members of parliament advanced their skills on gender-sensitive policy making;120 women and youth knowledge in stress management, positive digital footprint, women representation at the appointed positions and advanced leadership, women in diplomacy and peace topics advanced through three Virtual Community of Practice meetings;2 Women and Youth Advisory councils by the head of community established and capacitated to implement small-scale community initiatives;2 policy clubs established involving women local leaders, members of parliament and political party members;2 packages with legislative amendments elaborated;2 sessions on elected positions at the local level and appointed positions at the national level organized within the largest regional FemInno conference;Youth cadre contributed to local democratization processes in 56 settlements of 14 enlarged communities. Youth contributed to policy making, 37% of the recommendations to the "Draft Law on Making Amendments to the Regulations on the Evaluation of Student Learning Results of State Public Educational Institutions" proposed by MESCS were accepted. Women and Youth Advisory Councils led by women improved transportation service in Khoy and extracurricular service in Noyemberyan communities.4 innovative models of municipal sectoral services designed and piloted in target municipalities
2024 Narrative: Through targeted programs like Women Leadership Schools and Women and Youth Advisory Councils (WYACs), over 500 women gained the skills to influence policies and participate in decision-making at national and local levels. Four new WYACs were established, contributing to the adoption of six policy packages and 63 recommendations, with 15 integrated into final drafts. UNDP strengthened local governance to address refugee needs, training 1,505 local government staff. Inclusive municipal services were introduced in five communities, engaging 6,000 refugees in governance and decision-making.

Contributing partners: United Nations Population Fund
SDG Targets: 16.1 Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.,16.7 Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.,16.b Promote and enforce non-discriminatory laws and policies for sustainable development.
