2021 Narrative:
Within the project “Supporting the Western Balkan’s collective leadership on reconciliation: building capacity and momentum for the Regional Youth Cooperation Office (RYCO)”, three Best Innovative Ideas coming from the students that attended the peacebuilding workshops were implemented in the form of grassroots projects in three multi-ethnic municipalities in Kosovo. 
Seed of Solidarity (Gracanica/e) - “Seed of Solidarity” one of the Best Innovative Ideas implemented in the municipality of Gracanica, aimed to plant the seeds of a better future.  This was done through workshops on human rights, peacebuilding and reconciliation as well as a visit to the archaeological park of Ulpiana as a symbol of the history that brings all Kosovo communities together.
Natural Peace (Gracanica/e and Vushtrri/Vucitrn) - The idea of “Natural Peace” was to create a workshop that would raise the awareness of young people from Albanian, Serbian and Roma communities, where they would be able to learn about important environmental issues and the importance of ecology for all of us. In this case, they would get to know each other, exchange experiences and work on a joint green project. The project was implemented in Gracanica and Vushtrri where youth also planted trees and installed trash bins as permanent evidence of cooperation between communities.
Stride for Peace - “Stride for peace” was one of the Best Innovative Ideas implemented in the municipality of Prishtina that aimed to inspire peace education to youth from different communities in Kosovo. The main idea was to educate youth in areas such as human rights, transitional justice, collective memory and to work together as a unity on the process of changing the narratives for the new generations.

Description: Support adolescent girls and boys across all three regions of Montenegro to receive career guidance and job training through the “Prilike” programme, which is recognized as a precursor to the EU Youth Guarantee scheme, integrating private-sector partnerships and civil society collaboration to support adolescents in acquiring labour market-relevant skills.
Contributing partners: Core Funding, Swedish International Development Agency, TUI Care foundation

Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: UNICEF supported the continuation of Prilike, a school-to-work transition programme, through which 450 adolescent girls and boys across four schools and two regions are receiving support through on-the-job training and career guidance, with the aim of integrating it into the official school curriculum. The programme is synchronized with the school year, providing support to adolescents from September 2023 until July 2024.
2024 Narrative: UNICEF supported the continuation of Prilike, a school-to-work transition programme, with the plan of piloting the programme through the formal education system and integrating it into the official school curriculum. The programme is synchronized with the school year, providing support to adolescents from September 2024 until July 2025.The programme is piloted in the central and southern region of Montenegro, in four different schools (Gymnasium "Slobodan Skerovic" Podgorica, Gymnasium Cetinje, Economics High School "Mirko Vesovic" Podgorica and High School "Ivan Goran Kovacic" Herceg Novi). More than 1600 adolescents across all three regions of Montenegro received career guidance and job training through the Prilike programme which is recognized as a precursor to the EU Youth Guarantee scheme, integrating private sector partnerships and civil society collaboration to support adolescents in acquiring labor market-relevant skills.

2023 Narrative: 17 civic initiatives of young people from the country were supported methodologically and financially in 2023 by UNFPA in collaboration with Terre des Hommes Moldova, Council of Europe and National Youth Agency with funds from Swiss Development Cooperation. More than 380 young people teamed up together with Youth Centers, teachers, and civil servants to transform for the better the localities in which they live. Gender stereotypes and discrimination, environmental crisis, lack of recreational spaces for youth, vocational orientation - these are just a few of the issues identified by young people across the country in the 'YouCreate' program. https://moldova.unfpa.org/en/news/young-people-solve-problems-local-level-17-initiatives-implemented-youth-their-communities
2024 Narrative: 16 youth youth led community-based initiatives from all over the country, have been implemented within the Your Create Program, with support of UNFPA in collaboration with Terre des Hommes Moldova, Council of Europe and National Youth Agency with funds from Swiss Development Cooperation. More than 3700 young people and 250 adults (youth workers, teachers, public servants) benefited from the realized activities that addressed with creative and impactful solutions the local needs on designing youth-friendly spaces (exterior / interior); art–therapy activities, media literacy activities, etc.: https://bit.ly/3C3hcRs These initiatives enhanced young people’s preparedness for civic and social engagement, equip with practical skills, motivation, and support their personal development and active citizenship.

2023 Narrative: In 2022, in consultation with President’s Office, UNICEF continued its support and technical expertise to the MoES for the development of the national strategy on inclusive education 2022-2032. In cooperation with the Ministry of Education and Science, the World health Organization, the Ministry of Health, local partners and NGOs the needs assessment of children and education systems in assistive technologies and Augmentative and Alternative Communication (AAC) was initiated - their assessment will be finalized in July 2023. Together with the Ministry of Education and Science, UNICEF and partners conducted an analysis of the web accessibility standards that will be included in the modification process of the national digital platform “All-Ukrainian School Online”. The new features aim at making the digital platform more user-friendly and accessible for children with visual impairments. UNICEF supported the development of digital lessons for the All-Ukrainian School Online to cover the gap in content for 5-11 grades.  UNICEF worked closely with MoYS to support its Youth Policy Reform, aiming to activate young people as driving force of emergency response and capacitate them for post-war recovery. UNICEF supported the Ministerial flagship program “Spivdiia” and strengthened 25 youth centers as providers of services for young people. UNICEF scaled up youth volunteering movement, engaging 192,522 young people as volunteers. Focusing on PSS life skills education and socio-emotional learning, UNICEF reached 137,314 adolescents all over Ukraine. To feature the results of young people’s contribution in emergency response UNICEF organize a National event with First Lady of Ukraine “Youth Awards” featuring the achievement 17 young volunteer leaders from UNICEF programs and attended by 300 youth. UNICEF supported the engagement of 41,103 boys and girls aged between 8-17 years. This included IDP children, predominantly those living in collective centers, with limited access to education or those who are out of school in socio-emotional learning, MHPSS and life skills education. They covered Chernivtsi, Ivano-Frankivsk, Ternopil, Lviv, Khmelnytsky, Uzhhorod, Rivne, Lutsk, Vinnytsia, Bucha, Khmelnytsky, Cherkasy Regions.100,767 children and adolescent reached in 2022 (24,535 by the services of Youth Centers - Youth Up; 35,692 Spilno meeting points - PDK; 19,540 equipped with skills and engaged in social cohesion; 11,000 by supporting vocational institutions in Mykolaiv MOES; 10,000 engaged through U-Report - YouthUp). UNICEF covered in Kyiv and Kyivska, Chernihivska, Cherkaska, Poltavska, Zaporizhska, Mykolayivska, Khersonska, Rivnenska, Ternopilska, Dnipropetrovska, Vinnytska, Volynska, Kharkivska, Zakarpatska,Chernivertska, Sumska, Odeska, Khmelnytska, Ivano-Frankivska and Donetska. UNICEF and partners are implementing comprehensive recovery support for Zhytomyr and other select municipalities. This includes supporting an integrated service model including reaching out to students, including children with special educational needs and pre-school age children.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Quality, accessible and inclusive education, health and social protection
Outcome: 2 By 2025, people  benefit from more inclusive  and higher quality educational  programmes focused on 21st  century skills for enhanced  employability, well-being and  active participation in society
Output: 2023-2025 2.2 Adolescents, youth and vulnerable groups have skills to increase their employability and active and productive participation in society and the economy
Sub-Output: 2023-2025 2.2.5 Adolescents and youth are provided with the opportunities to develop their twenty-first century skills to actively and productively participate in society
Description:
As adolescents can significantly contribute to societal development, if equipped with a set of 21st century skills in the area of education, media, digitalization and social life, by working with adolescents, their communities and key institutions, such as schools, to build, promote and support their skills and competencies, it is expected that a critical mass of adolescents will be able to better connect among themselves, mitigate risks and strengthen core social values that the country needs. In parallel with technical support provided to government to build and implement the competency- based curricula, UNICEF will work to increase opportunities to learn business and other skills and competencies trough non-formal education. UNICEF will further invest in awareness raising about the importance of adolescence in the life-course perspective; its linkage with socio-emotional development, behaviour and job readiness. UNICEF will help improve the capacities of government institutions to monitor and evaluate interventions and programmes for adolescents, also using U-Report   to ‘feed’ and test such interventions, to develop core indicators and improve the quality of data and information sharing among all key actors. 

Furthermore, UNICEF will invest in creating more demand in society for skills-based education, by implementing communication for development interventions targeting the general public, including decision-makers, parents/caregivers and CSOs, and emphasizing the importance of skills development for adolescents, including for the most vulnerable groups such as girls, Roma and adolescents with disabilities.

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 2: Peace - Effective Institutions, Human Rights and Gender Equality
Outcome: Outcome 2.1: By 2025, all people in Kazakhstan are protected and enjoy full realization of human rights and gender equality and a life free from discrimination, violence and threats, and equally participate in decision making
Output: Output 2.1.2:Increased capacities of state institutions and other relevant organizations to expand access to justice and combat discrimination with a focus on women and marginalized groups
Sub-Output: Support to Enhancement of Law Enforcement and Judicial Practices on Anti-Corruption and Promoting Integrity Education among Youth in Kazakhstan
Description: The objective is to enhance the capacity of Anti-Corruption Agency’s officers and judiciary in dealing with financial and corruption crimes and to raise awareness on the importance of countering corruption among youth
Agencies: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime
Contributing partners: The US Government Department of State's Bureau of International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs
Implementation partners: Kazakhstan Anti-corruption Agency, Kazakhstan higher education institutions
SDG Targets: 16.3 Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.,16.5 Substantially reduce corruption and bribery in all their forms.
Geography: Astana, Almaty (city), Kazakhstan, Bayanaul, Zerendi, Pavlodar, Akmola
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2023 Narrative: Technical and analytical capacity of Anti-Corruption Agency to investigate corruption-related cases strengthened. 42 officers-analysts (4 women) of Anti-Corruption Agency of Kazakhstan enhanced their knowledge and skills on application of IBM i2 software for criminal intelligence and investigation of corruption-related crimes.Four (4) IBM i2 Analyst Notebook and iBase software licenses purchased and handed over to the Anti-Corruption Agency for further use in its analytical and investigation activities.
2024 Narrative: The curricula of the advanced training courses of the Justice Academy under the High Judicial Council has been enhanced by the new training course on international standards and national judicial practices for adjudicating corruption-related crimes in Kazakh and Russian languages. The faculty of the Academy has started using the course materials at the refresher training sessions for serving judges in Kazakhstan from 1 September 2024. The course has a clear focus on enhancing knowledge, skills, understanding of international standards and gaps in national legislation on the investigation and prosecution of corruption cases. Such specialization will help serving judges to adjudicate corruption crimes by applying national legislation, international standards and best practices, and will contribute to the prevention of corruption among both judges and judicial system personnel.“The fundamentals of Law and Anti-Corruption Legislation” course utilizing the UNODC Global Resource for Anti-Corruption Education and Youth Empowerment (GRACE) initiative products developed, piloted and integrated into the training curricula of Narxoz University. 137 students of Narxoz University have chosen this course as a compulsory discipline in 2024-2025 academic year.Held a series of five capacity-building workshops for some 120 judges (45 women) from district and city courts on practical application of international standards and advanced practices in adjudicating corruption-related and financial crimes The Youth Anticorruption Summer Schools and student case competitions held in Astana city, Akmola and Pavlodar provinces brought together more than 100 representatives from some 30 universities, colleges and public youth associations from across the country. Throughout these activities, participants engaged in collaborative discussions on implementing anti-corruption strategies and enhancing integrity within their respective institutions. Based on the knowledge gained during the Anticorruption Summer School, the Code of Academic Integrity was revised, and new compliance procedure tools were introduced in Karaganda Medical University. Between 2023 and 2024, using the i2 Analyst Notebook and i2 iBase applications, the Agency's officers analyzed over 230 requests from across the country, resulting in the creation of 7,500 analytical schemes. These schemes were incorporated into the evidence base of approximately 140 criminal cases, including high-profile investigations related to multi-billion tenge corruption, embezzlement, and bribery. In addition, using i2 Analyst Notebook and iBase software, officers of the Central Office of the Anti-Corruption Agency started piloting the analysis of bank transactions and electronic invoice scrutiny.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Support national efforts to promote prosperity and resilience for all citizens through inclusive and equitable green socio-economic development (GREEN SOCIO-ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT)
Outcome: By 2027, the well-being of the population of the Kyrgyz Republic will have improved through the further rollout of a green economy based on sustainable and healthy food systems natural resource management, and effective migration processes, by accelerating the use of gender transformative social and technological innovations and entrepreneurship
Output: Green economic growth is accelerated through increased equitable entrepreneurship and employment opportunities, including through the sustainable use of natural resources.
Sub-Output: Policies and mechanisms in place for equitable access to finance and decent employment create opportunities, especially for women, youth, and other vulnerable groups.
Description: Policies and mechanisms in place for equitable access to finance and decent employment create opportunities, especially for women, youth, and other vulnerable groups.
Contributing partners: European Union, Finland Ministry for Foreign Affairs, Green Climate Fund (Readiness and Preparatory Support), United Nations Development Programme
Implementation partners: Kyrgyz Ministry of Economy and Commerce, Kyrgyz Ministry of Finance, Kyrgyz Ministry of Natural Resources, Ecology and Technical Supervision
SDG Targets: 8.3 Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.,8.5 By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.
Geography: Kemin, Chui, Issyk-Kul, Osh, Issyk-Kul, Kyrgyzstan, Chui, Uzgen, Karakol (city), Osh (city)
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Data Collection and Analysis, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
LNOB groups targeted: Youth, Minorities, Older Persons, Migrants, Persons With Disabilities, Women & Girls, Stateless Persons
2023 Narrative: In collaboration with other development partners, UNDP supported the organization of Women Entrepreneurship Day 2023 that took place in Nov 2023 and gathered more than 280 women entrepreneurs. The event promoted the importance of women’s entrepreneurship in the socio-economic development of the country and provides women entrepreneurs, including from rural areas, with a platform to network, exchange experiences, discuss common challenges and celebrate achievements.At the request of the Secretariat of the National Council on the Implementation of the WTO’s Trade Facilitation Agreement (hereinafter - TFA), UNDP support is envisaged in the implementation of the TFA’s certain provisions. In particular, it will entail the following: (a) preliminary research on the state of play and mapping of the next steps will be conducted with regards to the transition of the country (the customs authorities) to e-declarations, (b) examining the current methodology on administrative fees for customs clearance of imported goods for compliance with international rules (e.g., WTO agreements), standards and best practices; (c) conducting research and developing justifications for reduction of the amounts of guaranties in order to transit through the territory of the country, as well as to become an authorized economic operator. To facilitate MSMEs’ access to digital marketplaces, UNDP is supporting the NIA in developing video and written guides on how to register on various marketplaces, including global, regional and local that will be available on the NIA’s web-site export.gov.kg. The portal is one of the main channels through which the agency provides services to its clients and where both export-oriented MSMEs and potential buyers can find useful information ranging from analytical briefs and guides to exporters’ database. three modules have been developed/improved for the web-site: a module for exporters’ self-registration in the exporters’ database; a module for the online registration of companies for various events (exhibitions/business forums); a module to filter exporters in the exporters’ database by various criteria. UNDP supported the Association of E-commerce in organizing the E-commerce Forum gathering more than 650 participants, 289 of them are women, from the public, private and development sectors. Participants had an opportunity to learn about emerging trends and opportunities in the sector, exchange ideas and knowledge, as well as network. Topics included digital technologies in e-commerce, marketplaces, financial payments services, etc.UNDP supported the participation of Kyrgyz MSMEs in the following five international trade fairs/exhibitions that resulted in export contracts: 2023 ITB Berlin tourism exhibition; Agriteq 2023 Qatar; Arabian Travel Market (ATM) 2023; Shanghai Expo 2023; World Travel Market (WTM) 2023, London. Feasibility Study for Green Finance Facility has been completed. It explored different options to start the green finance mechanism in the KR.  In 2023, a landmark agreement was reached with the Ministry of Economy and the State Development Bank (SDB) to establish the green financing vehicle under the SDB, leveraging its substantial capital. This collaboration positions the SDB to catalyse and mobilize resources for the overall capital of the green financing vehicle.A total of 2,233 applications were collected from Jalal-Abad, Batken and Osh provinces for business acceleration programme. Subsequently, 860 applicants shortlisted and underwent business pre-acceleration courses targeted to raise the skills to develop business ideas and plans. At the final stage 78 beneficiaries passed successfully to the next acceleration stage in Osh, which selected 76 business projects for further funding. The monitoring showed that the total number of employed workers in the supported 76 projects is 378 people, of which 206 are women and 172 are men. At that, 111 of them are seasonal and 267 are permanent workers.
2024 Narrative: UNDP has provided support to transformative regulatory initiatives to drive sustainable development and economic competitiveness in Kyrgyzstan. Key achievements include the Green Economy Development Program (2024–2028) to promote sustainable growth, the E-commerce Park Law fostering digital innovation, and the Entrepreneurship Code creating a pro-business ecosystem. Moreover, the adoption of a National Methodology for Time Release Studies has significantly improved customs efficiency, positioning Kyrgyzstan as a stronger player in regional and global trade.On gender equality, UNDP’s SDG costing exercise identified a 2.4 billion KGS financing gap in gender-related targets and proposed innovative solutions, including gender-responsive budgeting, to close it. A draft methodological guide for tagging gender-specific expenditures is set to enhance transparency and accountability, ensuring resources advance women’s leadership, prevent violence, and promote parity in decision-making. These strategic interventions underscore UNDP’s commitment to fostering inclusive and sustainable growth in Kyrgyzstan.

Plan name: United Nations Transitional Framework
Strategic priority: Strengthening Systems
Outcome: National systems are able to effectively plan for and implement inclusive recovery
Output: Data generation
Sub-Output: National and local authorities are equipped with evidence based data on youth perceptions and aspirations, to inform planning and broader work in support of youth engagement and role of young people in the recovery process
Description:
- Joint UNFPA/UNDP/MoYS nationwide research “Impact of War on Youth in Ukraine”, aimed to study the state of youth (14-34 y.o), in particular, socio-economic status, values and preferences with an emphasis on the impact of a full-scale invasion on the youth of Ukraine, factors contributing to the conflict or strengthening stability, how young people see their role in the state's recovery process.

- Youth Well-Being Index survey to be conducted in 5 targeted municipalities - a comprehensive monitoring tool to assess the level of well-being of youth in the municipality in 7 areas (education, health, economic opportunities, participation in political and public life, information and communication technologies, safety and security), in order to have evidence-based data for the implementation of youth policy at the local level.
Contributing partners: United Nations Population Fund
Implementation partners: United Nations Population Fund
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.
Geography: Ukraine, Odeska, Lvivska, Mykolaivska, Ivano-Frankivska, Ternopilska, Vinnytska, Dnipropetrovska, Kyivska, Khmelnytska, Chernihivska, Zaporizka, Chernivetska, Volynska
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2022 Narrative: In 2022, due to a full-scale invasion and war in Ukraine, in consultation with municipalities partners of YWBI project it was decided not to conduct the new cycle of YWBI surveys among young people. Only the city of Kremenchuk, which launched the third wave of the survey at the beginning of 2022 shortly before the start of hostilities, was able to continue and complete the survey in August 2022, resulting in engaging of 800 respondents among young people of Kremenchuk who assessed the state of the well-being of young people in the municipality. The city of Ternopil launched the YWBI survey in late December 2022 and expects to receive results by the end of January 2023.The expanded functionality of the new Youth Well-Being web platform, allowed partner municipalities to conduct other sociological surveys to determine the changed priorities areas of investment in youth development in the context of ongoing war and humanitarian response. Online survey on the needs of young people (including internally displaced persons) in the Chernivtsi urban territorial community (City of Chernivtsi, Korovii village, Chornivtsi village) was conducted with participation of a total of 719 respondents, with the purpose of using the results to plan the activities of the youth center of Chernivtsi "Youth Residence", aimed at addressing the needs of young people and promote the realization of their potential in the existing context.In partnership with one of the leading IT companies Youth Well-Being platform was supplemented with a new functionality with useful resources for young people, where a series of UNFPA thematic youth podcasts "MOLO has a question" and "Mentalochka" are presented.A joint UNFPA/UNDP nationwide research with the aim to understand the specific impacts of the war on young women and men and assess the prospects of young people’s participation in the humanitarian and recovery activities was launched in late 2022. The research will look on the impacts the war has and will have on young men and women; how young people see their current and future engagement in humanitarian and early recovery activities; discover issues that unite or divide different segments of young people; identify factors and trends that can cause or prevent conflict and insecurity; and to envisage potential scenarios for the country from the youth perspective. It is also expected to develop a list of policy recommendations on how to mainstream youth needs and use youth potential in the Ukraine’s National Recovery Plan
2023 Narrative: In late 2022, UNFPA Ukraine along with UNDP and the Ministry of Youth and Sports of Ukraine, conducted research titled "The Impact of War on Youth in Ukraine." The study focused on young people's socio-economic status, challenges, aspirations, values, and needs in the context of a full-scale invasion. The research aimed to assess the effects of war violence on youth, both internally displaced within Ukraine and those who left the country (est. 4.0 million in total), with a particular emphasis on vulnerable groups. The survey involved 2,604 young people aged 14-34 within Ukraine and 405 young people who relocated abroad due to the war. The survey results, officially presented in early 2023 through open discussions with government representatives, academia, and youth NGOs, have been instrumental in shaping program activities for youth by various stakeholders, including UN agencies, the Ministry of Youth and Sports of Ukraine, youth NGOs, and youth centers, all guided by an evidence-based approach.In 2023, considering the context of ongoing war, limited access to the statistical data and displacement of youth, 5 partner municipalities (Kremenchuk, Ternopil, Chernivtsi, Vinnytsia and Lutsk) were able to join the new cycle of Youth Well-Being Index survey and finalized the conduction of the monitoring of the state of well-being of young people in their communities. In total, 2317 respondents aged 14-35 participated in the YWBI survey during 2023. Local authorities, NGOs and policymakers can use the data received in order to make informed decisions and develop targeted youth policies and programs in their communities. Also, thanks to the expanded functionality of the YWBI platform, Chernivtsi urban territorial community conducted additional online survey (565 respondents aged 14-35 y.o.) in order to determine the priorities areas, challenges and needs of local youth in the context of ongoing war and humanitarian response. The results were used for planning the activities of the youth center of Chernivtsi "Youth Residence", aimed at addressing the needs of young people and promote the realization of their potential in the existing context.
2024 Narrative: Youth Well-Being Index (YWBI) 2024The Youth Well-Being Index (YWBI) project aimed to measure youth well-being at the municipal level and support evidence-based policymaking. Given the ongoing war, access to statistical data was severely limited, and youth displacement further complicated the process. As a result, only three partner municipalities—Dnipro, Kremenchuk, and Lviv—were able to participate in the latest YWBI survey cycle.In Dnipro, the survey was conducted between February and March 2024. Preliminary findings indicate:The highest indicator: Information and communication technologies (0.84, where 1 is the highest possible).The lowest indicator: Safety and security (0.42), highlighting a significant challenge for the municipality.These results emphasize the need for targeted interventions to enhance safety and security for young people in Dnipro. However, given the ongoing war, improving security conditions remains a complex issue requiring multi-sectoral coordination.In Lviv, the survey faced technical challenges on the platform and with partner businesses, preventing its successful implementation. As a result, no preliminary insights are available for Lviv at this stage.Youth Municipal Fund – LvivIn 2024, UNFPA supported the establishment of the Youth Municipal Fund as part of Lviv’s European Youth Capital initiatives. The Fund aims to strengthen municipal youth policy by mobilizing resources for youth-led initiatives and fostering sustainable engagement with key stakeholders, including:The Ministry of Youth and Sports of Ukraine,The All-Ukrainian Youth Fund,The Lviv City Council.The Fund’s membership includes five youth organizations working together to expand opportunities for young people in Lviv:Plast Lviv,Molodvizh.Center,Society Initiatives Institute,Lviv Open Lab,Foundation for Regional Initiatives (ФРІ).Key Achievements in 2024:Governance and Institutional FrameworkThe Fund successfully developed its charter and prepared the registration documents for the establishment of the Youth Public Union "Youth Fund Lviv".Outreach and VisibilityA brand book and website were created.A communication campaign was launched, reaching over 10,000 people.Partnerships and Resource Mobilization27 local businesses signed partnership agreements, ensuring sustainable financial support for youth programs.The Fund operates on a model where businesses allocate 10-50% of sales from jointly developed products to finance youth initiatives.Planned Interventions and Focus Areas:The Fund is designed to channel its resources into three key areas:Professional fulfillment of young people,Addressing the consequences of war,Promoting a culture of mental health care.The Fund aims to develop its interventions through a grant-based program, enabling young people to design and implement projects aligned with these priority areas. However, in 2024, no grant programs were launched, as the focus was on establishing the Fund’s legal and institutional framework.Importantly, the Fund integrates demographic resilience into its long-term strategy, ensuring that youth programming responds to war-driven demographic shifts. Future initiatives will target displaced youth, community cohesion, and sustainable youth-led development in conflict-affected areas.

Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 4.3 Output 4.3. By 2025, the national social protection system is strengthened to deliver progressively universal inclusive and gender-responsive social security, social protection benefits and social services to address all forms of poverty, violence, social exclusion and other vulnerabilities , 2.2 Output 2.2. National institutions have enhanced capacities to generate robust systematic evidence to measure SDG progress and align national and sectorial policies, programmes/plans and budgets with SDG indicators, 4.1 Output 4.1. By 2025, capacities of health system and stakeholders are strengthened to implement efficient and transparent, innovative and inclusive Universal Health Coverage-focused policies and programmes, comprehensive responses to health emergencies and to promote a healthy lifestyle and health literacy among all age groups as well as quality professional development opportunities and a decent work environment for healthcare employees.
2023 Narrative: Over 80 public officials from different ministries and agencies strengthened their capacity in Program Based Budgeting (PBB) and Results Based Management (RBM) from the ministries of preschool and public education, health, employment, finance as well as from academia and various agencies under the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan. Total 18 national trainers were selected to continue with strengthening capacity of the national partners in PBB and RBM. Assessment, recommendations, and manuals were developed on how to advance PBB and RBM. UNICEF-UNDP joint work to support the Ministry of Economy and Finance proves that strategic planning capacities with sound results frameworks at various levels of public administration (national/strategic, regional, sectoral, institutional) are critical prerequisites for implementation of PBB in Uzbekistan.   UNICEF’s contribution in joint work under Global Flagship Finance Initiative was significant. At the initial stage UNICEF CO was swift to pitch to RO that national partners have been requesting continued support following successful accomplishment of UN Joint Programme to establish Integrated National Financing Framework (INFF). This was well supported by UNICEF ECARO through initiating discussions with and obtaining support of UNDP RO. Later, at the implementation stage UNICEF lead both programme implementation and administration of received funds.  Also, it is worth mentioning that the work was built on the extensive experience and comparative advantage of both UNICEF and UNDP: while UNICEF leveraged its strong expertise in development of key performance/programme outcome/output indicators for social sectors, as well as PF4C Global Framework to link them with the budgets, UNDP brought its extensive experience towards supporting the Government’s PFM reform agenda pertaining to SDG Financing (SDG budget tagging, SDG bonds, Tax for SDGs initiative etc.). UNICEF-UNDP joint work under Global Flagship Finance Initiative demonstrated One UN approach in action. It has complemented the work that both agencies have been conducting to support the government of Uzbekistan in establishing the Integrated National Financing Framework (INFF) and provided additional inputs for finalizing the SDG Financing Strategy. It also opened new opportunities for continued and closer partnership around ensuring coherence and coordination of conceptually interconnected reforms in strategic planning, budget management at all levels of public administration. Last but not least, the partnership to some extent allowed to gain a stronger voice in the PFM Working Group within the framework of Country Platform, co-chaired by Agency for Strategic Reforms under the President of Uzbekistan and World Bank.
2024 Narrative: UNICEF supported the adoption of the resolution by the cabinet of ministers on result-based budgeting implementation. This contributed to the strengthening of the PFM system and equipped the government with tools and processes to plan, budget, and monitor public resources more efficiently, transparently, and equitably, prioritizing the needs of vulnerable groups, including children.

2021 Narrative:
Under the capacity building activities targeting fight against trafficking in human beings- 21 representatives of relevant national institutions (MoI, Ministry of Finance and Social Welfare, Centers for Social Work) were trained on the dangers of human trafficking, VoTs identification and referral. Result: Service providers at municipal level, acquired skills, capacities and knowledge in supporting the most vulnerable groups and identifying the VoTs.

U okviru aktivnosti izgradnje kapaciteta nacionalnih institucija za borbu protiv trgovine ljudima – 21 predstavnika relevantnih državnih institucija (MUP, Ministarstvo finansija i socijalnog staranja, Centri za socijalni rad) obučeni su na temu: borba protiv trgovine ljudima, identifikacija i upućivanje žrtava trgovine ljudima. Rezultat: Pružaoci usluga na lokalnom/opstinskom nivou, su stekli vjestine i znanje koje ce koristiti u daljem radu i pruzanju podrske ranjivim kategorijama, kao i u identifikaciji zrtava trgovine ljudima.
2022 Narrative: IOM and NGO Defendologija implemented a 3-month long awareness raising campaign on dangers of trafficking in human beings which consisted of conducting 16 workshops in elementary and high schools and 4 workshops in Roma and Egyptian settlements, organizing Art competition, and conducting research on perception of the public on the topic of human trafficking (in 6 municipalities face to face and nationwide online). The aim of the campaign was to raise awareness on dangers of human trafficking among the youth, but also reach general population. Through the campaign 1802 persons were reached.U saradnji sa NVO Defendologija, IOM je implementirao tromjesečnu kampanju podizanja svijesti o rizicima trgovine ljudima koja se sastojala iz 16 radionica održanih u osnovnim i srednjim školama i 4 radionice u RE zajednicama: organizovana su umjetnička takmičenja i sprovedeno istraživanje percepcije javnosti na temu trgovine ljudima (uživo u 6 opština i online na nivou države). Cilj kampanje bilo je podizanje svijesti o rizicima trgovine ljudima među mladima ali i ostalom populacijom. Doseg ove kampanje je bio 1802 osobe.

Plan name: United Nations Transitional Framework
Strategic priority: Strengthening Systems
Outcome: National systems are able to effectively plan for and implement inclusive recovery
Output: Institutional capacity development
Sub-Output: Stronger, more resilient, and sustainable CSOs, especially at the local level, promote human rights, accountability and good governance during resilience building and recovery process, while CSO-relevant policies and sustaining the government youth machinery create an enabling environment for the civil society and youth engagement in the country’s recovery.
Contributing partners: Government of Denmark
Implementation partners: Ukraine Ministry of Youth and Sports
SDG Targets: 5.5 Ensure women's full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life,10.2 By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.,16.7 Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.,16.b Promote and enforce non-discriminatory laws and policies for sustainable development.

Geography: Ukraine, Zakarpatska, Lvivska, Rivnenska, Mykolaivska, Ivano-Frankivska, Ternopilska, Zhytomyrska, Volynska, Donetska, Vinnytska, Dnipropetrovska, Zaporizka, Luhanska, Poltavska, Kharkivska, Sumska, Odeska, Khmelnytska, Khersonska, Chernivetska, Cherkaska, Kyiv city, Chernihivska, Kirovohradska, Kyivska
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: UNDP promoted meaningful youth inclusion in the recovery planning process through the implementation of Dialogues of victory initiatives. A total of 597 young people (385 women, 212 men) took part in 30 facilitated dialogue sessions, resulting in informed proposals and recommendations to the local authorities underlining the need to strengthen youth engagement in the recovery planning and reconstruction processes. In addition, 10 civic initiatives on young IDPs integration, young people’s mental wellbeing and development of their potential were developed and implemented by the participants at community level with the support of the UNDP. The Action Plan for Open Government Initiative was adopted in a participatory manner with UNDP support. To increase the accessibility of legal aid provision, 8 field visits were conducted to ensure that legal support also reaches vulnerable groups including people with disabilities, elderly and IDPs in remote communities. Overall, 87 people (61 women and 26 men) benefited from legal support provided by UNDP through CSOs.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, UNDP Ukraine made substantial progress in empowering youth and strengthening civil society. Through the third iteration of the "VidNOVA:UA" programme, in partnership with All Ukrainian Youth Center and Ministry of Youth and Sports, UNDP engaged 23 teams from 16 regions, training them in project management and critical thinking. This initiative led to the renovation of over 2,270 square meters of space into vibrant, free youth centers, benefiting 713 participants from 24 youth exchanges. These efforts were crucial in rebuilding youth infrastructure and fostering social cohesion.UNDP also worked on amplifying youth voices through the “Dialogues of Victory” programme. In collaboration with CSO partner organizations and 20 youth councils, 20 dialogue events gathered 608 participants to discuss the recovery and future development of their communities.To further support youth, UNDP conducted the second Impact of War on Youth study, shedding light on the challenges facing young people in Ukraine and abroad amidst the ongoing war.In higher education, UNDP supported efforts of the National Agency for Corruption Prevention and CSO “Anti-corruption Headquarters” to integrate an Anti-Corruption and Integrity course into the curricula of 67 universities across Ukraine, promoting transparency and better governance.In partnership with the National Agency for Civil Service, UNDP launched a pilot internship programme for youth, aimed at strengthening capacity of local governance bodies in 9 communities to organize and implement internships for young people. To ensure greater social cohesion and transparency, UNDP supported the development of the Kyiv City Civil Society Development Programme for 2025-2027, addressing key concerns of civil society and fostering open dialogue with local authorities.Additionally, with UNDP support 4,233 vulnerable individuals in receiving legal aid.Finally, UNDP supported civic engagement during the process of creation of local recovery plans in 10 communities, facilitating inclusive decision-making through 40 workshops and 10 forums.

2021 Narrative: Newly hired young people may not be aware of labour regulations, or of how these relate to their own employment.  Being eager or desperate to find a job, they accept any available offer, even if it comes without an employment contract or the benefits of social security and labour protection.  The mobile application on Rights of Youth at Work (available on iOS and Android mobile systems) comes as a solution, bringing information within easy reach, in a format conducive to learning for this generation.

2021 Narrative:
Through the cooperation with the Association of Youth with Disabilities and Special Olympics Montenegro, a number of programmes were developed to support adolescents and youth with disabilities through the pandemic, including education, social and legal support, as well as an app for Special Olympics athletes to train at home.  With the Association of Scouts of Montenegro, programmes were implemented to support skills building, as well as well-being and mental health support for adolescents during the pandemic. 	

Kroz saradnju sa Udruženjem mladih sa hendikepom Crne Gore i Specijalnom Olimpijadom Crne Gore, razvijeno je više programa za podršku adolescentima i mladima sa invaliditetom tokom pandemije. Programi uključuju obrazovnu, socijalnu i pravnu podršku, kao i aplikaciju koja omogućava sportistima Specijalne Olimpijade da treniraju od kuće.  Sa Savezom izviđača Crne Gore implementirani su programi razvoja vještina, kao i podrške mentalnom zdravlju za adolescente tokom pandemije.

2021 Narrative:
UNICEF young reporters continued being at the heart of UNICEF digital and public comms and advocacy strategy giving it a youth voice on all child rights issues. They continued producing teen reports for Wadada News Montenegro, a weekly TV news for youth broadcast in prime time before the evening news on the national public service TV on weekends. They also spoke live in media, at our events and did live social media reporting on a variety of child rights issues. The most visited and the most shared web-contents in 2021 were COVID-19 fact-checking analysis made by UNICEF young reporters. The key highlight of their engagement in 2021 was the movie My Life, which they produced with peers from all over the country and which was broadcast at UNICEF’s 75th anniversary on December 11, 2021. As a result, 1 in 4 Montenegrin citizens noticed UNICEF young reporters in 2021 and 85% consider them to be a good role-model for youth.

UNICEFovi mladi reporteri nastavili su da budu u srcu UNICEFove digitalne i komunikacione strategije dajući mu glas mladih o pitanjima prava djeteta. Nastavili su da prave vijesti za TV dnevnik za mlade Wadada Vijesti Crna Gora koji se, svakog vikenda, emituje prije glavnog dnevnika za odrasle na javnom servisu. Mladi reporteri su uživo govorili u medijima i na UNICEFovim događajima, dok su na društvenim mrežama izvještavali su o brojnim pitanjima prava djeteta. Najposjećenije stranice na sajtu UNICEF-a CG su njihove analize tačnosti informacije o koronavirusu. To su ujedno i sadržaji sa sajta koji su se najviše dijelili tokom 2021. Kulminacija rada mladih reportera bila je produkcija filma Moj život, u okviru kojeg su pričali sa mladima širom Crne Gore, a koji je prikazan na proslavi 75. rođendana UNICEF-a, tj. 11. decembra 2021. Kao rezultat, svaki četvrti građanin CG primijetio je UNICEFove mlade reportere, a 85% ih smatra dobrim uzorom za mlade u zemlji.
2022 Narrative: Apart from being the leaders of UNICEF’s TikTok and Instagram accounts, an inclusive group of UNICEF Montenegro Young Reporters participated actively in a public debate on key child rights issues. 129 media reports with their voices were generated during the last year. As a result, 28% of Montenegrin citizens noticed them and 85% consider them to be a good role model for young people. The number of UNICEF Montenegro social media followers increased by 10% from 110,545 to 121,384.

Plan name: United Nations Development Assistance Framework
Output: Output 2.1.4 - State institutions and communities, particularly youth and women, have new frameworks, capabilities, and programmes to prevent threats to sustainable peace
Sub-Output: 2.1.4.3 - Strengthen community resilience to prevent violent extremism, including through dialogue and involvement of youth, women, religious leaders, civil society activists, local authorities and the police to jointly design and implement local initiatives aimed at prevention of radicalization
Description: Within UN Women project 'Inclusive governance and Justice system for Preventing Violent Extremism'. UNFPA integrated civic education in 8 pilot vocational schools, 11 madrasas (religious schools), and worked on building dialogue platforms at the local level in 11 pilot communities.                                                              1) Integration civic education in 8 pilot vocational schools was possible due to several activities, such as conducting needs assessment in the vocational schools, developing civic education guide, students' workbook on the civic education, training for teachers on using the guide, piloting the guide, developing an evaluation system to evaluate the civic competences of students, and developing podcasts on using the evaluation system. All products were developed jointly with the Republican Methodological and Scientific Center, Association of Primary Technical Education both under the Ministry of Education and Science; 2) Integration of civic education in 11 madrasas required the same algorithm. In addition, there was developed a civic education app, conducted Olympiad among the madrasah students and video lessons were produced on the civic education jointly with the State Commission on Religious Affairs and Muftiyat;   3) Dialogue at the local level was aimed to improve the resilience at the community level (pilot 11 communities). 33 groups of religious men, women leaders and civic activists were formed, who were later trained on PVE, peacebuilding, gender equality and tolerance. After two rounds of trainings, each group separately and jointly implemented local initiatives focusing on promoting tolerance and gender equality. The trainings and initiatives were coordinated and implemented jointly with the State Commission on Religious Affairs and Ministry of Interior.
Agency abbreviations: UN Women, UNDP, UNESCO, UNFPA, UNICEF, UNODC
Agencies: UN Women, United Nations Children's Fund, United Nations Development Programme, United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation, United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, United Nations Population Fund
Contributing partners: Government of Japan, The UN Secretary-General’s Peacebuilding Fund (UN Peace Fund)
Implementation partners: CSOs, Kyrgyzstan Ministry of Justice , Lithuania Ministry of Education and Science

2023 Narrative: The KAP (Knowledge, Attitudes, and Practices) study was developed, validated, and published by the National Youth Council of Moldova (CNTM), with significant involvement from the Ministry of Education and Culture (MEC). The MEC played an active role in the process, helping to disseminate the findings widely to ensure that the insights reached a broad audience. Additionally, CNTM created a comprehensive set of infographics to highlight and communicate the key insights and findings of the study effectively. These visual aids serve to enhance understanding and facilitate discussions around the study’s results, supporting efforts to promote informed decision-making among stakeholders.

Description: Support to the Child Rights Ombudsperson office to raise awareness on children's rights, including gender-specific concerns, regularly producing comprehensive reports on key emerging issues affecting children, with a specific focus on gender-related matters (how it affects girls and boys), and monitoring the implementation of Convention on the Rights of the Child (CRC) recommendations to ensure independent  child rights monitoring.
Contributing partners: United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: Moldova Peoples Advocate for Child's Right
SDG Targets: 16.2 End abuse, exploitations, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children.,16.b Promote and enforce non-discriminatory laws and policies for sustainable development.

Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: The rights of boys and girls will be considered, as appropriate.  However, the sub-output does not seek to address root causes of gender inequality
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Collaborating with the child rights ombudsperson significantly advances human rights by promoting awareness, influencing policy, monitoring compliance, ensuring access to justice, engaging stakeholders, and building capacity. This partnership creates a unified approach to protecting and enhancing children's rights, making a substantial impact on their realization
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
Sustaining peace marker narrative: The activity is conflict sensitive in response to the conflict analysis. The rights of children in breakaway region will be considered
2023 Narrative: In July 2023 a new Child Rights Ombudsperson was appointed by the Parliament of the Republic of Moldova to ensure regular independent child rights monitoring. UNICEF is supporting the Child Rights Unit of the People’s Advocate office to strengthen its capacity in elaboration of the Annual and thematic reports observing children’s rights, as well as ensure child participation through the existing mechanisms, i.e. Children’s council created under the Child Rights Ombudsperson. Support provided to organization of National Human Rights Forum that gathered about 70 adolescents to discuss key emerging issues and embed children’s rights perspective in policy and decision making.  UNICEF partnered with the Council of Europe to advance human and child rights agenda in the country. National Human Rights forum generated discussions around emerging child rights issues resulted also from the national study implemented in collaboration with the Child Rights Ombudsperson.In October 2023 the Office of the People’s Advocate of Moldova (OPA) was re- accredited with A status.
2024 Narrative: UNICEF partnered with the Child Rights Ombudsperson to advance the child rights agenda, focusing on developing the Annual Report, collecting evidence on emerging issues, and addressing key areas such as CRC recommendations, children’s participation in decision-making, and enhancing complaint mechanisms. In November 2024, the National Forum on Children’s Rights gathered about 70 children, including human rights defenders, Roma, refugees, children from the Transnistrian region, and children with disabilities. This forum provided a platform for practical discussions with public authorities on the role and involvement of children and duty-bearers in identifying problems and finding appropriate solutions.

Outcome: Community Recovery interventions and nexus approaches in key sectors address displacement and strengthen individual and community resilience

Description: The project will primarily aim to build and strengthen the functionality, capacity and knowledge of local institutions serving youth and women, including IDPs and returnees. The initiative aims to generate at least 1200 jobs for youth and women, including IDPs and returnees in western Ukraine.
Contributing partners: Government of Austria
Implementation partners: Ukraine Ministry of Economic Development and Trade
SDG Targets: 9.1 Develop quality, reliable, sustainable and resilient infrastructure, including regional and transborder infrastructure, to support economic development and human well-being, with a focus on affordable and equitable access for all.
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
LNOB groups targeted: Youth, Internally Displaced Persons, Women & Girls
2023 Narrative: Identification and ranking of priority regions (oblasts) in Western Ukraine – as a result, three oblasts were chosen for project interventions including Lviv, Ivano-Frankivsk and VolynAssessment and diagnostic of the entrepreneurship support and educational ecosystem and market analysis – TVETs, business support institutions and universities in the three selected oblasts were assessed and diagnosed through surveys; potential institutional partners were identified and contacted (target: 10 institutions)
2024 Narrative: Entrepreneurship training and business coaching Initiatives: ·        A total of 8 sessions were held, engaging 100 participants ·        Business coaching programs launched in Lviv, Ivano Frankivsk and Volyn, focusing on entrepreneurship development for youth, women, and internally displaced persons (IDPs)Institutional Collaboration: ·        Established partnerships with key Business Support Institutions (BSIs), including the Lviv Center for Entrepreneurship Development and the Volyn Chamber of Commerce and Business Association of Ivano-Franskivsk and more (total 7).·        Joint work plans and needs assessments were developed to align resources and strategies.HP LIFE Training: ·        HP LIFE introductory trainings were organized for over 400 participants from pilot regions·        HP LIFE tools were launched at Lviv Polytechnic University, with three courses adapted into Ukrainian, integrating entrepreneurial skills into academic programs. ·        12 trainers from educational and business support organizations trained in HP LIFE methodology (2 TOTs – Vienna and Krakow); ·        Adaptation of HP LIFE courses into Ukraine’s Learning Management Systems, ensuring accessibility for a broad audiencePublic Engagement: ·        Partnership events supported and attended: 1) Molodvizh event in collaboration with the Lviv City Council boosting youth entrepreneurship initiatives, 2) Business forum organized by Business Association of Ivano-Frankivsk. Communication Campaigns: ·        Initiated project branding, including a website and promotional materials, with a dedicated communication expert hired.·        Organized an introductory meeting with the H.E. Ambassador of Austria to Ukraine for the youth entrepreneurship training within a partner institution TechStartUp School to highlight the activities.

2023 Narrative: Through the UNICEF-supported #BeSafe and #Volunteers4Climate programmes, more than 3 million people accessed information on DRR and Climate Action (CA). Additionally, 28,000 children and 3,600 teachers enhanced their DRR and CA capacities. This year, Kazakhstan and four other Central Asian countries signed the Regional Strategy on Promoting Sustainable Development, Culture, and Children and Youth Engagement in Climate Change Agenda – a strategy developed by youth, including UNICEF-supported youth from Kazakhstan – during the ‘Central Asian Forum on Children and Youth in Action – Climate Change’.

2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNICEF continued shaping uSupport mental health online platform. The platform was successfully tested with young people and mental health providers, considered as necessary and user-friendly. The Ministry of Health agreed to pilot it in 2024, in three regions, involving its mental health workers, with UNICEF support. This will be supported by marketing campaign. In collaboration with the National Edinburgh University and ECARO, UNICEF analyzed via focus group discussions with adolescent girls and boys on how they are seeking support online on mental health, what language they use, and with whom apart from searching online they have emotional connect to share their thoughts and feelings around mental health. The analysis will help developing a monitoring tool and effective approaches to increase their access to information on mental health and support services to improve their wellbeing.

2023 Narrative: Launched in 2022, UNICEF Talks, which promotes youth voices in a TED talk format, has become an important platform for young people to share their experiences and empower their peers. With 145 in-person participants, a reach of 146,000 on social media, and 150,000 reels views in 2023, UNICEF Talks has become a UNICEF flagship event in Kazakhstan. In 2023, UNICEF launched the ‘Stay True to Your Dreams’ campaign in partnership with the Kazakhstan Football Federation (KFF); the National Commission on Women’s Rights, Family and Population Policy; and the National Volunteer Network to encourage young girls to pursue their career dreams regardless of gender stereotypes. Women from different professions spoke about their work and why they decided to be bold and build their careers.

Gender marker narrative: The program is designed to empower both boys and girls to actively engage in decision-making processes within their communities and to participate in volunteering activities. While all activities integrate a gender-sensitive approach—ensuring diversity in terms of gender, ethnicity, and the inclusion of young people from vulnerable groups—the program does not directly address the specific barriers to participation that stem from gender-related issues. In terms of monitoring and evaluation, the program collects quantitative data disaggregated by gender. However, no qualitative analysis has been introduced to explore the participation dynamics from a gender perspective, which could provide deeper insights into how gender influences engagement in the program.
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Sustained and inclusive economic and social development
Outcome: Outcome 2: Quality Services for All
Output: Output 2.3 Social protection of all persons in need
Sub-Output: Support to ICF-based assessment for additional educational, health and social support to children and youth
Description: Support will be provided for full implementation of the ICF-based functional assessment system for children and youth, including capacity development for establishing seven regional expert bodies for functional assessment located in Strumica, Bitola, Gostivar, Kumanovo, Stip, Veles and Ohrid, covering the needs of the South-West, Pelagonija, Polog, North-East, East, and Vardar planning regions. The programme will enhance capacities for functional assessment of children and youth, including by supporting capacity development for professionals that will be engaged in the bodies, present the new model for functional assessment to service providers (including Centers for Social Work, schools and kindergartens), as well as parents in the four regions, and support rapid disability assessments and respective plan to provide support services. Technical assistance is also provided for initiating and coordinating legal changes, needed for functional assessment to become a single entry point for children and youth with disability to access support services.
Contributing partners: Government of the United States of America, United Nations Children's Fund, United Nations Partnership on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities
Implementation partners: North Macedonia Ministry of Education and Science, North Macedonia Ministry of Health, North Macedonia Ministry of Labour and Social Policy, North Macedonia National Coordination Body on Implementation of the CRPD
SDG Targets: 1.3 Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.,10.2 By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.
SDG Goals: 1 No Poverty, 4 Quality Education, 10 Reduced Inequalities
Geography: Ohrid, Polog, Southwestern, Southeastern, Gostivar, Vardar, Eastern, Shtip, Veles, Northeastern, North Macedonia, Republic of, Pelagonija, Kumanovo, Strumica, Bitola
QCPR function: Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Other (including coordination), Normative Support
Gender marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to gender equality/women’s empowerment
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
UNICEF supported North Macedonia to further advance towards switching to functional assessment based on the International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (ICF) as a single entry-point for children and youth to access various support services in the fields of health, education, and social protection. As a result of the progressive advocacy, the two bodies for functional assessments based on the ICF, covering the Skopje region, and the National expert body for functional assessment that were created with UNICEF support were taken over by the state healthcare system. Namely, the Public Health Center (PHC) Skopje, opened a new Service for functional assessment of children and youth up to 26 years of age, and from January 2021 it started with provision of regular assessments of children and youth from the Skopje region. In the period May-October 2021, with support from UNICEF, training and mentoring on ICF-based functional assessments was conducted in Pelagonija, Polog and South-West regions, involving almost fifty professionals. With UNICEF advocacy the PHC Skopje has engaged twelve of the persons whose capacity has been developed to staff three new regional functional assessment bodies in Strumica, Bitola and Gostivar. UNICEF also supported fifteen workshops to present the new model for functional assessment to service providers – including Centers for Social Work (CSW), schools and kindergartens – as well as parents in the three targeted regions.

UNICEF coordinated with line ministries and other relevant institutions the drafting of amendments to the Social Protection Law, Child Protection Law, Health Insurance Law, Healthcare Law and Primary Education Law in order to consolidate the provision of functional assessments for children and youth in line with the ICF. The amendments were approved by the Government and were put on the agenda of Parliament in December 2021. UNICEF also supported the revision of the draft Rulebook on ICF-based disability assessments, so that it is aligned with the three line-ministries – Health, Education and Science, and Labour and Social Policy – as well as other relevant institutions. 

While UNICEF has supported the establishment of functional assessment bodies which cover four of the eight regions of North Macedonia, children and youth outside the covered regions could not complete such an assessment and were thus not eligible to obtain access to educational and personal assistants. This resulted in difficulties in exercising their right to education, as well as problems in carrying out their everyday activities. To address this, UNICEF supported the creation of a special team to conduct ICF-based disability assessment to children from vulnerable communities in locations that are not covered by the regional assessment bodies.
2022 Narrative: In 2022 UNICEF developed national capacities for expansion of the human-rights based model of disability and needs assessment of children and youth in in the North-East, East, Vardar and South-West planning regions. The initiated establishment of bodies for functional assessment in these regions will complete the introduction of the new model as a single-entry point for support services and benefits throughout the country. With UNICEF advocacy and support, the amendment to the Healthcare Law was adopted in Parliament, which ensured legal basis for the sustainability and the continued functioning of the functional assessment service, with a national and 10 regional functional assessment bodies for children and youth. UNICEF also supported the revision of the draft Rulebook on ICF-based disability assessments, so that it is aligned with the policies of the three line-ministries – Health, Education and Science, and Labour and Social Policy – as well as other relevant institutions. The new model for functional assessment was also presented to service providers – including Centers for Social Work, schools and kindergartens – as well as parents in the four regions.
2023 Narrative: UNICEF developed capacities for expansion of the human-rights based model of disability assessment resulting in launch of two new disability assessment bodies in the North-East and Vardar regions. With UNICEF advocacy and support, the Rulebook on ICF-based disability assessment was adopted by the three line-ministries – MoH, MoES, and MoLSP.
2024 Narrative: Progress was achieved in establishing a system for human rights-based disability assessment of children and youth, as a single-entry point to support services and benefits. UNICEF supported the establishment of new regional functional assessment bodies in Shtip and Ohrid, expanding the coverage to all eight regions of the country. The number of functional assessment professionals in the bodies by 72% and permanent employees by 70%. The number of assessed children has risen by 38% in 2024 compared to the previous year, and the assessments enabled each child to access approximately five different support services and programmes.

Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 4.1 Output 4.1. By 2025, capacities of health system and stakeholders are strengthened to implement efficient and transparent, innovative and inclusive Universal Health Coverage-focused policies and programmes, comprehensive responses to health emergencies and to promote a healthy lifestyle and health literacy among all age groups as well as quality professional development opportunities and a decent work environment for healthcare employees.
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2024 Narrative: UNICEF supported the Ministry of Health, MOPSE, and the Youth Agency in promoting adolescent participation platforms such as U-Report and the IOGT platform to engage adolescents in shaping policies and services related to health and mental well-being. Through these platforms, around 4,000 adolescents participated in U-Report surveys addressing sensitive issues such as HPV vaccination and mental health stigma. These surveys assessed adolescents' awareness of mental health and HPV vaccination, their perceived influence on decision-making, and barriers to vaccination. Additionally, the IOGT platform was updated with new articles and videos on topics like mental health, bullying, and reproductive health, resulting in a significant increase in its user base from 264,000 to 648,000. These initiatives enhanced adolescent participation and provided valuable insights for policy development.

LNOB groups targeted: Other, Persons With Disabilities, Refugees & Asylum Seekers, Women & Girls, Youth, Children , Migrants
2023 Narrative: UNICEF continued to partner with the Ministry of Education (MOE) and other national stakeholders in advancing 21st century skills. Special focus was on integrating social-emotional skills into the common secondary and higher vocational education.The Universal 21st Century Skills Concept was developed by experts from leading national institutions in cooperation with international experts. Joint work allowed to align the Concept with international guidelines and better define the strategic directions, mechanisms, and conditions for the formation of universal competencies of children and young people at different levels of education. The Concept embraced the general framework of the universal 21st century competencies developed within Belarus educational system, with a particular focus on social-emotional skills (SES). Based on the Concept, an Action Plan to build SES in Children and Young People for 2023-2026 was drafted. The Action Plan clearly defined the main interventions and implementing partners for each block and was submitted to the MOE for endorsement.International expertise was highly appreciated by the National Institute of Education (NIE) and the Republican Institute of Professional Education (RIPE) during development of the SES ME tool comprising 25 criteria and 94 indicators to measure 3 main SES components: emotional regulation, communication, and cooperation. The ME tool was co-created with adolescents from technical vocational colleges who provided recommendations and feedback. The tool will be piloted in 2024.To ensure the quality and sustainability of the SES integration in the education process the SES normative framework was supplemented by development of an in-service training programme for general secondary and technical vocational education teachers and methodological recommendations for different groups (e.g. teachers, administrations, parents) on how to integrate SES in the education process in schools and colleges.The in-service training programme for pedagogues was complemented with a curriculum for an elective courses on advancement of social-emotional skills among 3-4th and 6th-7th grade students and trainer guide developed by the NIE. The programme for pedagogues and the curriculum for school students will be piloted in 2024.

2023 Narrative: An assessment of youth needs was developed, and consultants were engaged to evaluate and report on the Strategy for Youth with UNICEF technical support. Ministry of Youth and Sport was also supported to evaluate and report on the Strategy for Sports, in order to develop the new Strategy for Sports. Technical and financial support in mapping providers of education, health and social protection services to adolescents, across 25 municipalities, is provided by UNICEF in partnership with the ILO in preparation of the EU Youth Guarantee in Montenegro, with a focus on those working with NEETs and young persons with disabilities, and poor, minority and excluded adolescents and young people. An in-depth analysis focusing on the needs of adolescents and young people was produced in collaboration with the Ministry of Sports and Youth. It was used to inform the new Youth Strategy and develop relevant policies and programmatic interventions, as well as serve as a basis for the budgeted action plans in collaboration with the ministry, youth organizations and other relevant stakeholders.
2024 Narrative: UNICEF Montenegro supported the Ministry of Sports and Youth in developing a new Strategy for Sports, with a focus on school sports and inclusion in sports. The Strategy was officially adopted by the Government of Montenegro in August 2024. Thanks to strong advocacy with the Ministry of Ecology, Sustainable Development and Northern Region Development, the Government of Montenegro signed the Declaration on Children, Youth and Climate Action. The already strong links with the Ministry for Sports and Youth resulted in the adoption of the Strategy for Sports, with UNICEF CO advocating for schools sports and inclusion – elements that were not present in the previous strategy.UNICEF is currently working with the Government on the development of the new Youth Law and the workplan.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework

Output: 4.5. Countering hate speech
Sub-Output: Strengthening the role of youth in promoting increased mutual understanding, constructive narrative, respect for diversity, and trust
Description: Support to young men and women in order to promote constructive and fact-based narratives, and contribute to building trust, intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity, gender equality and social cohesion in the region. In doing so, the project aims to address the priority conflict drivers of hate speech, divisive narratives, negative gender norms and a deficit of reconciliation within the region.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Contributing partners: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Faculty of Political Sciences Montenegro
SDG Targets: 16.10 Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: The project’s core thrust is to strengthen the engagement of young men and women – recognizing the crucial impact of traditional gender norms – across identity group lines and communities to promote constructive narratives and counter hate speech and patriarchal gender norms in order to increase inter-group dialogue, mutual understanding and gender equality.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Promoting human rights, especially of youth, reduces the risk of conflict and instability, and leads to sustainable peace
2023 Narrative: Building on the regional partnership between faculties of political science at the universities of Sarajevo, Belgrade and Montenegro, with the addition of Faculty of Philosophy, University of Banja Luka, the project launched the Regional Youth Academy on Constructive Narratives. The six-module academy strengthened capacities of 149 young people (118 women and 31 men) from Bosnia and Herzegovina, Serbia, and Montenegro to tackle issues of negative narratives and actively engage in the fight against harmful content, misinformation and manipulative content. Ten female students of the Faculty of Political Science attended the Youth Academy on Constructive Narrative. After completing the Academy, the students were divided into two teams and decided to create public advocacy campaigns directed against hate speech and aimed at promoting interculturality. The Academy was also an opportunity for an academic collaboration and knowledge exchange among regional experts in the field of Media and Information Literacy (MIL), while access to the OER platform (Open Educational Resource) will enable future use of these educational resources and tools within the faculties’ programmes.
