Sub-Output: (UNFPA) Strengthened capacity of the LPAs and National Youth Centers Network to developed evidence-based and budgeted youth action plans, and deliver quality programs and services for young people.
Description: During the last years, UNFPA supported the Ministry of Education and Research in designing and implementing national and local youth policies, expanding and building the capacity of the National Network of Youth Centers and of local public authorities to address youth work, youth budgeting and empower young people for active civic engagement and participation. UNFPA continues its support jointly with the Swiss Development Cooperation Office in Moldova. During 2023 - 2026, UNFPA is focusing on supporting Local Public Authorities to develop results-based youth action plans, strategies, or other sectoral planning documents applying a participatory approach; conduct analysis of the annual rayonal youth budgets and empower LPAs and other stakeholders to use available data; draft curriculum for the continuous training program for the youth workers based on the national standards and European competency framework developed; support the Network of Youth Centers in delivering their programmes and run mobile youth work to reach out to young people from rural and vulnerable communities with programs on youth participation, personal development, information, and reference to services. UNFPA is also supporting the work and capacity building of the National Youth Agency that was recently created by the Ministry of Education and Research.
Contributing partners: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation, UNFPA Core funds
Implementation partners: Moldova Ministry of Education and Research, Moldova National Youth Council, Moldova Probono, Moldova local public administration, Moldova youth centers, Moldova, Centrul media pentru tineri, National Youth Development Agency, Terre des Hommes
SDG Targets: 4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,5.5 Ensure women's full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life
QCPR function: Policy Advice and Thought Leadership, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Data Collection and Analysis, Normative Support, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: The Project aims to empower all adolescents and youth, regardless of gender. While we do not specifically target any gender, we are committed to ensuring that girls have equal opportunities to participate and engage in civic life.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: The program promotes youth rights to active citizenship, empowering young people to engage in and participate in the country's democratic processes. It also supports the government in developing national and local policies and programs that benefit young people.
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
Sustaining peace marker narrative: The programme has no direct interventions to sustain the peace, besides the work with young people with different backgrounds, regions, etc. that contributes to social cohesion.
2023 Narrative: In collaboration with the Ministry of Education and Research, the National Youth Agency, with funds from Swiss Development Cooperation and other key partners, the following key results were achieved during 2023 to advance youth civic engagement and participation:Five rayonal public authorities (LPAs) were supported and empowered in developing action plans and local youth budgets through the involvement of young people and based on the identified local needs. Since the support programme was launched in 2019, 19 LPAs out of 35 received comprehensive support from UNFPA, which is 54,28%. The programme will continue in 2024 and further reach out to at least 65% of LPAs. To support evidence-based planning in the youth sector, UNFPA conducted an annual analysis of rayon youth sector budgets showing the trend per each rayon (district compared to previous years and other districts). The network of Youth Centers was further supported in strengthening professional skills, programs and mobilizing young people at the local level. https://moldova.unfpa.org/en/news/nicoleta-reaboi-today-girls-our-country-have-opportunity-learn-express-their-opinions-and-lead In 2023, the Youth Centers Network expanded and counted 60 centers throughout the country. Only in the first semester of 2023, the Youth Centers reached over 28,000 young people (for the second-semester data is not yet available), including young refugees, young people from rural areas, young people with disabilities, etc. To align the youth work in Moldova to European standards UNFPA supports the National Youth Agency in developing a continuous training programme for youth workers, the activity will be completed in 2024. The annual Youth Workers Forum was co-supported by UNFPA. More than 200 young people and representatives of youth organizations advocated for youth role as agents of change during International Youth Day with UNFPA support https://moldova.unfpa.org/en/news/%E2%80%9Etrain-youth%E2%80%9D-gathered-young-people-all-over-country-ungheni-celebrate-international-youth-day 17 civic initiatives of young people from the country were supported methodologically and financially in 2023. More than 380 young people teamed up together with Youth Centers, teachers, and civil servants to transform for the better the localities in which they live. Gender stereotypes and discrimination, environmental crisis, lack of recreational spaces for youth, vocational orientation - these are just a few of the issues identified by young people across the country in the 'YouCreate' program. https://moldova.unfpa.org/en/news/young-people-solve-problems-local-level-17-initiatives-implemented-youth-their-communities
2024 Narrative: UNFPA in collaboration with the Ministry of Education and Research, the National Youth Agency, with funds from Swiss Development Cooperation and other key partners, achieved the following key results during 2024 to advance youth civic engagement and participation:In 2024, 8 districts from the country benefited from coaching and mentorship in development of result-oriented local youth action plans, local youth strategies, local youth programs. The support program for LPAs provided a detailed analysis of the situation of young people in the targeted districts and training for authorities, local youth organizations and young people active in the community in strategic planning of youth activities and participatory budgeting. It also provided individualized assistance for the development of a results-oriented action plan, adapted to local needs and tailored to the available resources for the next calendar year.  Since the Support Programe for LPAs was launched in 2019, 22 LPAs out of 35 received comprehensive support from UNFPA, which is more than 63% of LPAs.  To support evidence-based planning in the youth sector, UNFPA conducted an annual analysis of rayon youth sector budgets showing the trend per each rayon (district compared to previous years and other districts). The Report for 2024 is available here. UNFPA supported the Youth Centers Network in strengthening youth workers professional skills, programs and mobilizing young people at the local level. Thus, in 2024, the Youth Centers Network expanded and counted 67 centers throughout the country. Only in the first semester of 2024, the Youth Centers reached over 43754 young people (for the second-semester data is not yet available), including young refugees, young people from rural areas, young people with disabilities, etc.In order to align the youth work system from Moldova to European standards, UNFPA Moldova continuously supports the National Youth Agency in implementing the road map on youth work curriculum development. Thus, during 2024 were developed and approved the National Qualifications Framework for youth workers and the National Occupational Framework. The ongoing support for road map implementation is planned also for 2025.The annual Youth Workers Forum (2024 edition) was co-supported by UNFPA. More than 2600 young people with fewer opportunities, from rural remote areas, attended non formal educational and recreational activities, including outdoor activities within the Mobile Youth Center Program, supported by UNFPA.  UNFPA supports youth participation and civic engagement, with voting being one of the most impactful ways for young people to make their voices heard and contribute to the country's development. In 2024, UNFPA supported implementation of the youth mobilization campaign "Drop Everything and Go Vote!”, organized by the Youth Centers Network with the National Youth Agency's guidance. This campaign was carried out with support from the United Nations Population Fund, Soros Foundation Moldova, and the Government of Switzerland. Thus, in recent national elections in the Republic of Moldova, youth voter turnout has increased. During the second round of the presidential elections on November 3, 2024, more than half of young people aged 18–25 (51.78%) and 26–35 (52.04%) cast their votes, maintaining the record turnout from the 2020 elections. The growing number of young voters results from sustained mobilization efforts and support through various opportunities and programs that encourage civic activism among youth. Young people are becoming more aware of their vote's power and ability to influence decision-making processes and actively participate in them.The potential to participate in change, think critically and use technology in a safe mode to the personal advantage were the key highlights of the series of public events organized in the frame of the International Youth Day, conducted with UNFPA support. The events were attended of more than 500 young people, representatives of youth organizations, LPAs and local youth led organizations. https://moldova.unfpa.org/ro/events/zit-2024-tinerii-pentru-spa%C8%9Bii-digitale-sigure-%C8%99i-incluzive

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Support national efforts to promote inclusive and gender transformative approaches to climate action, disaster risk management and environmental protection to conserve natural resources and leverage ecosystem benefits for sustainable human development (CLIMATE, ENERGY, DRM AND BIODIVERSITY)
Outcome: By 2027, the Kyrgyz Republic has started the transition to low-carbon development and risk-informed climate resilience, contributing to people’s fair and equitable access to ecosystem benefits and to empowerment of vulnerable communities in the governance of natural resources and disaster prevention
Output: Climate policy, financing, and awareness mechanisms are designed and implemented that support climate actions, with the full participation of women and men at all decision-making levels
Sub-Output: Supporting community-based climate-smart solutions in agriculture - including drip irrigation systems and disseminate agricultural inputs, installation of artificial glaciers for women and youth
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: Peace Building Funds
Implementation partners: Kyrgyz Ministry of Agriculture, Kyrgyz Ministry of Culture, Information, Sports and Youth Policy
SDG Targets: 1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.,1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.,2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.
Geography: Aravan, Kyrgyzstan, Jalal-Abad, Osh, Aksy, Ala-Buka
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 3 - Sustaining Peace is the principal objective
2023 Narrative: Within FAO support 313 women and 37 men trained on plant protection and water and soil saving technologies. 141 SHG (Self Help Groups) and LSG members, farmers, including 125 women exchanged on vegetable crops cultivation. The introduction of drought- and heat-resistant seeds, drip irrigation systems, and training on soil and water conservation, have increased awareness and adoption of climate change adaptation strategies and more efficient utilisation of natural resources which is crucial for decreasing tension at and across the border.•	Sustainable pasture management techniques coupled with alternative gender-sensitive income generation opportunities (production of vermicompost, processing of coarse wool) enhanced the potential of pastures and fostered dialogue and stability among communities. 20 women and 16 men participated in the final workshop and study tour to artificial glaciers. Of them, 9 are in 40-49 y.o.a; 12 in 50-59 y.o. and 15 in 60-69 y.o.a.   •	3 artificial glaciers are installed in remote pastures of Kara-Dobo of Kashka-Suu village, Kol of Olon-Bulak village and Kok-Sai of Kara-Bashat village of Aksy district, Jalal-Abad oblast. Six e-pasture fencing are installed in pastures of Aksy, Alal-Buka and Aravan districts. 12 units of the two-wheel tractors, 12 units of the Fruit drying equipment, 700 kg of pasture crops, 6 units of wool processing machines delivered to SHG Associations.
2024 Narrative: ●15 young entrepreneurs will receive technical and financial support for the implementation of agro start-ups. 6 start-ups - 1000 USD worth technical support from the PBF project, 9 startups - from 2 banks (Aiyl Bank and Halyk Bank) and 2 private entrepreneurs. ●4 LSG developed gender-responsive local plans to address problems of garbage, which leads to pollution; conflicts between school children in two LSGs, violence against migrant children. ●One artificial glacier was installed in the Besh Bashat pasture of Kara Tobo village in Aksy district, as water source in dry and remote areas.

2021 Narrative: In progress. UNDP provided direct support on enhancing employment and entrepreneurship opportunities for more than 1,100 unemployed people (more than 45% of whom are women), business advisory and consultancy services, mentorship webinars and training sessions to around 9200 private sector representatives (more than 30% of whom are women). Moreover, with the aims of reducing the skills mismatch in the labour market, UNDP was actively engaged in enhancing the technical and vocational training curriculum of the Monocenters "Ishga Markhamat" under the Ministry of Employment and Labour Relations for demanded professions and competencies, which included reviewing and upgrading of the professional training programmes based on International WorldSkills Standards.
2022 Narrative: Promoting Youth Employment Project: The project successfully organized offline and online trainings for more than 444 MELR specialists (40% of them women) in the regions, of which 244 participants were offline and 200 participants were online. The trainings improved and deepened the Employment Support Centers' knowledge of soft skills and ensured the successful integration and delivery of career development services

Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 3 - Pillar 3: Democratic governance, rule of law and civic participation
Outcome: Outcome 3.1 - By 2022, women and men, girls and boys participate in decision-making and enjoy human rights, gender equality, effective, transparent and non-discriminatory public services
Output: Output 3.1.3 - Women and men, girls and boys are equipped with knowledge and skills to enjoy their human rights and have equal access to justice.
Sub-Output: 3.1.3.11 - Enhanced civic youth engagement and youth participation in decision-making at all levels
Description: Local initiatives of youth CSOs and non-formal youth groups in the area of democratization and human rights are supported with mentoring by CSO hubs
Contributing partners: Government of Denmark
Implementation partners: Ministry of Youth and Sports of Ukraine
SDG Targets: 16.7 Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
In close partnership with the Ministry of Youth and Sports of Ukraine, UNDP provided expertise and organizational support for the implementation of the Youth Worker Programme. During the reporting period 1,350 (1,053 women, 297 men) obtained knowledge and skills on how to use innovative tools to engage young men and women in community life, which is essential in view of the final stage of the decentralization reform. 
The First Youth TV Channel was established and functions as a unique communication platform for all youth workers throughout Ukraine, and already has 2,400 subscribers and 35K viewers on Facebook. 
Over 100 (60 duty bearers, 40 right holders) youth activists and public servants responsible for youth policy on subnational levels were engaged into online public discussion on the draft State Target Social Programme ‘Youth of Ukraine 2021-2025', organized by the UNDP on the request of the Ministry of Youth and Sports. Some 283 participants (81 men, 202 women) gained experience in and basic knowledge of volunteering by implementing 11 local initiatives and 17 volunteer events. Additionally, 38 partner organizations joined volunteer activities. The participants of local events received the opportunity to get acquainted with the activities of local organizations and join them as volunteers that boosted the organizational capacity of local NGOs, which often have low visibility among local residents. According to the Ukrainian Volunteer Service estimations, around 30-35% of participants still keep in touch with the organizations they met at the Volunteer School and participate in further activities. 
Seven subnational youth civic initiatives were implemented in Kyiv, Chernihiv, Kirovograd, Chernivtsi and Kherson oblasts, through which 831 young people (499 women, 332 men) were engaged in design and implementation of 21 civic education activities and 5 advocacy campaigns. The advocacy campaigns have resulted in adoption of 5 subnational youth policy documents which provide for establishing local youth councils, developing regulations on youth advisers in local administration, establishing competition of youth initiatives in the local administration, introducing volunteer management classes for university students and green waste management programmes at territorial community. 
According to the results of independent assessment of 44 youth-led initiatives supported by UNDP in 2017-2021, the initiatives contributed to the creation of community of people involved in the public and civic sectors who know how to engage young people.  Young people are now more inclined to believe that their ideas may come true. More than half of respondents, inspired by the experience, plan to continue their civic activity in follow-up initiatives. This implies an active search for new ideas and their implementation at the local level, or engagement as participants and volunteers (for more than a third of respondents). Still, one in ten participants engaged in youth civic initiatives is not motivated to participate in similar activities further.

2021 Narrative: PBF-funded project implemented by the three participating UN agencies (UNDP, UNFPA, OHCHR) experienced the 10-month delay in 2021 caused by the Government of Ukraine-initiated revision process and resulting in an unforeseen postponement of project activities and administrative processes. Since the (re-)signature of the (revised) project document at the end of October 2021, the three implementing agencies have initiated bilateral and joint technical meetings to develop the joint principles of engagement with target groups and stakeholders, the project’s implementation plan, including timeline, activities, jointly developed training curricula, and key advocacy messages. The implementation of planned activities will start in the first quarter of 2022.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Climate action, natural resources and disaster risk management
Outcome: Outcome 3: Healthy Environment
Output: Output 3.1 Low-emissions development and climate change resilience
Sub-Output: Design and implement evidence based communication for development initiatives on youth led climate action
Description: Conduct nation wide campaigns that increase public demand and youth engagement in creating environmental policies and practices that address climate change.
Contributing partners: Government of Sweden, Makedonski Telekom, United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: North Macedonia Ministry of Education and Science, North Macedonia Ministry of Environment and Physical Planning
SDG Targets: 4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.,13.3 Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Data Collection and Analysis
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: To further amplify the voice of young people UNICEF also established U-Report in the country and in this reporting period amassed 300 UReporters and published 9 polls. These  activities engaged multiple UNICEF Volunteers and will continue to do so in the scale-up of U-Report.
2022 Narrative: UNICEF communication team reached 140929 people and engaged 5113 on social media with posts related to environment and climate change.
2023 Narrative: During 2023, through UNICEF support, a total of 980 young people participated in skills building and youth participation programmes. More importantly these young people created 139 products, policies and community level actions. Through the Air Care Ambassadors programme, 30 young people developed 67 media products (short documentaries, photographs, etc.). These young people also sent out 16 formal requests on air quality to respective policymakers.
2024 Narrative: On a national level UNICEF leveraged the U-Report tool to consult children and youth on opportunities for green skills development which resulted in an ECAR wide study in collaboration with the European Training Foundation. Throughout the year UNICEF created synergies between the skills development and advocacy programmes with the aim to strengthen the role of children and adolescents in important processes and policy development. After a joint event on climate change education and green skills development between UNICEF and the Ministry of Environment and Physical Planning, over 200 young innovators were invited by the Minister to explore opportunities for state funding of their solutions. UNICEF support for children and adolescents in tackling air pollution, climate change and environmental sustainability contributed to a strong commitment by the government to elevate the participation of children and young people in the development of the new Nationally Determined Contribution and include child and youth specific measures and activities. Government officials have publicly acknowledged the disproportionate effect of climate change on children and pledged to advance the role of children and young people in mitigating its effects.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Climate action, natural resources and disaster risk management
Outcome: Outcome 3: Healthy Environment
Output: Output 3.1 Low-emissions development and climate change resilience
Sub-Output: Capacities and seed funding for youth for modeling innovative environment and climate-friendly solutions
Description: Implement youth-led initiatives and programmes using design thinking methodology that enable young people to participate and contribute with innovative solutions to take climate change and protect the environment.
Contributing partners: Government of Sweden, United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: North Macedonia Ministry of Education and Science, North Macedonia Ministry of Environment and Physical Planning
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.,13.3 Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Data Collection and Analysis, Direct Support/ Service Delivery
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 10 Output 3.1 Low-emissions development and climate change resilience, 7 Output 2.2 Quality and affordable education
2021 Narrative: Within the programme for Climate change and Environmental education, UNICEF implemented one UPSHIFT cycle dedicated to the topic. 10 teams of 46 young people from secondary schools in the country completed the three-day design thinking workshop. Five teams were awarded seed funding to advance their climate change and environment protection social innovations. The teams will further be supported with a mentoring support from the implementing partner as well as within their schools. This programme will further engage young people in a cooperation with the Youth Cultural Center of the City of Skopje. Within this year’s editions of the CineDays film festival, and the Zdravo Mladi music festival young artists will participate in a number of workshops and challenges offering them the opportunity to utilize their creative energy in advocating form sustainable development and climate change mitigation.
2022 Narrative: In partnership with the Fund for innovation and technological development (FITD), UNICEF implemented three UPSHIFT thematic cycles on the topic of water, air and energy. 150 young people provided 15 innovative solutions to the school/community challenges in the respective topics, 5 solutions per topic were awarded with 2000 euro and coaching support for implementation.
2023 Narrative: Through UPSHIFT 99 young people developed 10 innovations for their communities. The programme included a crowd-funding campaign that managed to raise 155,720 MKD in support of the UPSHIFT solutions. In partnership with UNDP and the City of Skopje, UNICEF also established a national Biohacking Laboratory with an objective to develop and pilot an extracurricular educational programme. The programme and the Lab itself were designed in a manner that is available and accessible to all groups, including marginalized groups of youth (i.e., from the rural areas). The Lab ultimately reached all VET schools that have courses in Chemistry and Technology and/or Agriculture and Veterinary, and directly worked with 626 students.UNICEF also created an innovation programme for university students in the hard/technical sciences. These new “Innovation Camps” aimed to foster social innovation from university students aged 18 to 22 years. The primary goal of these camps is to provide a venue for future researchers and scientists in the niche areas of environmental sustainability, climate change and biodiversity. Within 2023, two such camps were organized with 39 young people. The UPSHIFT implementation consistently ensured equal gender participation. However, anecdotal data suggested that girls were less likely to assume prominent roles in the teams. In 2023 the programme devoted specific focus on working with positive female role models to actively encourage young women and girls. This practice from UPSHIFT extended into the Innovation Camps and Biohacking Laboratory programmes and initial feedback is positive.
2024 Narrative: Through the UPSHIFT and Innovation Camp programmes 245 young girls and boys from across the country led the development and implementation of social and technical innovations that addressed pressing issues in their communities. The programmes place specific focus on gender differences and implements various strategies to ensure equal outcomes for girls and boys, including promoting positive female role models in sciences, engaging female mentors and monitoring in-group activity and dynamics among participants. All activities were implemented with strong support and contribution from national institutions such as the Fund for Innovation and Technological Development (funding 49% of the UPSHIFT programme) and scientific institutions providing direct mentoring support during the Innovation camps.

Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Contributing partners: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Ministry of Culture and Media Montenegro, Montenegro Ministry of Sustainable Development and Tourism
SDG Targets: 11.4 Strengthen efforts to protect and safeguard the world's cultural and natural heritage.
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to gender equality/women’s empowerment
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: Capacity building was aimed at creation of conditions for declaring a transboundary biosphere reserve of the Bojana river basin within the program "Man and Biosphere", with special activities that will include young people. Rapid assessment of the biodiversity values in Bojana/Buna basin, conducted by EuroNatur, as the only comprehensive research of this area, highlights the need for its in-depth research, protection and sustainable practices planning under a concept that can ensure wider area integrated planning, also a trans boundary one, such as UNESCO Man and Biosphere Reserve (MAB BR). In addition, the ecosystems of Bojana/Buna area are interconnected with those belonging to the Lake Shkoder/Skadar and so are their values.
2022 Narrative: Environment for the active involvement of local young actors in the "new age" transboundary biosphere reserve concept of sustainable development practices in the Bojana/Buna delta area was developed. Youth, aged 18 to 35 who live and work in the Bojana/Buna delta area, were engaged with a purpose of developing a strategic and bottom-up approach to "Man and Biosphere” program for the protection and development of the area. Two Youth Clubs have been established, and initiated activities contributed to development of transboundary biosphere reserve concept of sustainable development. Razvijeno je okruženje za aktivno uključivanje lokalnih mladih aktera u koncept prakse održivog razvoja prekograničnog rezervata biosfere u području delte Bojane/Bune. Mladi, starosti od 18 do 35 godina koji žive i rade na području delte Bojane/Bune, angažovani su u cilju razvijanja strateškog pristupa odozdo prema gore programu „Čovjek i biosfera“ za zaštitu i razvoj područja. Osnovani su klubovi, a pokrenute aktivnosti doprinijele su razvoju koncepta održivog razvoja prekograničnog rezervata biosfere.

Description: To support the enhanced access to information, knowledge, market opportunities, and linkages of smallholder farmers, youth, women and vulnerable population
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations

2023 Narrative: In 2023, FAO initiated its regional efforts to support the enhanced access to information, knowledge, market opportunities, and linkages of smallholder farmers, youth, women and vulnerable population in Georgia. FAO produced an initial list of potential target villages in Georgia to identify the villages that have the potential to be transformed in digital villages in the country. FAO is in the process of recruiting a national consultant for this initiative.
2024 Narrative: Through FAO’s Digital Villages Initiative (DVI) the selected rural communities gained access to digital advisory services through Georgian TelAgri application, and tested the FAO’s Farm Management application where farmers could record and plan farm operations. In addition, within DVI an agrometeorological weather station allowing farmers to receive timely alerts on their phones, along with the greenhouse monitoring and automation system were installed in the local demo farm. The demo farm of the Agricultural University of Georgia is expanding its range of digital solutions. As part of the DVI initiative, digital pest traps have been installed

Strategic priority: Enhanced human wellbeing, capabilities and equality in Georgia by 2030

Description: To support the increased youth engagement in agriculture, food systems and rural development
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Ministry of Environmental Protection and Agriculture of Georgia
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,16.7 Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 16 Peace and Justice - Strong Institutions
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 3.2 3.2. Sustainable and inclusive agricultural and rural development, strengthened food systems and improved livelihoods.
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: FAO Georgia provided support to enhance youth engagement in agriculture, food systems, and rural development in 2023. The analysis of the situation and needs of rural youth was initiated, commencing with a stakeholder mapping exercise, with a focus on the existing policy framework and political participation of youth. Moreover, the Agrarian Olympiad for 2023 was conducted, becoming a key driver in talent recognition, environmental awareness, and the overall development and sustainability of the agricultural sector. Notable achievements include massive participation from 870 contestants and the identification of 39 diverse winners across categories. The winners were honored at the awards ceremony held on November 22, 2023, in Tbilisi, Georgia. The National Agricultural Olympiad 2023 received support and was conducted in collaboration with the USDA project: " Safety and Quality Investment in Livestock’ in Georgia (SQIL), as well as private sector partners, including TBC for Business, Aldagi, Agrosphere, Baraka, Hektas, Georgian Wine Guild, Vinotel, Beko, Agromotors, Pomona and Muracha. Also, this year, FAO introduced a new feature by organizing an exhibition space in the reception room, where six main sponsors (SQIL, TBC, Aldagi, Hektas, Agrosphere, Baraka) were showcased at individual desks.
2024 Narrative: FAO has identified “youth” as an important group whose needs must be addressed across all of FAO’s programmatic work areas. Within each of FAO’s 20 programme priority areas, youth has been included as a cross-cutting theme together with gender and inclusion. The Organization recognizes that youth are already at the frontline to build more sustainable agrifood systems and are best placed to rejuvenate the sector and acquire the knowledge and skills needed to innovate and uptake new technologies.Focus groups were held in 5 regions of Georgia to analyze the situation and needs of young people living in rural areas. The outcomes of the focus groups contributed to the elaboration of the Situation and Needs Analysis of Rural Youth. Youth workshops were held in Shida Kartli, Gori and in Guria, Ozurgeti. The draft of the Situation and Needs analysis report was presented at the youth workshop held in Tbilisi in April within the framework of the project, in which representatives of the FAO Regional Office for Europe and Central Asia, as well as the Ministry of Environment protection and Agriculture and various stakeholders participated.On the basis of all three workshops conducted in Kartli, Gori and in Guria, Ozurgeti and Tbilisi , the Situation and Needs analysis report and the ToRs of the National Youth Network for Agrifood Systems and Rural Development were developed. The Core-group of the youth network of agriculture and rural development was formed, consisting of the representatives of the Ministry of Environment Protection and Agriculture and its agencies, and the stakeholders of various sectors. The 1St Workshop of the core-group was held, where the activities under ToR of the network were introduced.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Building trust and mutual accountability through the Rule of Law, Rights and Duties agenda

Description: The regional JP aims to empower youth to engage in constructive and fact-based narratives, strengthen trust, intercultural dialogue, diversity, gender equality and mutual understanding in the Western Balkans. It does so through by supporting and promoting youth coalitions and networks, meaningful participation of young people in policy and governance processes, and building resilience to divisive narratives and mis/disinformation by promoting constructive narratives. Achievements include impactful youth empowerement, youth in decision making, youth-led initiatives, inclusive narratives, youth exchanges, gender equality promotion, and inclusivity in sports.
Contributing partners: The UN Secretary-General’s Peacebuilding Fund (UN Peace Fund)
Implementation partners: Non-Governmental Oranizations, Republic of Serbia Ministry of Education, Science and Technological Development, Republic of Serbia Ministry of Youth and Sport, Republic of Serbia Office for Human and Minority Rights
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.
QCPR function: Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: The project has specific and mainstreamed activities that advance gender equality and address gender norms that influence divisive narratives and conflict factors. By empowering and connecting young women and men and building their capacity and by working with key institutions to address gender norms and toxic masculinities across the region, when combined with other interventions, the self-efficacy and effectiveness of these young women and men in advancing gender equality and, in turn, social cohesion will be increased. Young women and men will also develop a culture of inclusion where root factors of discrimination, divisive narratives and violence can be better understood and mitigated. The project has allocated a considerable amount of its budget to GEWE and  to date,  46.68% of the budget  was allocated to GEWE related activities. This gives the project a GEM 2 rating, meaning that gender equality is a significant objective of the project  .  In terms of the original phase of the project's RF, it was assessed that  the project’s outcome statement is gender responsive; one of its output statements is gender blind and the other is also gender responsive. Also it was assessed that 14/34 of the project’s indicators are assessed as gender blind , 11/34 as gender targeted, 2/34 as gender responsive and 4/34 as gender transformational.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2023 – 2027
Strategic priority: SP1_Just and inclusive institutions and equal opportunities for human development
Outcome: OC1_By 2027, institutions deliver human rights-based, evidence-informed and gender-responsive services for all, with the focus on those who are left behind
Output: OU 1.2_Health, education and food systems are strengthened and become more resilient to ensure universal access and quality of services and respond to humanitarian needs
Sub-Output: (UNFPA) Pilot the Menstrual Health Management programme in schools and community based organizations serving adolescents and youth.
Description: The pilot results from 2024 have generated strong evidence supporting the inclusion of menstrual health education in schools and the nationwide expansion of free menstrual product access. A cost-efficiency analysis has been conducted, and further advocacy is underway to secure funding for menstrual hygiene products from school budgets and governmental sources. The Ministry of Education and Research (MER) has expressed interest in equipping 164 schools with menstrual pads for the 2025-2026 academic year. Additionally, up to 50 more schools may be included in the initiative, with UNFPA providing dispensers and delivering educational sessions on the responsible use of menstrual hygiene products.
Contributing partners: Core Funding, Government of Sweden, United Kingdom Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office
Implementation partners: United Nations Population Fund, Youth Media Center
SDG Targets: 3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,4.a Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 4 Quality Education
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis, Support Functions, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Gender marker narrative: The program directly empowers girls by championing and investing in equal access to education, specifically by incorporating menstrual health and hygiene management into Moldovan schools.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Contributes strongly to sexual and reproductive rights of young people, mainly girls ensuring both dignified school attendance as well as sexual and reproductive health and rights.
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2023 Narrative: The Menstrual Hygiene Program was piloted in 4 schools from four districts that were supported in creating a safe and gender-sensitive environment for boys and girls to empower them to adopt healthy behaviors, including menstrual health-related. UNFPA equipped the four schools with modern classes for studying health education, and medical offices and the psychologist's office were refurbished in a youth-friendly manner. 533 students received education on menstrual hygiene management, including 83 refugee youth from Ukraine. The schools and other community-based organizations serving young people (Youth Klinics, Youth Centers) are to be equipped in early 2024 with dispensers and menstrual hygiene products. In addition, with the Ministry of Education and Research, UNFPA launched the national communication Campaign “Schools that Inspire”, by showcasing a series of video materials, and articles on the schools that promote healthy environments for students including sexuality education, menstrual health, and hygiene management, refugees inclusion, etc. https://moldova.unfpa.org/en/news/schools-inspire-discover-best-moldovan-schools-nurturing-safe-environment The Campaign will continue in 2024. In 2023 almost 0,5 mln people have been reached with Campaign materials. The programme is implemented in partnership with the Association Youth Media Center in support of the Ministry of Education and Research of Moldova.
2024 Narrative: With UNFPA support, over 160 educational institutions across the country now provide free access to menstrual hygiene products directly within the school. Sanitary pad dispensers are installed in girls' restrooms, ensuring students in all 164 schools no longer need to leave class or seek pads from classmates or the school nurse.Within three months of installing the dispensers, the percentage of girls in the pilot schools who missed at least one class during their menstrual period dropped over fourfold, from 55.2% to 12.5%.Additionally, 56% of the girls surveyed said they feel safe at school. Nearly 39% of them also reported that boys no longer make jokes about menstruation and have become more respectful.School absenteeism during menstruation is a reality in our country, as confirmed by teachers and social workers. Due to low family incomes, many girls are forced to skip classes or use alternative products such as cotton, gauze, tissues, socks, bedsheets, or even sleeves from their younger siblings' clothing.In an online survey involving 558 female students, many respondents reported experiencing irregular and heavy menstrual cycles, hormonal imbalances, and, in the absence of enough sanitary pads, having to leave school early in the day. Moreover, menstruation now often begins much earlier (at 8–9 years old), making access to pads a necessity rather than a luxury.In the new school year, alongside equipping schools with dispensers and sanitary pads, nearly 700 teaching and non-teaching staff participated in online training sessions. These sessions focused on puberty development, menstrual health and hygiene, and effective communication about sensitive and "taboo" topics. Following the training, teachers, school psychologists, and medical staff educated students about the natural changes in their bodies and how to navigate certain situations.In addition, the menstrual hygiene program was piloted in 41 Youth-Friendly Health Centers, and 67 Youth Centers across the country.A partnership with a pharmaceutical company resulted in co-financing with UNFPA for key resources, including menstrual pads, furniture for two medical offices, and student educational activities.

2023 Narrative: The partnership with the Agency for Youth and Sports advanced the support for municipal youth councils. 105 young people and representatives from three municipalities worked jointly to design and implement sustainable policies and programmes at the local level. The young people developed detailed (costed) workplans for improving the air quality in their municipality. These solutions were presented to municipal representatives and is expected that will be reviewed at subsequent municipal council sessions.UNICEF also piloted new programmes for youth participation and skills building. Through the Air Care Ambassadors programme, 30 young people developed 67 media products (short documentaries, photographs, etc.). These young people also sent out 16 formal requests on air quality to respective policymakers.Building onto the success of the programme for environment and climate change education, in late 2023 UNICEF established a partnership with the Vocational Training and Education Centre (VETC), initiating a greening revision of VET curricula, to support green skills development in students. The revision is being conducted in cooperation and with co-funding from the Swiss Development Organization ‘Helvetas’.
2024 Narrative: Children and adolescents also engaged decision makers on a local and national level. Through the Air Quality Advocacy programme these young advocates worked in municipalities to formulate specific asks and submit them for official review with the support of Local Youth Councils. Over 250 young people participated in multiple workshops and camps.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Enhanced human wellbeing, capabilities and equality in Georgia by 2030
Outcome: Outcome 3: By 2025, all people without discrimination benefit from a sustainable, inclusive and resilient economy in Georgia
Output: 3.3. Increased productive employment, decent work, skills development and effective national social protection for all
Sub-Output: Effective life-long learning systems are avialable in non-farm vacations for youth (including in NEETs) and job seekers
Description: Creating better life-long learning opportunities through local partnerships
Contributing partners: European Union, United Nations Development Programme
Implementation partners: Ministry of Education, Science, Culture and Sports of Georgia
SDG Targets: 4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.,8.6 By 2020, substantially reduce the proportion of youth not in employment, education or training.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth
Geography: Guria, Racha-Lechkhumi and Kvemo Svaneti, Imereti, Kakheti, Autonomous Republic of Adjara, Tbilisi, Georgia
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 3.3 3.3. Increased productive employment, decent work, skills development and effective national social protection for all
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2021 Narrative: In 2021 UNDP supported youth NEETS  supporting policy elaboration through fact-finding on the rout causes and factors and attitudes of marginalization of youth and educational disintegration. UNDP also elaborated model of secondary school based VET delivery  for advocating introduction of management, regulatory and  teaching methodologies of VET in  secondary schools to increase coverage of VET services.
2022 Narrative: UNDP evaluated existing teaching programmes in Tourism and Wellness/health with focus on three main directions: reflect Tourism and Wellness/health sectors in educational classificatory on detailed level; Introduce vocational education standards and framework documents in Tourism and Wellness/health sectors and Introduce and implement vocational education programmes (diploma, certificate) in Tourism and Wellness/health sectors per vocational education facilities. Within the framework of the project, the Skills Agency elaborated (and will be enhanced in the upcoming months) the Capacity Building Programme encompassing general modules, VET authorization standard specific modules and respective guidelines to help public schools prepare for the authorization processes granting them a right to implement short term training-retraining VET programmes. These will ensure inclusion of NEET youth and other vulnerable groups into the learning process On the national level, the project ensures accessibility of VET system by NEETs and other vulnerable groups conducted by the Skills Agency. The following key results were achieved in partnership with the Skills Agency: ·      the Skills Agency developed career management service, the same as orientation service for persons with disabilities. Based on the regulatory framework of the inclusive education, the orientation service provides opportunities to persons with disabilities to use the service throughout the year and prepare for the desired professions. ·      the Skills Agency began to develop sectoral network of VET teachers in the ares of personal services and health care. The sectoral network is percieved as one of the key mechanisms for supporting teachers in VET, through enhancing development of VET teachers, professional advancement, sharing of sectoral news and cooperation between VET teachers. ·      To strengthen VET institutions through introducing entreperenurial VET college model, the Skills Agency trained relevant personnel and identified the organizational structure. ·      The concepts for introducing digital and blended learning in the helath and wellness sectors of Georgia, as well as distance and home-based work opportunities are elaborated including elaborating the new qualifications, occupational and educational standards as per requirement of new regulatory framework, which in addition to „competency mapping“ and validation process implies increased private sector engagement. ·      the Skills Agency elaborated the Capacity Building Programme encompassing general modules, VET authorization standard specific modules and respective guidelines to help public schools prepare for the authorization processes granting them a right to implement short term training-retraining VET programmes.In total 1516 VET students and schoolchildren, 16 college staff members, 34 HUB college staff members, 41 HUB college partners, 92 college and school staff members and partners from local governments benefitted from availability of needs-based institutional development plans put in practice for provision of diversified VET services.
2023 Narrative: UNDP’s achievements in this direction include the following:  >Establishing strong foundations for institutional development and introducing vocational training into general education. The project accomplished this by elaborating comprehensive guidelines and developing relevant capacity-development programmes for public schools, thus enabling them to obtain authorization for vocational programme implementation.  >Introducing extracurricular activities through clubs and institutionalizing relevant student services led by Sunny House (Project Partner). These achievements contributed to enriching educational outcomes and developing competencies that are in high demand in the labour market (something that has proven difficult to achieve exclusively through formal education). The project also transformed student life, making it more engaging, accessible, motivating and productive. UNDP (CBLLL project) supported the development of new programmes and educational opportunities in the target sectors by establishing platforms, networks and capacity-building opportunities. (CBLLL supports the organizational development of sectoral skills organizations by creating new sectoral networks comprised of college-level academic and private-sector representatives).  UNDP CBLLL project has transformed two partner VET colleges into entrepreneurial organizations, thus creating unique spaces for learning and development in the region. The project focused on NEET (not engaged in employment, education or training) youth and empowered VET providers by introducing ‘catch-up’ courses as a second-chance opportunity. Two such catch-up courses on digital and financial literacy have been developed and are slated to be piloted in partner schools. Other planned activities in this area include capacity-building for school administrators and teachers.  The project elaborated and strengthened services for supporting the key competency development of youth, NEETs and persons with disabilities, thus making vocational education accessible, relevant and inclusive for lifelong learning. In vocational education, accessibility, inclusiveness and relevancy of services are immensely important on multiple individual and societal levels. Although vocational education is focused on educating for the labour market, the social impacts of creating fair and equal opportunities by engaging vulnerable populations in productive activities for individual and the common good should not be overlooked.  To that end, CBLLL activities create new models and modalities to ensure that vocational education is relevant to the needs of both human and labour market development and that it offers innovative services, including digital and blended learning. The project developed a concept note on introducing digital and blended learning in Georgia to be used as a guiding document for digitizing resources and processes in VET systems.  Educational resources, modules and videos created in entrepreneurial learning enhance entrepreneurship competencies in formal and informal education programmes that are available in VET institutions. The elaboration of career education and orientation services for persons with disabilities was introduced in partnership with the Skills Agency. These services, available through vocational education institutions, are essential instruments for advancing opportunities and skills for better employment.  Following UNDP’s long-standing experience and approach, the project’s elaborated and piloted models are institutionalized for replication and nationwide scale-up in other sectors.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Support national efforts to promote inclusive and gender transformative approaches to climate action, disaster risk management and environmental protection to conserve natural resources and leverage ecosystem benefits for sustainable human development (CLIMATE, ENERGY, DRM AND BIODIVERSITY)
Outcome: By 2027, the Kyrgyz Republic has started the transition to low-carbon development and risk-informed climate resilience, contributing to people’s fair and equitable access to ecosystem benefits and to empowerment of vulnerable communities in the governance of natural resources and disaster prevention
Output: Capacity of disaster management systems is strengthened, and community resilience to multiple shocks is increased at all levels through enhanced participation of women in DRR planning, as well as effective investments, policies, mechanisms, and tools
Sub-Output: Government, local self-government institutions, schools and youth organizations have increased capacity in Emergency Preparedness and Response
Description:
Capacity development of Local government and youth organizations for Emergency Preparedness and Response
Local self-government institutions and youth organizations have increased capacity in Emergency Preparedness and Response
Contributing partners: Core Funding, Government of Japan, United Nations Children's Fund, United States Fund for UNICEF
Implementation partners: Kyrgyz Ministry of Health
SDG Targets: 3.2 By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.,3.8 Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.
Gender marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to gender equality/women’s empowerment
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: In 2023, 179 (105 women, 74 men) local authorities were trained on DRR, risk assessment and capacity mapping. This led to the development of child sensitive disaster preparedness and response plans considering the needs and context of selected most at-risk communities. In addition, UNICEF supported the development of regulations with three SOPs for humanitarian assistance and social protection service delivery during emergency. The process included a thorough intra-governmental review, public hearings, and gender analysis of the normative acts more gender sensitive. The finalized Regulation was sent to the Cabinet of Ministers for approval.﻿UNICEF provided financial support and supplies to Red Crescent Society of Kyrgyzstan and UN volunteers to implement Safe school project nationwide.
2024 Narrative: School-based disaster preparedness was strengthened through the implementation of national “Safe Schools and Pre-schools in the Kyrgyz Republic in 2015-2024" programme to promote sustainability and resilience in the education sector. A total of 974,574 school children benefited from simulation drills. Additionally, 6,483 schoolchildren (3,110 boys and 3,373 girls) enhanced their preparedness through training on disaster risk reduction and climate action. Non-structural risk reduction measures were implemented in 7 schools to enhance the overall safety of these education facilities to better prepare schoolchildren and staff for potential disasters. In line with the principles of “leave no one behind” 25 children with disabilities enhanced risk awareness.A total of 996 preschool children benefited from the induction of local disaster risks, appropriate response behaviour and practical simulation in 14 pre-schools (10 in Bishkek, 2 in Nookat, 1 in Toktogul, and 1 in Balykchy.

2022 Narrative: Advocacy platform which supports adolescents’ and youth’ sexual and reproductive health and rights and includes teachers, young people, parents, and religious leaders was expanded in  Chisinau municipality and 5 targeted districts (Cahul, Rezina, Orhei, Falesti, Ungheni) and is currently acting in 50 communities. 1265 key actors (parents, teachers, religious leaders, LPAs, young people, etc.) were informed in 2022 about the benefits of comprehensive sexuality education and sexual and reproductive health and rights of young people. 567539 population was reached through multimedia materials developed and disseminated widely by UNFPA on comprehensive sexuality education and its impact, etc.Two National Conferences on Health Education and Adolescents health and wellbeing were conducted in partnership with Youth Media Center and Health for Youth NGOs/Network of Youth Friendly Health Clinics. About 1000 professionals from education and health communities, parents, young people engaged. The the “Health education” Facebook group which brings teachers and CSO expanded and includes now 419 members. The CSE was addressed in more than 10 TV and radio programmes with participation of UNFPA, Ministry of Education and Research, teachers, young people, parents, and implementing partners of UNFPA.

Plan name: Republic of Moldova - United Nations Partnership Framework for Sustainable Development  2018-2022
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 4 - Inclusive and equitable social development
Outcome: Outcome 4.1 - The people of Moldova, in particular the most vulnerable, demand and benefit from gender-sensitive and human rights-based, inclusive, effective and equitable equality education, health and social policies and services
Output: (2021) 4.2 Women, young people and persons with disabilities have improved capacity and are empowered to access and demand quality education, health and social services
Sub-Output: Support Youth Klinics to provide out of school peer-to-peer health education
Description: Support Youth Klinics' volunteers in conducting online and offline peer-to-peer health education including on sexual and reproductive health and rights
Implementation partners: Youth Friendly Clinic
SDG Targets: 3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
In 2021, the UNFPA continued to support the  Network of Youth Kliniks to provide peer-to-peer educational programs for young people in Moldova. 

The volunteers of YK have strengthened their capacity to develop and deliver information through social media by applying posters, videos, etc. To enrich the learning outcomes of young people, UNFPA developed and equipped all 41 YKs with innovative learning materials about sexual and reproductive health and rights, including a board game and online quiz "Without Taboo", puzzles and posters with changes in puberty of boys and girls, board games on HIV/AIDS prevention and use of modern contraception. In addition, 5 podcasts/video formats were developed and will be widely disseminated to young people, parents, teachers in 2022.  

This year the peer education program through social media has been extended to the Russian-speaking community. As result, volunteers conducted an information campaign on 1- Reproductive health; 2- The phenomenon of violence against young people (at home, at school, in the community, between young people); 3 - Cyber Bullying and 4- Mental Health / COVID-19 pandemic conditions (Anxiety, depression, laziness, distrust, isolation, loneliness, lack of motivation). They have reached out to 113646 adolescents and youth up to 24 years through social media and to another  12794 boys and girls through offline peer education activities. 

In addition, to strengthen the capacity of the Youth Klinics network to align their programs and services to the needs of young people from vulnerable groups, in partnership with NGO "Health for Youth" and Coordination Center of YK "Neovita", the international ”Out of School Comprehensive Sexuality Education Guidance” was translated into Romanian and presented to key SCOs working with young people. The YK already applied this Guideline to develop the CSE program for young people with disabilities.

2021 Narrative:
>IT skills of 44 students in Gali and Gudauta improved through trainings programming, robotics, 3D design and graphical design at the newly established IT Centers in Gali and Gudauta.
>67 conflict affected young people in Sukhumi, Gali and Ochamchire were provided with vocational education (culinary courses, courses for electricians and sewing courses) using resources available at VET institutions in Abkhazia. 
>Creative potential of 70 young people in Gali and Ochamchire enhanced their skills at the newly established SmART Class in Ochamchire - a platform for alternative and innovative methods of informal education in the areas of bibliophilia, healthy lifestyle and civic activism, as well as had an opportunity to participate in intellectual games.

Up to 260 conflict affected youth and teachers improved access to quality education services through projects implemented by Innovative Education Foundation (EU COBERM) and Conciliation Resources (EU RRF) provided access of conflict-affected youth to quality education:  
Innovative Education Foundation: The mixed groups of 18 Abkhaz and Georgian educators received necessary knowledge of best educational practices in IT/STEM education through joint workshops, training, webinars and seminars and are able to start applying them.
Conciliation Resources: 240 Abkhaz students got access to online English courses and 90 teachers retrained in delivering English language classes, as well as stress management and skills for conducting lessons in online format

2022 Narrative: UNDP continued its efforts to ensure participation, inclusion, and access to quality education for conflict affected youth. 10 youth from Gali and other districts of Abkhazia gained access to quality education in Estonia, increasing literacy level, skills of critical thinking, and high competence, contributing to increased chances for employment and decreased poverty.A new platform for cooperation has been established among Georgian and Abkhaz preschool teachers and early childhood educational specialists as a new entry point in confidence building field. The action improves quality of Early Childhood Education in Georgian and Abkhaz preschools through advancing competencies and qualification of teachers and caregivers, and introduces international best practices.  In 2022 UNDP continued expanding digital capacities of underserved communities, cultivating a digital mindset within Abkhazia through creating and piloting short gender-responsive TVET (Technical VET) courses enhanced by digital content and e-learning tools in the demanded skills and specializations (Web Development based on WordPress, Landscape design, Tourism Management, Electrician, Photo/Video Editing). The action increases employment opportunities of youth and adult learners in TaT and Abkhazia and there is an evidence-based demand in local societies to benefit from this opportunity with the aim to advance further their skills and professional career.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Inclusive human capital development leading to health, well-being and resilient prosperity
Outcome: Outcome 4. By 2025, the most vulnerable benefit from enhanced access to gender-sensitive quality health, education and social services.
Output: Output 4.1. By 2025, capacities of health system and stakeholders are strengthened to implement efficient and transparent, innovative and inclusive Universal Health Coverage-focused policies and programmes, comprehensive responses to health emergencies and to promote a healthy lifestyle and health literacy among all age groups as well as quality professional development opportunities and a decent work environment for healthcare employees.
Sub-Output: Awareness raising activities delivered among youth on reproductive health, HIV and AIDS, family planning
Contributing partners: UN Multi-Partner Human Security Trust Fund for the Aral Sea region in Uzbekistan , United Nations Population Fund
Implementation partners: Uzbekistan Ministry of Health, Uzbekistan Ministry of Preschool and School Education
SDG Targets: 3.1 By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.,3.2 By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.,3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,3.8 Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: In progress. The following activities were completed in 2021: 21 methodological and informative brochures in three languages for teachers, students and parents were developed and approved to be part of “klassnyi chas” topics,       75 schoolteachers improved their knowledge and skills on teaching topics about reproductive health, HLS, HIV and STI prevention during 5-days training, 2419 teachers attended sessions on these topics during mandatory course of advancing professional skills in the Republican center of advance training for teachers in the Republic of Karakalpakstan, 27 volunteers from youth leaders improved their knowledge and skills on how to share information using peer-to-peer approach, 1195 adolescents learned about these topics from youth leaders during peer-to-peer sessions and yet 2000 adolescents will be covered by the end of 2021.
2022 Narrative: Completed: Further on raising awareness and prevention of STI/HIV UNFPA within the framework of the MPTF2 project “Investing in a resilient future of Karakalpakstan by improving health, nutrition, water, sanitation, hygiene and wellbeing of adolescents and by harnessing the talents of youth during and after COVID- 19”, UNFPA supported training for 100 teachers from selected districts of the Republic of Karakalpakstan who covered 718 teachers by peer-to-peer sessions on reproductive health, family planning, menstrual hygiene, gender and discrimination, HIV and STI prevention, etc. 123 volunteers from young teachers, psychologists and youth activists were trained on the same topics and shared this information with 14 287 (43% of male and 57% of female) adolescents and community people. The group of volunteers continue conducting information sessions and plan to cover 15 000 of adolescents and community people by the end of 2022. The same topics were included as additional lectures to the mandatory courses for teachers in the Republican Center of Advanced training for teachers of the Republic of Karakalpakstan and 5 658 teachers learned about it throughout a year. Eight booklets, 10 brochures for adolescents and their parents, and 50 methodological guidelines for teachers on above mentioned topics were developed by national partners and designed in three languages for further sharing with schools. To mark up successful work of volunteers, UNFPA supported final meeting where volunteers from several districts had a chance to share their experience, lessons learnt and best practices; participate in team competition and get awards for their work.

2023 Narrative: By the end of 2023, 8 district-level National Action Plans (NAP) for the Gender Equality Strategy (GES), with a particular focus on VAWG were finalized. The GES and NAP were successfully localized in Chui province thanks to a series of capacity development events organized for 40 local government partners, including study tours and trainings, as well as political and institutional support from the Plenipotentiary Representative in response to the Cabinet of Ministries' order.
2024 Narrative: UN Women, in close coordination with the Ministry of Labor, Social Security and Migration (MLSSM), and in partnership with UNDP and UNCIEF, has been facilitating the consultative process of comprehensive review of the implementation of Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action and SC Resolution 1325. To review country’s progress since its submission of the Beijing+25 report, the consultations that were organized included interviews and focus groups discussions with 330 representatives of national and local governments, civil society organizations and development partners. The process included assessment of national policies implementation, including those recommended from Beijing+25 National report, review of the achievements and key challenges in its different sections to further identify strategies to promote GEWE. The comprehensive National report to review the progress following 30 years of implementation of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action was submitted by the MLSSM on 28th June 2024.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Transparent and accountable democratic governance
Outcome: Outcome 4: Good Governance
Output: Output 4.2 Institutions capacitated for better planning, budgeting and service design and delivery
Sub-Output: Local governments supported in launching and implementing public calls for CSOs and youth CSOs and monitoring of CSO projects implementation
Description: Grant schemes will be managed by UNDP with strong participation of partner local governments. This approach should allow local governments to understand all details of this process, and by participating in it they should learn how to execute public calls for CSOs independently. The partner local governments (LGs) will be supported in preparation of the documents for conducting public calls for CSOs, with specific theme aimed at youth. The calls for proposals are expected to be open for 4 weeks, and within the first week, an info session and two-day training on project preparation will be organized. Upon the closure of the public calls, the project team will provide support to and ensure quality control of the work of the evaluation commission. The project also developed e-Learning programs to build capacities of the local administration in Project Cycle Management (PCM) training and introducing transparent model for funds disbursement to CSOs from municipal budgets.
