2024 Narrative: UNDP- In partner local governments, sessions with young people were organized, focused on discussing the challenges they face and exploring opportunities for their involvement in community affairs through volunteerism and activism. The implementation of 30 CSO projects was monitored by a combined monitoring team comprised of 2 members of the ReLOaD2 project team and 2 LG representatives. In 2024, 123 monitoring visits were organized.

2023 Narrative: 1) Tashkent International Model United Nations 2023:UNODC ROCA, in collaboration with sister UN agencies - UNFPA and UN Women, played a pivotal role in organizing the Tashkent International Model United Nations 2023 (TIMUN), Central Asia's largest international MUN platform, bringing together over 500 young minds from 14 different countries and simulating 11 UN committees.Having supported TIMUN in Uzbekistan since 2018, UNODC - a global leader against illicit drugs, organized crime, terrorism, and corruption, provided a unique opportunity for young participants to model two UNODC committees: the Commission on Crime Prevention and Criminal Justice (CCPCJ) and the Commission on Narcotic Drugs (CND).                                                                                                                                                                                                          2) The Youth Media Hub, established in Fergana Valley in 2021 within the framework of the Peacebuilding Funds Project, provided life skills training to 50 vulnerable young people in 2023.
2024 Narrative: UNODC facilitated the Wunderkind Model United Nations (WMUN) Conference in Tashkent, benefiting 80 school students (38 girls and 42 boys) from public and private schools and lyceums across Tashkent. Through featured simulations of UN committees addressing corruption, terrorism, cybercrime, and health coverage, young people have increased the knowledge and skills required to actively discuss these issues.

2023 Narrative: OHCHR built the capacity of local governments in seven target municipalities to ensure the right to participate in decision-making processes and promoted inter-community dialogue on socially relevant issues, with a particular focus on underrepresented groups.OHCHR supported the Ministry of Education and Science of the Kyrgyz Republic in the development of two manuals containing more than 60 lessons on human rights, equality and diversity for the country's secondary school curriculum. The manuals have passed all the mandatory expertises and have been approved by the Kyrgyz Academy of Education for use by all schools in the country.OHCHR also built the capacity of young activists from the disability community in the areas of human rights, non-discrimination and advocacy and supported their initiatives, including training their peers, ensuring physical and information accessibility and promoting advocacy at the national and international levels. In addition, OHCHR supported a wide range of human rights awareness-raising activities, particularly among young people and persons with disabilities.
2024 Narrative: OHCHR engaged with more than 100 human rights defenders, defense lawyers, media representatives both in Bishkek, Osh and other regions on the promotion of international human rights standards in law and practice.  OHCHR continuously mentored and briefed its civil society and media partners, and advised them on the use of international human rights standards in their work; and built their capacity on the engagement with the UN Human Rights Standards.

Outcome: Outcome 4: Good Governance

Sub-Output: Capacity development of duty bearers to improve data collection and budgeting related to services for children and youth with disability
Description:
Capacity development of duty bearers to improve data collection and budgeting related to services for children and youth with disability, by: i) establishing system for administrative data collection to inform policy and service development; ii) identifying and addressing financing and budgeting bottlenecks of targeted social services to most vulnerable categories with the development of an analysis of financing and budgeting bottlenecks.
Strengthening national capacities for evaluating programs/projects supported by the Government through the ExCEL Programme (Executive Course for Evaluation Leaders) organized by UNICEF. Technical assistance for strengthening the national evaluation capacities within the government institutions through workshops and consultations.
Capacity building of data providers for TransMonEE to collect data on children with disabilities, data gap assessment of statistical data on children, improved processing of data related to poverty including the children with disabilities.
Contributing partners: United Nations Children's Fund, United Nations Partnership on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities
Implementation partners: Association of special educators and rehabilitators of the Republic of North Macedonia, North Macedonia Ministry of Education and Science, North Macedonia Ministry of Finance, North Macedonia Ministry of Health, North Macedonia Ministry of Labour and Social Policy, North Macedonia National Association of Disability Organizations, North Macedonia National Coordination Body on Implementation of the CRPD, North Macedonia Polio Plus, North Macedonia State Statistical Office

2023 Narrative: UNICEF supported the development of an electronic registry of children and youth that have undergone functional assessment, and initiated an analysis of to identify service bottlenecks, which will contribute to better planning and budgeting of support services. The analysis of budgeting and public expenditures for support services for children and youth with disabilities, incorporating data on service provision and satisfaction from survey of parents and survey/interviews of service providers has been completed for two regions in the country.
2024 Narrative: The electronic register for children and youth with disabilities that have undergone assessment, established with UNICEF support will improve the planning, delivery, monitoring and the assessment of service quality. A comprehensive gap analysis identified geographic disparities in funding and service delivery to children with disabilities, offering insights for reform in resource allocation.

2021 Narrative: In line with the current initiatives of the country office and the momentum of reform in the education and environment domains, UNICEF launched a joint initiative with the Office of the President of North Macedonia, titled “Reimagine the future”. The initiative commenced with an exploratory phase reaching out to many young people to identify the key areas of their interest and concern. Based on the data gathered with over 700 young people, a series of deep-dive consultations with youth from across the country were held on three distinct topics: Education, Environment and Climate change and Mental health and wellbeing. The recommendations arising from these discussions were incorporated in a Youth for Action Strategy aimed at policy makers. This Youth for Action Strategy was signed and backed by the President of North Macedonia, pledging to champion these calls on their behalf.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework

Sub-Output: Strengthened capacity of the MoES, MoCISYP, local municipalities and CSOs to implement the existing effective programs and models of youth participation and skills development for adolescent-led solutions
Description: Provide technical support to MoES, MoCISYP, local municipalities and CSOs to strengthen the existing effective programs and models of youth participation and skills development for adolescent-led solutions
Contributing partners: Core Funding, Government of Japan, Peace Building Funds, UNDP Multi-Partner Trust Fund, United Nations Children's Fund, United States Fund for UNICEF
Implementation partners: Kyrgyz Ministry of Culture, Information, Sports and Youth Policy
SDG Targets: 4.a Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.,5.c Adopt and strengthen sound policies and enforceable legislation for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls at all levels.
Geography: Kyrgyzstan, Chui, Talas, Naryn, Batken, Bishkek (city), Issyk-Kul, Jalal-Abad, Osh
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: UNICEF continued its dedication to empowering adolescent girls and boys by investing in their knowledge and skills. A total of 4,882 adolescents (62 per cent girls) benefited from various projects, including peacebuilding, STEM4Girls project, and the UNICEF Volunteer programme. For instance, within STEM4Girls, 300 girls were empowered with green skills and STEM knowledge, equipped with co-created tools, and they trained 1,764 peers. Private sector partners contributed to creating internship and mentorship opportunities for girls. The Eco Hackathon initiative aimed to address environmental issues, leading to the creation of 12 eco-friendly solutions by girls. Four of these solutions secured financial backing for further implementation.
2024 Narrative: Within STEM4Girls programme UNICEF has reached to over 17,000 girls and boys with peer sessions on gender equality, green skills, communication and leadership skills, STEM and design thinking. Two eco-hackathons were held to enable youth develop and pitch their solutions to environmental issues. Design thinking workshops were held with 50 schools to jointly with children come up with effective mechanisms for child participation in school management. More than 80,000 children and youth across the country have engaged as UNICEF volunteers to deliver messages on sanitation and hygiene, DRR preparedness and CRC. In total, UNICEF has engaged over 114,000 children and youth in various actions aimed at improving the knowledge, health, education of children and young people.

Gender marker narrative: Girls and women from diverse religious and ethnic backgrounds are principle objective, and UNFPA will support them to actively lead initiatives and promote healthy behaviors, civic education, and peacebuilding. Support will include initiatives on youth leadership activism and meaningful participation in national and local implementation and monitoring processes. The results will be captured through the programme’s M&E framework.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2023 Narrative: 12 Self-help groups (SHGs) received different equipment in support of their business projects. Members of 45 SHGs participated in different capacity building and business mentoring workshops, exchange visits between Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan within the PBF project. 6 Association of SHGs formed to continue established self-financing mechanisms and revolving funds, as well as support ongoing and new business projects in border villages.
2024 Narrative: The PBF cross-border project facilitated two impactful exchange visits, showcasing significant outcomes for self-help groups (SHGs) and local self-government (LSG) representatives: A delegation of 27 SHG and LSG representatives from Kyrgyzstan visited six successful business projects established by SHGs in Dustlik and Kairoki villages of Namangan district, Uzbekistan. And a total of 55 SHG and LSG representatives from Uzbekistan toured six innovative business projects organized by SHGs in Alabuka district, Kyrgyzstan. These exchange visits not only strengthened bilateral relationships but also explored new avenues for cooperation and economic development. The success of SHG-led ventures in a different context, fostering mutual learning and collaboration, and demonstration of valuable insights into entrepreneurial practices increased economic ties between the two countries.UNFPA continued to support the capacity building of madrasah teachers and representatives of the religious women centers on reproductive health topics. 60 madrasah teachers capacitated on health education and 62 representatives of religious women centers increased their knowledge on safe motherhood and cervical cancer.A total of 40 young people were engaged in UNFPA Policies and practices communities (PPC) initiative in Muras Ordo. The youth participated in various activities, including capacity-building sessions, community meetings, and intergenerational dialogue workshops. In the living settlement of Muras Ordo, a community initiative was implemented jointly with the Mayor's Office to address social issues, focusing on intergenerational dialogue, creating a green space, and improving mental health and well-being.

2023 Narrative: 38 WSCOs and 495 women from nine municipalities of Batken province, who live in border villages affected by military conflict, improved their skills to interact constructively and collaboratively with local and national government representatives to raise their concerns. This achievement is attributed to the use of innovative tools during Speed Data consultations, which allowed for prompt feedback and ideas from participants on a wide range of issues, and Design Thinking Workshops that were conducted after consultations to discuss ideas and co-create solutions to address gender, peace, and climate change issues affecting their communities. Women from diverse backgrounds, including those who are most disadvantaged, shared their experiences and visions to inform LSGs and local socio-economic development plans being elaborated.
2024 Narrative: During 2024, the capacity of nine Local Self Governments of Batken province to integrate gender responsive budgeting, localize and implement national action plan 1325 using inclusive approaches also for Local Socio-Economic Development Planing was strengthened. These contributed significantly to improving trust and collaboration between LSGs and the local population including women, people affected by conflict, migrants and other vulnerable groups, who report that they would turn for help in solving controversial issues at local level to LSGs. In addition, the joint CSOs and Ministry of Interior working group conducted monitoring of the NAP 1325 for the period of 2023-2024 and during the workshop that engaged inter-ministerial group and CSOs parnters, new priorities for the NAP 1325 for 2025-2026 were developed.

2022 Narrative: UNDP: -Following the establishment of cooperation with 5 municipalities, events were organized in each of them to consult the young people for their local needs and establishment/development of local youth councils. Alongside with the Needs assessment, these consultations contributed to the creation of the action plan for support of establishment/development of local youth councils in each of the 5 municipalities.-       Thematic working group consisted of 26 members of municipal councils was established within the Association of units of local self-government (ZELS). 16 members of the municipal councils were trained on youth questions on local level following a tailor-made Training Manual on youth policies on local level.-       Study on constructive narratives was produced following a thorough analysis on situation with divisive society in North Macedonia, Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo and Serbia. The study contains 40 case-studies of projects for constructive narratives on local level and a roadmap for municipalities for further actions in the field.-       Agency for youth and sport was supported in the creation of the National Strategy for youth through a consultative process with young people and all relevant stakeholders. Series of constitutive meetings were organized as well as online consultations.
2023 Narrative: UNDP- Youth council established in Municipality of Gostivar. Youth councils strenthened in Municipalities of Bitola, Veles and Ohrid.Youth initatives supported in Gostivar, Bitola, Veles, Struga and Ohrid.
2024 Narrative: UNDP- In cooperation with the Ministry of Social Affairs, demography and youth, the project “Youth 4 Inclusion, Equality  Trust” contributed to the implementation of the National Youth Strategy 2023-2027 through capacity building of youth officers from national institutions and municipalities on youth policies. The project activities contributed to the implementation of the Law on youth participation in North Macedonia by support of youth policies in 5 municipalities: Bitola, Veles, Gostivar, Ohrid and Struga through implementation of youth initiatives and strengthening the municipal youth councils.

SDG Targets: 3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,3.8 Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.,5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.,5.2 Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.,10.2 By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.,10.3 Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.,10.4 Adopt policies, especially fiscal, wage and social protection policies, and progressively achieve greater equality.

QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Contribute to the right on Health
2024 Narrative: The situational analysis report on adolescents and youth in Turkmenistan was commissioned by UNFPA to examine the enabling environment and current state of youth development in the country and provide recommendations for future policy. The report draws from extensive literature reviews, focus group discussions with 77 adolescents and youth, and key informant interviews with national partners and UN agencies.While Turkmenistan has shown a commitment to youth development through national policies and international agendas, gaps remain in data collection and implementation. The report indicates that youth are eager to participate in society, but that opportunities and access to information are limited. The existing legal framework promotes youth participation, but there is a lack of established mechanisms and youth-led platforms.Key areas of concern include health and social protection, education and employment, gender equality, and marginalized youth. While progress has been made in certain areas, such as sexual and reproductive health and rights, challenges persist due to cultural barriers, limited access to information, and gendered social norms. The report emphasizes the need for increased investment in mental health support, recreational opportunities, social protection, and climate resilience for young people.The education system, while inclusive, requires improvements in teacher training and modernization of vocational education. The transition to work life remains challenging, with high rates of youth unemployment and a need for better career guidance and employment support services. Gender inequality continues to affect young women's access to education, employment, and social participation.The report concludes with recommendations for the UN and national partners to strengthen data collection, promote youth participation, and address gaps in services and opportunities for adolescents and youth in Turkmenistan.

2022 Narrative: Within the framework of the regional project, UNFPA supported the Agency of Youth and Sports in the development of a new National Youth Strategy 2023-2027. In particular, UNFPA fully supported the work in 3 out of 8 thematic areas (Education, Health and Culture), by engaging local experts, organizing 24 consultative thematic working groups; in addition, in order to ensure transparency and inclusiveness, additional consultative meetings with different target groups were organized (organizations working with persons with disabilities, high schools students and university students associations, youth from rural areas and youth coming from disadvantaged groups). The first draft of the strategy was finalized in December and the process is expected to be finalized in Q1 - 2023.

Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 4 - Inclusive and equitable social development

Sub-Output: Continue building and maintaining the Network of Youth Peer Educators on Life Skills from Vocational Education and Training
Description: Implementation initiated in 2020 and continues until 2022 as part of the project ‘Develop life skills and healthy behaviors of students in Vocational Education & Training for their development and job readiness’ is implemented by the United Nations Population Fund with the co-financing from the Austrian Development Agency from funds of Austrian Development Cooperation and UNFPA and in partnership with the Ministry of Education, Culture and Research.
Contributing partners: Moldova Ministry of Education, Culture and Research
Implementation partners: Moldova Ministry of Education, Culture and Research, Terre des Hommes
SDG Targets: 3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 4 Quality Education
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
Established in September 2020, with continued investments during 2021, the “Network of VET Youth Peer Educators on Life Skills” has become functional. It includes 74 peer educators (students from 12 Vocational Education and Training schools) who delivered peer education activities to 2085 young people (650 boys and 1435 girls) in 2021. In total, 2327 VET students have been reached by peer educators since September 2020 when the Network was established.  

To ensure the quality of peer education activities, peer educators have passed a complex training program, which also included an offline summer camp. They have learned about healthy nutrition, prevention of bullying and GBV, sexuality, and changes in puberty, HIV and STIs prevention, prevention of teenage pregnancy, etc. Due to the extended COVID-19 period and restrictions for offline events, to ensure meaningful and equitable engagement of peer educators they have been equipped with tablets and the internet. 
The Network of Peer Educators teamed up with Pupils Council in VET and jointly organized an informational Campaign on preventing HIV/AIDS starting with December 1st. Moreover, 311 parents of VET students have been taught by psychologists and specialists on adolescents' development how to support their children in a safe transition to adulthood. 

The main UNFPA implementing partner in building the Network is Foundation Terr des Homme Moldova, with core funds from the Austrian Development Agency and co-financing from UNFPA.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Human capital development, reducing vulnerability, social inclusion
Outcome: By 2027, all people, especially the vulnerable, benefit from strengthened human capital including early childhood development, and more resilient, gender-responsive, and quality healthcare and education
Output: 3.2. Quality education
Sub-Output: Support the national authorities in creating inclusive and equitable quality education for refugees and stateless children and youth at all levels.
Description: In 2024, UNHCR worked to support the education of refugee children, with the focus on increasing the primary school enrolment rate for Ukrainian refugees and the provision of support in overcoming language, cultural, psychological and other obstacle to equitable and quality education, to result in a better learning outcome for refuge children. As a result of the serial of workshops with refugee parents, which were coordinated by the Ministry of Education, Innovation and Science, the primary school enrollment rate of Ukrainian refuges increased. In addition, as a result of the improved cooperation on with the Ministry and upon the UNHCR’s advocacy efforts,  the Law on General Education was amended to include stateless persons and to ensure adequate support to refugee children. The need for a specific support to refuge children was also acknowledged in the Strategy of Education to cover the period up until 2030, which was enabled in cooperation with UNICEF.
Agencies: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Contributing partners: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Implementation partners: Ministry of Education Montenegro, NGO Red Cross Montenegro
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.
QCPR function: Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Data Collection and Analysis, Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Normative Support, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: UNHCR, within its age, gender and diversity (AGD) approach, ensures that the needs and aspirations of women and girls are particularly taken into account in the process of design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation project cycle. Due to the proportionally high number of women among the temporary protection holders, the porgrammes in relation to this group were particularly designed to address their needs in terms of education.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2023 Narrative: UNHCR has been an important partner to the Ministry of Education in ensuring inclusive and equitable quality education for refugee children, with a particular focus on the refugee children from Ukraine. UNHCR convened numerous meetings to provide the Ministry of Education and other relevant counterparts with the technical expertise and the data from the field obtained in a direct outreach with refugees necessary for an adequate response to the increasing education needs of refugee children.
2024 Narrative: Refugee children still need additional support in overcoming language, cultural, psychological and other obstacles to ensure they have access to equitable and quality education that would ensure that they complete their education with relevant skills, knowledge and competencies.Through a series of workshops, UNHCR directly reached Ukrainian refugees and raised awareness of the importance of school enrollment. It also provided information about the enrollment procedures and offered legal support related to enrollment. However, the schools are struggling with capacities, and those schools with the highest number of refugee children cannot provide sustainable and adequate support to children. Teachers also lack the capacity and skills to work with refugee children, which needs to be tackled in the upcoming period.The overall school enrollment rate among Ukrainian refugees has increased in comparison to the previous year, but it still stands low at 20-25% of children from Ukraine attending Montenegrin schools. The vast majority of refugee children from Ukraine participate in online school. UNHCR, together with the Ministry of Education and UNICEF, will continue to undertake efforts to boost the enrollment rate and provide conditions for refugee children to be able to maximise their learning outcomes.

2021 Narrative: In the 2nd quarter of 2021 UNODC Regional Programme for Afghanistan and Neighboring Countries in partnership with the Prevention, Treatment and Rehabilitation Section (PTRS) of UNODC Headquarters   convened a regional webinar on “Listen First Initiative”. Representatives from the Ministry of Health and Medical Industry, Ministry of Sport and Youth Policy and the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Turkmenistan participated in the webinar. The participants developed their skills in prevention of drug use among youth through raising awareness around listening to children and youth as the first step to help them grow healthy and safe.

Description: It is aimed to contribute to strengthening youth resilience through increased youth leadership and engagement into local community projects. The overall purpose of this project is to contribute to alleviating the structural factors that compel youth of Turkmenistan to resort to migration from Turkmenistan as the first remedy. The project will target both returning youth migrants as well as those among youth who plan to migrate.
Contributing partners: Eurasia Foundation
Implementation partners: International Organization for Migration

Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2022 Narrative: 1.   80 % of youth participating in the project that declare being engaged and having increased leadership and management skills at the end of the project. Ideas Fair, Training seminars on Project design and management, Information coverage of social projects were organised to increase the knowledge and practical skills in usage of new media tools and initiate the project proposals. The Youth Leadership Camp organised, and 40 motivated and enthusiastic youth established good networking with talented young people and professionals from all over the country, improved the skills and generated the ideas for future activities/projects;2.   Four categories of Grants were planned:   Youth Leadership Grants (up to 5,000 USD), Innovative Solution Grants (up to 17,000 USD), Social Idea Accelerator Grant (up to 15,000 USD) and Grants for small pilot social projects (up to 17,000 USD)a.   The selection process for several Grants were conducted ( Youth Leadership, Innovative Solution)b.   within the Youth Leadership Grants 9 Youth projects initiated and funded. The projects are covering the following issues:•        Community development projects that build infrastructure, services and systems that improve the lives of youth•        Youth empowerment initiatives that promote volunteering, respect for diversity and inclusivity •        Youth advocacy initiatives that promote youth involvement in local decision-making and youth constituency needsIt has been realised in close partnership with local NGOs.  3 NGOs strengthened their institutional capacity by participation in the Institutional Development Program through increasing the knowledge of employees and design a Plan for activity and financial sustainability.
2023 Narrative: 876 people from vulnerable groups of population, including people with disabilities, unemployed youth, low-income families (55% female and 45% male) from Ashgabat, Ahal, Balkan and Mary regions were able to build up their problem-solving, team building, leadership, networking, communication and management skills through IOM small-grant capacity building youth-led projects. The most successful of them established the Children’s Recreation Center for people with disabilities at the Sports Club of Disabled People and a sewing workshop in Mary region, held phycological rehabilitation training for late-blinded people in Ashgabat, Akhal and Balkan regions, launched the Volunteer Academy course in Ashgabat, improved knowledge of school children on environmental issues in Mary region, equipped a volleyball sport club for integration of visually impaired people into sports activities in Ashgabat, conducted a series of training on Tourism Tour Guides for peers in Mary region.

Agencies: United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights
Contributing partners: Core Funding, Government of Sweden
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
2022 Narrative: 30 national Media professionals, journalists and bloggers strengthened their knowledge about the human rights situation of Roma refugees, and the multiple vulnerabilities they facing in exercising their rights by participating in a Media brunch organized by OHCHR in October 2022. Roma refugees shared their personal stories, that were further used for production of video reportages, audio podcasts and online media articles about the situation of Roma Refugees in Moldova.22 human rights activists and representatives of vulnerable groups from the Transnistrian region successfully completed an 18-months Human Rights Capacity Building Program, following a final testing and were awarded with diplomas of completion. Four advocacy papers and one video animation product were developed and submitted by participants to duty bearers to address human rights issues and concerns in relation to persons with disabilities, survivors of domestic violence, Roma, people living with HIV. In the period April - May 2022, 19 trainings targeting more than 287 participants (double increase in comparison with initially planned indicator) were conducted for persons with disabilities and their family members, Roma community, community of people living with HIV, and women who had experienced gender-based violence, with the participation of de-facto authorities. Representatives of vulnerable groups benefited from knowledge and practical application of human-rights based approach, as well as recent amendments and advancement in the regulatory framework for increased compliance with international standards and human rights obligations for vulnerable groups (persons with disabilities, people living with HIV, Roma, survivors of domestic violence).OHCHR engaged extensively with OPDs in different contexts, such as: Disability taskforce as part of the Interagency coordination forum in the context of refugee response; UNPRPD project - creation of regional advocacy groups (3 regional advocacy groups); Platform for monitoring international HR recommendations - evaluation of disability specific recommendations. In addition the organizations participated in the evaluation of the National Human Rights Action Plan. Moreover, at least 30 persons with disabilities, OPDs and CSOs providing services for persons with disabilities participated in the on-line meeting on UNDIS consultations. Also, expert consultations with OPDs and CSOs in the field on disability inclusive indicators as part of the indicator matrix in the context of the new country framework was conducted.

2022 Narrative: In 2022, UNFPA continued to support the National Network of Youth Klinic to reach out to young people with information about sexual and reproductive health and rights. In that regards, UNFPA supported the annual summer school of the 170 participants volunteers and volunteers’ coordinators representing 32 YK participated, so they can strategize and plan better their out reach activities. YK Volunteers implemented 2473 activities (only 10 % of its in online format) with a total of 22082 beneficiaries, including 2520 participants on the board game 'Fara Tabu'  developed by UNFPA and donated to all 41 Youth Klinics in the country.

2021 Narrative:
10 women suvivors of violence are ready to conduct peer-to-peer support and awareness raising activities on EVAW area to women victims/survivors of violence, as a result of the coaching, facilitation activities, including art terapy sessions provided by the UNW in partnership with the National Coalition Life without violence and WLC NGO.

On November 25, 2021, a Dialogue with 9 Conquerors of Violence was organized. The event was organized by the Parliament of the Republic of Moldova and UN Women in partnership with the Swedish Embassy as part of the UN Secretary-General's Campaign, which marks the annual campaign on the Elimination of Violence against Women "16 Days of Activism Against Gender-Based Violence". The purpose of the event was to make the voices and perspectives of survivors of gender-based violence heard. The event brought together representatives of Parliament, the Government, civil society and development partners with survivors of violence, to convey a common call for the elimination of gender-based violence

20 women survivors of domestic violence have been involved in 5 art therapy workshops and created 5 symbolic works through the quilling art method, as a result of the event conducted by the WLC in the Parliament of the Republic of Moldova in order to raise awareness among the authorities and citizens about the seriousness of the phenomenon and to emphasize once again the importance of services and support needed by women who don’t feel safe in their own home during the closure of the annual campaign on the Elimination of Violence against Women "16 Days of Activism Against Gender-Based Violence . 31 people, out of which 27 women and 2 men, 2 nonbinary people and 1 woman with disabilities, both program participants and their friends and relatives from Chisinau, Balti, Soroca, Cimislia, Budesti, Falesti, Cricova, Criulen district, Ocnita district, are ready to identify and promote innovative approaches on EVAW, as a result of mentoring program“Youth for Gender Equality”, implemented by the GENDERDOC-M Information Centre and Women for Women NGO as well as of the result of the 9 community-based initiatives developed by themselves together with the mentors tackling issues as sexual harrasment, discrimination, stereotypes and gender inequalities (info on each project is attached).

2023 Narrative: Enhancing the U-Platform.by on education and engagement of young people remained a priority. The total number of registered users reached 1,741. The U-Platform’s content was enhanced to be accessible for people with vision impairments. The Belarusian version was introduced and reviewed together with Belarusian-speaking youth. Five new online courses were developed, including an interactive self-paced course on digital literacy; a supervised digital course to build technical skills for creating online courses for the U-Platform; a course on content creation tested by 24 representatives of Youth Parliaments; a digital course on UPSHIFT; and a course for Adolescent Parliaments covering parliamentarism, inclusion, SDGs, and communication with media.UNICEF continued to engage youth through popular bloggers producing podcasts on issues of importance for young people such as bullying online, creative thinking and emotional intelligence, etc. The podcasts were broadcasted through free podcast platforms, UNICEF social networks and promoted by bloggers with the total outreach over 70,000 users. Engagement and integration of vulnerable adolescent groups, including Ukrainian refugees, was enhanced through developing universal skills (i.e., critical thinking, creativity, collaboration, communication) and building their resilience through coping techniques. A local NGO trained 60 adolescents, including Ukrainian refugees and adolescents living with HIV, on peer support and volunteer activities. Trained peer support volunteers provided counselling sessions to 180 adolescents in 10 cities and coordinated 7 volunteer initiatives for 524 adolescents including 115 adolescent Ukrainian refugees (57 girls and 58 boys aged 10-19). As a result of counselling support, adolescents reported feeling more connected, less reserved, and more resilient to challenges.

Description:
-  Y-peer education activities: 15 Youth Peer education trainings and youth network coordination meetings
- Condom distribution and promotion activities
Contributing partners: United Nations Population Fund
Implementation partners: Kosova Population Foundation (KOPF)
SDG Targets: 3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,5.6 Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

2021 Narrative:
Peer education: UNFPA implementing partners, continued working with young people and addressing their Sexual and Reproductive health needs, according to their age, thereby expanding access to gender-sensitive, life skills-based sexual and reproductive health information to empower them to make informed choices regarding their reproductive health and to take leadership in sharing their knowledge on Sexual and Reproductive Health with their peers. Implemented activities aimed at increasing knowledge and awareness about SRH/RR, prevention of teenage pregnancies, HIV infections, Gender-Based Violence, and safe sex. Three hundred and forty-one (341) young people are certified as master trainers, during the ToTs. The majority of participants were young girls and smaller number of boys. On average, pre-test results were 62% right answers; post-test 82% with an increase of knowledge by 20%. Trainings were organized in cities but also in small places, where sexuality education in schools is not yet at a desirable level.
Small group information sessions on SRHR continue to be organized at the student dormitory. This year, 10 sessions were organized, with the participation of 44 students, and most of them reported becoming regular condom users, requesting a monthly supply of free of charge condoms from the KOPF. The online reach of young people is 148,329.
 
 Social marketing and Condom promotion activities:  UNFPA continued to support successful social marketing component. This year, UNFPA supported KOPF to procure a new stock of one million Love Plus condoms, through third-party procurement procedures.
 In 2021, through social marketing, 579,183 condoms were sold and 4,000 condoms and 3,600 IEC materials were distributed free during different outreach youth activities.
Condom promotion activities included Small group sessions with youth (students), Info Point Stands, Marking of SHR/RR-related workdays (including World Contraceptive Day, World AIDS Day, European HIV Testing Week).
  • During the Info Point stand in Mitrovica for marking European HIV Testing Week (29-29 Nov 2021) youth distributed condoms, IEC materials, and other promotional materials in order to raise awareness about contraceptives and SRH in general. 1,500 free-of-charge condoms and around 1,200 IEC materials were distributed during the event.
 Marking World AIDS Day 2021 we organized in Ferizaj Info Point Stand and distributed condoms, IEC materials, and other promotional materials in order to raise awareness about contraceptives and SRH in general. 1,300 free of charge condoms and around 1,400 IEC materials were distributed during the event
• During the Info Point stand in Mitrovica for marking European HIV Testing Week (29-29 Nov 2021) youth distributed condoms, IEC materials, and other promotional materials in order to raise awareness about contraceptives and SRH in general. 1,500 free-of-charge condoms and around 1,200 IEC materials were distributed during the event.
 Marking World AIDS Day 2021 we organized in Ferizaj Info Point Stand and distributed condoms, IEC materials, and other promotional materials in order to raise awareness about contraceptives and SRH in general. 1,300 free-of-charge condoms and around 1,400 IEC materials were distributed during the event.

Output: 4.3. Citizens` participation
Sub-Output: Leveraging communication,advocacy, risk communication and community engagement  to generate and maintain public interest and awareness of child rights issues and promote youth participation in media and civic space
Description: Generate and maintain public interest and awareness of child rights issues, promote youth participation in the media, quality media production for, about and with children and ethical reporting on child rights issues including support to relevant institutions to strengthen risk communication and community engagement capacities
Contributing partners: European Union, Government of Sweden, United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: NGO Organisation for Improving relations between media and youth
SDG Targets: 4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: 10 girls and 6 boys are part of an inclusive group of UNICEF Montenegro young reporters who are in charge of UNICEF Montenegro IG and TikTok and contributing actively to having the voices of youth heard in the public debate on child rights
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Inclusion of the voices of youth in the public debate on child rights issues helps create a more participatory, inclusive and democratic society that respects human rights of all children and youth equally.
LNOB groups targeted: Human rights defenders (incl. NGOs, journalists, union leaders, whistleblowers…) , LGBTI persons (sexual orientation and gender identity), Refugees & Asylum Seekers, Minorities, Stateless Persons, Youth, Persons With Disabilities, Children , Women & Girls
2023 Narrative: UNICEF remains the strongest UN brand in the country – 9 out of 10 respondents have heard of it and have a positive opinion about it. More than 2,200 media reports mentioning UNICEF were generated in 2023. Child poverty, violence, health and education were published on the front pages of dailies more than 40 times and these articles mentioned UNICEF. The number of UNICEF Montenegro social media followers (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, LinkedIn, TikTok and YouTube) increased by 4 per cent from 121,384 to 126,013. In 2023, the UNICEF Montenegro website gained 214,000 new users. One of the key highlights of UNICEF public advocacy and comms was related to the parliamentary elections. Within the two weeks before the national parliamentary elections, media releases with calls to action to all political actors were published by UNICEF and NGOs with the aim of focusing the pre-election public debate on the best ways for Montenegro’s new government to decrease child poverty and all forms of violence, as well as to improve access to and the quality of education and health for every child. Also, a youth political campaign was led by an inclusive group of UNICEF Montenegro Young Reporters. It culminated in a live two-hour dialogue two days before the elections, with representatives of all political lists answering questions from young people from all over the country about what they would do to resolve issues in education, violence against children, youth mental health, climate crisis and child poverty. Meetings with the president, prime minister, ministers, mayors and other decision makers were used as opportunities for communicating publicly key priorities and asks for children. Safer Internet Day, International Education Day, International Day of Persons with Disabilities, World Children’s Day, World Parents’ Day, World Poverty Day, World Breastfeeding Week, World Immunization Week, World AIDS Day, International Volunteers’ Day, Human Rights Day and others were marked. As a result, nationally representative research from 2023 shows that there is significant public support for prioritizing child rights issues. Eighty-nine per cent of citizens support inclusive education. Seventy-six per cent support fostering and adoption instead of placing children without parental care in an institution. Sixty-three per cent think corporal punishment is unacceptable. Nine out of ten think the government should have a reduction in violence and child poverty, and improvement of the quality of education and health care for every child and family as its priorities in the coming period.
2024 Narrative: One of the key highlights of UNICEF’s public advocacy and comms, led by an inclusive group of UNICEF Montenegro’s young reporters, was related to the municipal elections in the capital. During the two weeks before the elections, media release and social media videos with the voices of young people concerning things that girls and boys want from the new local government were published on UNICEF’s social media with the aim of focusing the pre-election public debate on the best ways for the local government to support the quality of life of all children and families in the capital. 1 in 4 citizens aged 18 and above noticed UNICEF young reporters in 2024, while this percentage increases to 1 in 3 among citizens aged 18-29. 8 out of 10 citizens consider them a good role model for youth in the country.A visit by the Regional Director, the Barnahus regional conference and meetings with the President, Prime Minister, Ministers, Mayors and other decision-makers and partners were used as opportunities for publicly communicating the key priorities and requests for children.Safer Internet Day, International Education Day, International Day of the Girl Child, International Day of Persons with Disabilities, World Children’s Day (WCD), World Parents’ Day, World Teachers’ Day, World Poverty Day, World Breastfeeding Week, World  European Immunization Week and others were celebrated, as well as COP29. “Child Rights at the Heart of the EU accession process and the 2030 Agenda” conference was organized by UNICEF in cooperation with the Government of Montenegro and the EU, and with support from the Peace Building Fund, on the occasion of the 35th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. It ended with a call to action to the government to keep child rights at the heart of the EU accession process by implementing the MICS survey in 2025, developing the new Strategy on Child Rights, investing sufficient funds for quality services for children and families, and applying for the EU Child Guarantee to obtain additional resources for reforms for children. It created significant social and traditional media coverage.Nationally representative research from 2024 shows that there is significant public support for prioritizing child rights issues:8 out of 10 citizens support inclusive education and t fostering and adoption instead of placing children without parental care in an institution; two thirds (66%) think corporal punishment is unacceptable: 6 out of 10 limit time and media content that the children follow and talk to children about this; 63 percent say to check information from media that sound suspicious to them by looking it up in other sources, talking to experts, friends, etc.

This will also include work in relation to curriculum reform and support to teachers in promoting skills among children and youth

Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 5.3 Output 5.3. Governance system capacity and regulatory framework on Disaster Risk Reduction and natural/cultural heritage protection are strengthened to effectively deliver on obligations under the Sendai Framework on DRR and related Conventions
2023 Narrative: In Uzbekistan, UNICEF partnered with ICP to engage young volunteers, adolescent girls and boys in ten selected target schools from Tashkent and Termez cities, Chirchiq, Yuqorichirchiq, Kasansai and Bulungur districts in community DRR, climate change adaptation, disaster preparedness, and comprehensive school safety. Three-day training seminars were organized in Tashkent and Samarkand for 45 teachers from target schools in two cohorts on 21st-century skills, time management, stress management, DRR and climate change. Furthermore, ICP organized five training seminars for 232 (125 boys, 107 girls) adolescent girls and boys, members of newly established School DRR clubs in each target school for engaging in community resilience and school safety, including search and rescue operations and first aid. 125 volunteers of RCSU, in turn, supported the School DRR Clubs to conduct simulations and drills on how to act in emergency situations. Finally, the trained teachers and RCSU volunteers organized seminars on youth engagement and action planning for the school DRR club members. As a result, the schoolchildren from the School DRR Clubs in the target schools engaged in community and school observations, interviews with teachers, parents and community members, and reviews of school preparedness plans. The School DRR Club members developed their school hazard profiles, drafted action plans to improve disaster preparedness, and showcased them to the school community members.

Description: Unleashing Employment and Income Generating Opportunities for Rural Youth in Armenia
Contributing partners: Government of Russia
Implementation partners: Armenia Ministry of Education, Science, Culture and Sport
SDG Targets: 1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.,8.3 Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.
SDG Goals: 1 No Poverty, 4 Quality Education, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth
Geography: Vayots Dzor, Syunik, Kotayk, Gegharkunik, Armenia
QCPR function: Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Data Collection and Analysis, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2022 Narrative: UNDP facilitated availability of up-to-date labor market information for decision-makers in charge of reforms in vocational education and training. UNDP efforts in this direction addressed the demand and supply mismatch in the labor market as one of the reasons of unemployment, particularly among the youth. To address this gap, UNDP developed methodology for analysis of demand and supply of skilled labor force for planning of annual enrollments at Technical and Vocational Training Institutes. To ensure the vocational education system equips students with in-demand skillset, UNDP completed development/revision of state competency-based education standards with corresponding modular programs for a number of occupations in high demand. To enhance the capacities of local vocational institutions for delivering modern curricula, UNDP equipped 10 of them with IT, sewing and greenhouse production equipment, benefiting 2,537 students (women 1,395, men 1,142), and strengthened the capacities of 620 teaching staff (women 434, men 186). For higher efficiency of career guidance system, UNDP trained overall 100 career counselors (all women). As part of its efforts towards strengthening the human capital in the regions of Armenia, UNDP helped 80 young people (women 45, men 35) develop transferable skills and facilitated the labor market entry of 90 youths (women 50, men 40) through active labor market programmes.
2023 Narrative: UNDP continued supporting the institutional capacity building of state bodies responsible for formulation and implementation of employment policy with a quantitative methodology on analyses of labor market demand and supply in cooperation with State Statistical Committee and international experts. As part of its broader efforts in this realm, UNDP continued strengthening the career guidance system in vocational education through capacity building of 104 (women 95%) career guidance and professional orientation specialists.Simultaneously, 2,258 youths (1,204 women, 1,054 men) accessed labor market responsive training with UNDP support through modernized laboratories (IT and design) in 8 vocational facilities. To ensure wider outreach and inclusion into innovative non-formal training, especially for young women and NEET youth, UNDP partnered with “Technological Training Center-Federation of Armenian Associations Auvergne Rhone Alpes” Educational Foundation for launching an online learning platform with 500 students on innovative low carbon technologies highly needed in the labor market.Overall, 150 young people (women-70, men-80) increased their employability with UNDP support accessing upskilling/reskilling opportunities in the growth sectors of Armenia through non-formal training, business capacity development and on-the-job training programs. This provided 66 youths (women-37, men-29) with decent jobs across the regions of Armenia.
2024 Narrative: UNDP leveraged innovative digital solutions as a development enabler to enhance the institutionalcapacity the state bodies responsible for employment and VET policies through 2 innovative modelsaimed at labor market (LM) demand and supply analyses in cooperation with the National Center forEducational Technologies (www.ktak.am). One of the innovative models refers to the upgrade of theEdu2Work platform with VET data. The other model aims at identifying the career paths of VET alumni.Through 2 digital models, now the respective line ministry has access to real-time data and is enabled tomake evidence-based decisions on the ongoing VET reforms [E46-47]. As part of its broader efforts,UNDP continues capacitating 100 career guidance specialists (95% women) in analyses of LMinformation. Simultaneously, more than 170 VETIs’ directors/deputy directors increased their knowledgein “Strategic Management of VETIs” aimed at enhancing the quality of VET. As part ofcompetency-based VET, 105 students (48w) accessed newly established 4 workshops (welding, sewing,driving, photovoltaic systems) followed by the training of 24 VET teachers in the field of solar energy. Topromote the digital and inclusive agenda in the VET, UNDP equipped the National Centre for VocationalEducation and Training Development (www.mkuzak.am) with a server to enable information exchangeamong VET institutions. In the field of non-formal education, especially for refugees and NEET youth,UNDP partnered with “Aren Meghrabyan Foundation” in the implementation of 2 trainings for 72 youngpeople on 3D Modeling and Web Design. In bordering areas, UNDP provided grants to 13 MSEs tosustain and enlarge businesses, create new jobs (33), and strengthen resilience to external shocks. WithUNDP support 601 (479w) people benefited from upskilling/reskilling opportunities. Through on-the-jobtraining with 219 regional employers, 525 displaced population (441w) have been integrated into thelabour market, and 247 people (47%) have secured decent jobs after completion of the training inArmenia [E11].

2022 Narrative: The "Network of VET Youth Peer Educators on Life Skills" continued to conduct informative activities with peers in their schools. During 2022, 74 youth peer educators (10 boys and 64 girls) have organised 124 peer-to-peer activities (online, hybrid, and/or offline modality) involving 4867 young people (2494 girls and 2373 boys, out of which 21 young people with disabilities) from targeted VET institutions.Peer-to-peer educators held discussions with their peers on topics such as violence prevention, reproductive health, contraception, hygiene, addictions (drugs, alcohol, etc.), stereotypes, etc. During the activities with their peers, educators used board games together with the board game "Fara tabu".

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Social cohesion, people-centered governance, rule of law and human rights
Outcome: By 2027, all people, especially the vulnerable, benefit from improved social cohesion, increased realization of human rights and rule of law and accountable, gender-responsive institutions
Output: 4.3. Citizens` participation
Sub-Output: Fostering social cohesion through empowering and engaging children and youth to participate in developing child-centered policies (Joint PBF program)
Description:
Joint UN Project: Enhancing citizens’ trust in institutions and building resilient communities, UNICEF component, including:
1. Support children, adolescents, and youth, including through youth organizations and CSOs, to contribute to local and national dialogues and Local and national Social Cohesion Pledges as active citizens and agents of social cohesion. 
2. Enhance the skills, capacities and resilience of children, adolescents, parents/caregivers, and teachers through civic education programmes, caregivers` support and peaceful conflict resolution to apply core values and competencies leading to peaceful, and inclusive societies. 
3. Establishment of a Social Cohesion Innovation Lab to drive online and offline community-led solutions
4. Support Young Reporters initiative aimed at promoting quality and continuous participation of adolescent girls and boys, including those from marginalized groups, in the public debate on social cohesion. 
5. Strengthen local and national institutional capacities and tools for the participatory development, adoption, and implementation of social cohesion pledges 
6. Strengthen capacities of the Parliament of Montenegro and selected local parliaments for improved oversight and contribution to dialogue on social cohesion, including active participation and engagement of children and youth in the work of local and national parliaments. 
7. Strengthening institutional capacity and mechanisms for research and independent monitoring of hate speech, violence, divisive narratives, including the spread of mis/dis-information, both online and offline
8. Build national capacities for evidence-based social cohesion policy making by using behavioural insights and nationally representative public perception surveys before and after the Project to measure the impact and to inform, design and implement targeted social and behavioral change strategies and actions 
9.Launch a multi-platform communications and advocacy initiative to counter divisive narratives and normalization of hate speech and violence and support a culture of trust, dialogue, and collaborative vision. 
10. Strengthen capacities of women politicians through capacity building of Women clubs in National and Local Parliaments
Contributing partners: The UN Secretary-General’s Peacebuilding Fund (UN Peace Fund)
Implementation partners: Council on the Rights of the Child Montenegro, Ministry of Education Montenegro, Office for Sustainable Development Montenegro, Ombudsman Montenegro
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,10.2 By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.,16.7 Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 10 Reduced Inequalities, 16 Peace and Justice - Strong Institutions
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: The project underscores the pivotal role of gender equality in ensuring social cohesion. By actively empowering girls and boys, women and men, decision and opinion makers, the project is challenging the prevailing narratives of gender-based hate speech, violence, sexism, and misogyny, and fosters girls and women's significant contributions and participation in civic and political spheres (output 2.3). By building the capacities of both women and men in key influential roles, including politicians, policymakers, and opinion leaders, the project seeks to pave the way for more inclusive, gender-sensitive approaches, emphasizing safeguarding of progress in achieving gender equality and countering gender equality backlash. The project approach mainstreams gender quality principles, and all activities are based on gender-sensitive approaches.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: The project aims at strengthening institutions by supporting them to be responsive to the results of the inclusive dialogues, reflecting communities’ shared demands and in a participatory manner to adopt and enforce inclusive, gender responsive, rights based, people and child-centered social cohesion policies
Sustaining peace marker: 3 - Sustaining Peace is the principal objective
Sustaining peace marker narrative: The project aims to transform the potentially negative effects of lack of trust and the existence of divisive narratives and hate speech, gender-based and violence against and among children and youth into favorable outcomes - engaging the community, especially disenfranchised groups, in dialogue and thus contributing to building a shared vision of common good, increased inter-community and institutional public trust and greater community resilience to divisions and hate speech
LNOB groups targeted: Youth, Human rights defenders (incl. NGOs, journalists, union leaders, whistleblowers…) , Children , Women & Girls
2024 Narrative: As part of the new joint UN programme on social cohesion, supported by PBF, UNICEF launched activities focusing on capacitating adolescents and youth for civic engagement and participation – including the launch of children parliaments in 5 cities in all three regions. The socio-emotional skills programme was adapted to have a stronger focus on social cohesion, and multiple programmes were implemented focusing on violence prevention and conflict resolution.
